DEBATE.TITLE: DEATH OF FORMER SENATOR CLEMENT FRANK RIDLEY

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! It is with regret that I inform the Senate of the death, on 20 May 1988, of former Senator Clement Frank Ridley, Senator for the State of South Australia from 1959 to 1971.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Button Sen The Hon J.N.

TALKER.NAME: Senator BUTTON
TALKER.ROLE: Leader of the Government in the Senate)

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave-I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That the Senate expresses its deep regret at the death, on 20 May 1988, of Clement Frank Ridley, senator for the State of South Australia from 1959 to 1971, and places on record its appreciation of his long and meritorious public service.

Clement Ridley was a strong supporter of the principles of the Labor and union movement. He concentrated on industrial relations during his 12 years as a senator. He was a Federal President of the Vehicle Builders Employees Union, President of the Trades and Labor Council of South Australia and a South Australian delegate to the Australian Council of Trade Unions. He was also a State Australian Labor Party President. His contribution to the Parliament included being a Temporary Chairman of Committees, a member of the Printing Committee and a member of the Australian delegation to the General Assembly of the United Nations in 1965. Although it is 17 years since Senator Ridley departed from the Senate, I am sure all honourable senators will join with me in regretting the passing of an active parliamentarian.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Chaney Sen The Hon F.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —On behalf of the Opposition I wish to support the motion of condolence moved by the Leader of the Government in the Senate (Senator Button). Clearly Mr Ridley gave signal service to his State and to the Senate. I note that he is another deceased Labor member of parliament who came from the traditional source of members of this place. He was a a skilled tradesman, of whom there are still a few in the Senate. I think Senator Childs is one--
—And Senator Devereux.

—And Senator Devereux, yes. There are still a few of that honoured group in the Parliament, and I welcome that fact, and I support the Leader of the Government in the Senate in his comments about the late Senator Ridley.

SPEECH.PARA: Death of Former Senator Ridley

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Foreman Sen D.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —I would like to add support to this motion. Clem Ridley was a senator, as was mentioned, from South Australia from 1959 until 1971. During that time he served South Australia with distinction. Although the Senate at that time was structured slightly differently from what it is today, in that committees as they are constituted today did not exist, Clem was an active and involved member of the Caucus manpower committee, as it was then known, or as it would be known today, the economic and industrial relations committee. His work on that committee stemmed from his trade union background. Until he came into this place Clem Ridley was Secretary of the Vehicle Builders Employees Union of Australia. In fact he was Federal President of the VBE as well as serving as State President of the South Australian branch of the Trades and Labor Council, as was mentioned by Senator Button. He was also the President of the South Australian branch of the Australian Labor Party.

SPEECH.PARA: Clem Ridley was also a strong supporter of the trade union movement. He used this place to raise important issues that today we take for granted. I make these remarks here today not only on my behalf but also on behalf of my South Australian Senate colleagues and those of Clem Ridley. Time will mourn his passing.

PETITION.TITLE: Telecom Australia: Deregulation and Privatisation
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable President and senators in the Senate in Parliament assembled.

The humble petitioners, the undersigned citizens of Australia, wish to express their opposition to the privatisation and de-regulation of the Australian telecommunications system and to the proposed implementation of timed local calls and directory assistance charging.
Your petitioners pray that the Australian Government will take the necessary action to prevent any such privatisation, de-regulation, timed local calls, and directory assistance charging.

PETITION.TITLE: War Veterans' Benefits and Services
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the President and members of the Senate in Parliament assembled. The humble petition of the undersigned members of the War Veterans' community and concerned citizens respectfully showeth:
That there has been continuous, substantial and damaging erosion of war veterans' benefits and services since May of 1985 in a very wide range of areas;

That it is cruel and cynical of the Government to treat war veterans, many of whom are now advanced in age, in declining health and vulnerable, as expendable and unworthy of optimum care and benefits, when they and their comrades gave of their utmost to this country in its times of greatest need;

Now, therefore your petitioners request that the Senate in Parliament assembled pass appropriate legislation to reverse the decisions of the Government which have brought about the erosion of war veterans' benefits and services.

PETITION.TITLE: Food Irradiation
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the President and members of the Senate in Parliament assembled. The petition of the undersigned respectfully showeth:
That there is widespread concern by farmers and consumers, about the proposal to irradiate food in Australia. Your petitioners most humbly pray that the Senate in Parliament assembled, should
(1) Block the introduction of food irradiation into Australia.
(2) Ban the import of cobalt-60 and caesium-137 and caesium-134 to be used to irradiate food products.
(3) Ban the import of all machinery used for food irradiation (electron beam, X ray etc.).
(4) Ban the importation and sale of irradiated food in Australia.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Preservation of the Environment
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable The President and members of the Senate in Parliament assembled: The petition of the undersigned respectfully showeth:

But for a High Court decision narrowly favouring the Federal Government, 20,000 years old archaeological cave sites near the Franklin River, Tasmania, would have been destroyed, like a United Kingdom Government unable to stop a Wiltshire authority from clearing Stonehenge for a freeway. Constitutional protection for historical and environmental assets is needed.

Your petitioners therefore most humbly pray that the Senate in Parliament assembled should request the Government to hold a referendum to amend the Constitution so that the Federal Government has the bounden constitutional duty, which any citizen may legally require it to perform and a right superior to state and local governments, to set above the commercial advantage of one generation, protect and restore all we hold in trust for the future including relics, sites, features, areas, wildlife, buildings or things of Aboriginal and other historical, cultural, architectural, scientific, aesthetic, ecological or environmental importance and to care for the maintenance of the balance of nature, manage land, marine and atmospheric use so as to avoid their degradation and act nationally and internationally in any matter seen as related to these including to prevent military and commercial use of uranium and derivatives, beach and related mining; to preserve Heritage Areas, The Great Barrier Reef Region at least as originally defined in the 1975 Act and extended into Torres Strait.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: How-to-Vote Cards
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the President and members of the Senate in Parliament assembled. The petition of the undersigned citizens of Australia respectfully showeth that:

Millions of dollars of taxpayers money is spent at each Federal election in Australia in the drafting, production and distribution of How-to-Vote cards which are unnecessary and pollutant and that this waste is not desirable or essential in assisting the electorate to vote informatively for their parliamentarians.

Your petitioners most humbly pray that the Senate in Parliament assembled, should urge the Government to introduce legislation which requires that the registered How-to-Vote cards of all political parties and candidates for political office must be placed under glass in every polling booth within obvious sight of all voters, thus making it unnecessary for How-to-Vote cards to be distributed at future federal elections.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Elector-Initiated Referenda
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the President and members of the Senate in Parliament assembled. The petition of the undersigned citizens of Australia respectfully showeth that:
1. the right of the people of a country to make law independent of politicians should be a basic and independent right;
2. consequently there is an urgent need for constitutional reforms.

Your petitioners most humbly pray that the Senate in Parliament assembled, should support the Constitution Alteration (Electors Initiative) Bill 1987 to alter the constitution so as to vest in the electors power to propose laws and to approve or disapprove such proposed laws.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Constitutional Commission
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the President and members of the Senate in Parliament assembled. The humble petition of the undersigned citizens of Australia showeth:
1. That the constitution of the Commonwealth has served Australia well, is not out of date, has proved to be flexible and should not be radically altered.

2. Our deep concern that the recommendations of the constitutional commission and its advisory committees which propose radical changes to the constitution are threatening to reduce our rights as citizens of the Commonwealth.

3. Our strongest opposition to any referendum proposals of the Hawke Government which gives more power to the government and less to the people and which concentrates that power in Canberra at the expense of the states and weakens the role of the Senate.

PETITION.TITLE: Human Embryo Experimentation Legislation
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the President and members of the Senate in the Parliament assembled. The petition of the undersigned shows:
That human embryos deserve legal protection to enable the development of their full human potential.
Your petitioners request that the Senate, in Parliament assembled, should pass Senator Harradine's Bill to prohibit experiments involving the use of human embryos created by in vitro fertilization.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Elector-Initiated Referenda
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the President and members of the Senate in the Parliament assembled; the humble petition of the undersigned citizens respectively showeth:

That while having some reservations on individual aspects of the Constitutional Initiative (Electors Initiative) 1987 your petitioners wish to express our strong support for the concept of people's democracy implied in that Bill.

Your petitioners therefore humbly pray that the Senate in Parliament assembled will refer the above mentioned Bill to an appropriate Parliamentary Committee and will examine the operation of direct democracy procedures overseas with the intention of passing legislation granting such facilities to your petitioners during the Bicentennial year.

Defence Determinations Nos 6 and 10 of 1988

The Committee sought the Minister's advice on whether legislative criteria existed in Determination No. 6 to guide the exercise of a particular discretion to pay certain allowances. Motor Traffic (Amendment) Ordinance (No. 3) 1988 (A.C.T. Ordinance No. 11 of 1988)

The Committee was concerned about the presence of a strict liability offence in subsection 186a (2) of the Ordinance (``A person shall not remain in or upon a trailer or camper unit that is attached to a motor vehicle whilst the . . . vehicle is being driven . . .''). The Committee considered that the offence should only arise where there existed a deliberate intention to ride on the accessory rather than arise, for example, where a person was ``trapped'' on a trailer etc. when an unwitting or careless driver moved the vehicle. The Minister for the Arts and Territories, the Hon. Gary Punch, M.P., agreed to amend the Ordinance to reflect this change. The Committee agreed with the Minister however, that the offence of actually driving such a vehicle could be in a different category since it was designed to impose upon the driver an obligation prior to driving to check that no one remained in or on the relevant accessory.

Dear Minister,

At its meeting on 17 March 1988, the Committee considered the recently made legislative instruments relating to the administration and control of rifle clubs and associations namely, the Defence (General) Regulations (Statutory Rules 1988 No. 18); the Rifle Clubs (Firearms) Order (published in Gazette No. S 56 of 25 February 1988); and the Rifle Clubs Firearms Order (Amendment) (published in Gazette No. S 66 of 14 March 1988). Each of these instruments was tabled in the Senate on 15 March 1988. The Committee is concerned about some technical aspects of this subordinate law package.

Firstly, the Committee has noted that the enabling power behind the two Rifle Clubs (Firearms) Orders is to be found in section 123g of the Defence Act 1903. Subsection 123g (1) provides that the Minister may make Orders ``for and in relation to the control and administration of rifle ranges''. Subsection 123g (2) provides that ``without limiting the generality of subsection (1) Orders may be made for or in relation to'' various matters, including ``(c) the regulation or prohibition of the carriage, possession or use of firearms on, or in connection with, a rifle range''.
Paragraph 4 of the Order provides that the Order ``applies in relation to firearms owned by members''. Paragraph 5 provides that-

It shall not be necessary for a member [of a rifle club affiliated with the National Rifle Association of Australia or the Australian Small Bore and Air Rifle Association] under or by reason of any law of a State or Territory to obtain or have any licence of permission for:
(a) the use of a firearm on a rifle range during a meeting organised by a club at that range for the purpose of competition or practice;
(b) the carriage of a firearm so used to and from the rifle range and its place of storage; and
(c) the possession of such firearm, provided it is kept in secure storage.

At first sight this appears to amount to an exemption of club members from the firearms control legislation currently operating in Australia. The Committee acknowledges that subsection 123g (5) of the Act provides that Orders are to ``have effect notwithstanding any provision of a law of a State or Territory''. The Committee also acknowledges that subsection 123g (6) provides that subsection (5) is not intended to affect the operation of other laws to the extent that they are capable of operating concurrently with the Orders. It would appear therefore, that a club member may own any number of manual, automatic or semi-automatic firearms which need not be licensed provided every aspect of their use and carriage is related to the rifle range, and provided the armaments are kept ``in secure storage''. The Committee has serious worries about how such a scheme for the control of gun ownership and use can be policed effectively in the interests of public safety.

Granted that the exemption applies only to members of the relevant gun clubs. Granted also that paragraph 3 of the Order provides that ``except to the extent of its explicit provision, this Order is not intended to affect the rules and safety procedures of clubs''. Nevertheless the apparent suspension of gun control laws appears on its face to be so sweeping and so fraught with potential for the break down of control mechanisms that the Committee seeks your expert advice on the following matters-
(i) the nature and details of the controls over club members' guns prior to the making of the Order;
(ii) the nature of the practical effects which the Order will have on those mechanisms for control; and

(iii) whether paragraph 5 of the Order is so wide in its scope that it is beyond the Order-making powers in paragraph 123g (2) (c) of the Defence Act as being a provision that neither prohibits nor regulates the carriage, provision or use of firearms but instead simply suspends the application of existing State and Territory prohibitions and regulations.

Secondly, the Committee has noted from the explanatory statements accompanying the first 2 instruments that ``it is proposed that the new exemption provisions will remain in force for approximately 6 months, to give the rifle clubs and associations time to adjust to State and Territory law, and will then be repealed''. Having considered this legislation as a package, and bearing in mind various public safety consideration which arise from it, the Committee agreed to suggest that the Defence (General) Regulations and the Rifle Clubs (Firearms) Order be each amended by the insertion of an appropriate sunset clause to terminate their operation. This will guarantee that if your proposed timetable for change is not met and the extension of the life of the legislation is necessary, this will require fresh instruments and these will come before the Parliament (and the Committee) for further scrutiny in the usual way.

As a matter of principle the Committee considers that where delegated legislation is acknowledged to be designed for a temporary purpose which is to be achieved within the constraints of a publicly stated timetable, then it is legislatively proper that a suitable sunset clause should emphasise ministerial acceptance of the transitional nature of that legislation.

This delegated legislative package is one of very considerable potential significance to the public and the Parliament. Although intended to maintain in legal force, though by virtue of a different legal instrument, the pre-existing exemptions prescribed by regulation 80 of the Australian Rifle Clubs Regulations, the proposed restructuring of the Clubs and eventual applicability of State and Territory gun and liquor licensing controls and are all matters bearing on a range of public policy and public safety matters of great general interest.

If the present structures and controls, in particular the exemption from gun laws, are intended by the Minister to be temporary then the interests of public safety and efficient public administration of the transition may best be served by inserting sunset clauses into the Order and the Defence (General) Regulations to reflect and guarantee this intent. Such clauses would furnish a definite legislative assurance that this far reaching initiative affecting gun clubs would be tightly and carefully managed to achieve a particular policy goal without delay. The committee makes no comment whatsoever on the merits of this initiative. That is not its role. Our concern is with the legal and public safety implications of delegated legislation which suspends the operation of laws to control guns and liquor.
The Committee would welcome your comments on this proposal.
Yours sincerely,
Bob Collins

Dear Senator Collins

I refer to your letter of 24 March 1988 in which you sought my views on certain matters relating to the Defence (General) Regulations and the Rifle Clubs (Firearms) Order (as amended). I note that you have since given a protective notice of motion with regard to the Order.

At the outset, I would like to say that I share your concern over the unsatisfactory nature of legislation affecting rifle clubs. As there is no longer any real basis for Defence interest in the activities of rifle clubs, there is no justification for general Commonwealth legislation on the matter. As you will appreciate, however, I have been prepared to accept the need for specific provisions of a transitional kind and in areas of difficulty.

Accordingly, I have no difficulty with your suggestion of an express time limit and I would be prepared to sponsor the necessary amendments to include `sunset clauses' in the Defence (General) Regulations and the Rifle Clubs (Firearms) Order. There is, however, a factor which complicates my position on this.

You would be aware that Senator Reid has given notice of a motion for disallowance of Statutory Rules 1988 No. 17 which repealed the Australian Rifle Club Regulations. If this motion succeeds, it will of course revive the former regulations. The legislative position would then be confused, to say the least, with the concurrent operation in the same field of those Regulations, the Defence (General) Regulations, and the Rifle Club (Firearms) Order. Obviously, if the disallowance motion does succeed I will need to review the legislative and other options with respect to rifle clubs.

In discussions over recent weeks about the rifle clubs legislative package and the disallowance motion, there have been some other matters raised which I should mention for information of your Committee. The first is that I have received representations that the exemptions contained in the Rifle Clubs (Firearms) Order are not as wide as those in the previous Regulations in that safety templates for rifle ranges are not covered. In fact, this aspect was not specifically addressed in the previous Regulations and I am not convinced that rifle club members are disadvantaged by the new Order but, to meet the difficulties expressed to me, I have been prepared to make a further Order which would enable continuing use of templates based on Defence Force standards at ranges used by rifle clubs affiliated with the National Rifle Association and the National Small Bore and Air Rifle Association. The effect would be to substitute the Defence Force standards for those which might apply under State or Territory law.
A further matter has been the proposed termination date for the Firearms Order and the Defence (General) Regulations.

As was stated in the explanatory material for this legislation, it had been intended that the termination date be 30 June 1988, based on the Commonwealth's commitment in this respect at the Premiers' Conference on gun control. In the recent discussions I have indicated my willingness to extend the transition period for perhaps several months if this overcomes perceived difficulties.
While I have been prepared to meet the expressed concerns on both the range safety and termination period issues, this has been dependent on the defeat of the disallowance motion.

Accordingly, I think I have to say also that my undertaking to include termination dates in the Defence (General) Regulations and the Rifle Clubs (Firearms) Order, like my willingness to make a range safety order, can be carried out only if the disallowance motion does not succeed. If it does succeed, I will have to undertake the review I mentioned above.

If I may turn to questions (i) and (ii) at page 2 of your letter, the National Rifle Association of Australia has advised that there are no set rules for the security of firearms. However, members of rifle clubs are advised to follow military practice in securing rifles and rifle bolts separately. No changes are envisaged for the duration of the Rifle Clubs (Firearms) Order. In fact it was not intended that there should be any changes as the purpose of the Order is merely to continue, for the interim period, the exemption from State and Territory law that existed under regulation 80 of the repealed Australian Rifle Club Regulations.

In response to question (iii) at page 2 of your letter, I am advised that paragraph 5 of the Order would not affect a State or Territory law that imposed a prohibition, as distinct from a licensing requirement. For example, the Order would not override a State law prohibiting the ownership of automatic or semi-automatic rifles.

In conclusion, may I again make it clear that I accept your Committee's points about the Defence (General) Regulations and the Rifle Clubs (Firearms) Order. The only reason I cannot give an unqualified undertaking is the uncertainty relating to the disallowance motion for Statutory Rules 1988 No. 17.
I will write to you again when the result of that motion is known, and when I have undertaken any consequent review.
Yours sincerely

Dear Minister,

At its meeting on 17 March 1988 the Committee considered the Motor Traffic (Amendment) Ordinance (No. 3) 1988 (being A.C.T. Ordinance No. 10 of 1988, tabled in the Senate on 16 March 1988). The Ordinance appears to contain an element of strict liability and the Committee invites your comments on the justifications for it.

New subsection 186a (1) provides that ``A person shall not . . . drive a motor vehicle to which a trailer or camper unit is attached while another person is in or upon the trailer or camper unit''. New subsection 186a (2) provides that ``A person shall not remain in or upon a trailer or camper unit that is attached to a motor vehicle while the motor vehicle is being driven upon a public street.''

The Committee queries the need for legal drafting which appears to create strict liability which could convict of a crime an unwitting driver or a person accidentally stranded on a trailer or camper unit without the driver's knowledge. The Committee appreciates that these are regulatory offences, that the penalty is low and that prosecution guidelines and the commonsense of law enforcers could preclude vexatious prosecutions. However, the Committee is generally opposed on principle to the creation of strict liability offences unless there are compelling reasons of real public interest and real legal necessity to justify their presence on the statute book. These conditions would seem to be satisfied in, for example, the case of the Motor Traffic (Amendment) Ordinance 1988 (A.C.T. Ordinance No. 9 of 1988), concerning the use of vehicles carrying explosives. Where strong justifications do not exist strict offences should not be created since they can lie unremarked in legislation until a currently unforeseeable administrative expediency prompts their use with unjust consequences. As the relevant case law has demonstrated a prima facie strict offence can generate considerable debate and disagreement among judges and lawyers as to whether mens rea is a presumed requirement and whether the defence of honest and reasonable mistake of fact is available.

The Committee would be pleased if you would re-examine the drafting of section 186a with a view to making it clear that some culpable element, whether knowledge or a lack of care, is necessary in order to ground criminality.
Yours sincerely,

I refer to your letter of 22 March 1988 concerning the Motor Traffic (Amendment) Ordinance (No. 3) in which you sought my comments on the inclusion of strict liability offences in new subsections 186a (1) and 186a (2) of the Motor Traffic Ordinance 1936.

The Committee has indicated its general opposition to the introduction of strict liability offences unless there are compelling reasons for the imposition of such an onus. While I agree with the Committee's views in respect of the application of strict liability offences, I would point out that the Motor Traffic Ordinance 1936 is an important piece of public safety legislation and I believe that the most rigorous standard should be applied where the activities of an individual can put the safety of others at risk. It is my view that it is appropriate that the offence created by subsection 186a (1) should be one of strict liability. The danger to persons riding in trailers or camper units is sufficiently serious to cast a strict onus on drivers to make every effort to ensure that they do not carry people in this way. The advice I have obtained from the Criminal Law Branch of the Attorney-General's Department in respect of the questions you have raised supports the view I have outlined.

TALK.START.PARA: —I seek leave to have the Government's response to the report of the Royal Commission on the Use and Effects of Chemical Agents on Australian Personnel in Vietnam, the Evatt report, incorporated in Hansard.

SPEECH.PARA: Leave granted.
The response read as follows-
MINISTERIAL STATEMENT ON THE GOVERNMENT'S RESPONSE TO THE REPORT OF THE ROYAL COMMISSION ON THE USE AND EFFECTS OF CHEMICAL AGENTS ON AUSTRALIAN PERSONNEL IN VIETNAM (THE EVATT REPORT)

On 22 August 1985 my predecessor tabled the 9-volume report of the Royal Commission on the Use and Effects of Chemical Agents on Australian Personnel in Vietnam, conducted by Mr Justice Phillip Evatt, DSC-the Evatt Commission. At that time Senator Gietzelt announced that, on the basis of the scientific, medical, statistical, and other evidence relied upon by the Commission, the Government accepted that the case for a link between Agent Orange and health problems among Vietnam veterans had not been established. The Government announced its intention to give close further consideration to other specific findings and recommendations of the Commission. In that it has been ably assisted by a report from Mr R. D. Hogg.
2. The document tabled in November 1987 by Senator McLean and purporting to be the report of Mr Hogg was not the full report. I therefore table Mr Hogg's report as submitted to the Government.

3. Madam Speaker, I now wish to announce the results of the Government's consideration of these reports. In doing so, I table a schedule outlining the Government's response to each recommendation of the Evatt Royal Commission presented in Volume 8 of the Commission's final report.

4. Perhaps the most controversial aspect of the Evatt Report was the statement ``Agent Orange Not Guilty'', with which the Royal Commission headed the chapter on Conclusions in its final report. Wide publicity was given to Mr Hogg's dissatisfaction with that statement. In support of his view, Mr Hogg pointed out that it was too early yet to speak with such absolute certainty. He went on to say however that, leaving aside that heading, there was no convincing argument, no new material presented by the Vietnam Veterans Association of Australia (VVAA) or others, to change the underlying conclusions and comments of the Commission. This, and Mr Hogg's judgment that the Commission's conclusions were, in the main, sustainable, did not receive wide publicity.

5. Much of the media and parliamentary attention given to the Evatt Royal Commission and its conclusions has centred on the criticisms made by and through the VVAA. In particular, the VVAA criticised what it saw as ``bias'' and ``plagiarism'' on the part of the Royal Commissioner, Mr Justice Evatt. The Government has considered these allegations. The Government's view is that no impropriety arises simply by reason of the fact that the Royal Commissioner adopted, by acknowledged quotation or otherwise, parts of submissions made to him. Further, the Government considers that other general allegations could not be sustained on the material provided by the VVAA. The Government confirms that it does not doubt Mr Justice Evatt's integrity, and notes that his integrity was not questioned by any party at the time of his selection as Royal Commissioner.

6. In addition to its own allegations, the VVAA submitted criticisms by some scientists dissatisfied with the Royal Commissioner's findings or with his treatment of them as witnesses. The Department of Veterans' Affairs examined the VVAA's submissions and made detailed comments on them, including comments on the complaints by Swedish scientists Drs Hardell and Axelson. In commending the thoroughness and objectivity of the Department's analyses, Mr Hogg expressed the view that the analyses should conclude the Government's responses to matters relating to the conduct of the Evatt inquiry and should be made available to the VVAA. The Government endorses this view and that material will now be made available. It also endorses the view that the Government should not proceed with any further inquiry into the Evatt Royal Commission's work, as-in Mr Hogg's words-no benefit would accrue to the health of Vietnam veterans from such an inquiry.

7. Madam Speaker, the Government has no option but to endorse the Commission's conclusions on chemicals and health as consistent with the evidence put before the Royal Commissioner. In short, the Commissioner concluded that the exposure of Australian service personnel in Vietnam to chemical agents did not produce dosage levels which would be likely to cause any long-term health effects. He also concluded that exposure of fathers to chemicals in Vietnam had not caused, and would not cause, birth defects. As a general statement, veterans and their families can be reassured by the Commissioner's report and his conclusions.

8. The evidence provided by the weight of scientific research and by the available data on cancer incidence among Australian veterans gives a solid basis for the Commission's summary conclusions on cancer. Nevertheless, reservations have been expressed about the Commission's final statement that ``service in Vietnam has not and will not cause cancer amongst veterans''. The Government does not intend to leave this potential source of concern unexamined, as I shall explain in more detail when discussing Mr Hogg's recommendations.

9. As to the Commission's recommendations, they are a mixed bag. Some ask the Government to do what it is already doing. Some raise what are, at most, very minor matters. Other recommendations nevertheless propose significant changes in the Repatriation system. The Government's response to the Commissioner's recommendations, including those which fall within the portfolio of the Minister for Defence, is contained in the material I have tabled. I propose to speak only to those recommendations which cover matters of some substance.

10. The Commissioner recommended ``that as a matter of policy claims by Vietnam veterans, their widows or dependants based on diseases of the circulatory system be allowed''. In the same terms he recommended that claims based on alcohol induced diseases or alcoholism itself be allowed. In Volume 5 of his report, though not in his summary of recommendations, he recommended that any mental health disorder should also be accepted as a matter of policy.

11. The basis for these recommendations apparently was that Vietnam service involved stress. Further, alcohol and cigarettes were available in Vietnam and an increase in smoking and drinking could be connected with Vietnam service. These are observations which may be correct. There is, however, a very considerable jump in translating these observations into a recommendation for automatic acceptance of particular conditions for Repatriation benefits. To take an extreme example, in relation to circulatory diseases, a veteran who never smoked, never drank, but spent one day in Vietnam could develop a heart condition fifty years after that day in Vietnam. If accepted, the Commissioner's proposal would mean that any claim for the heart condition would be automatically allowed under the Repatriation system.

12. Australia's Repatriation system is already among the most generous in the world, and the Government is unable to agree to the proposed automatic acceptance of pension claims for the stated health conditions. Under the Veterans' Entitlements Act, the Repatriation Commission is required to determine that an incapacity or death (claimed as related to the veteran's operational service) is war-caused unless the Commission is satisfied beyond reasonable doubt that there is no sufficient ground for making that determination. The Act provides that the Commission shall be so satisfied if it is of the opinion that the material before it does not raise a reasonable hypothesis connecting the incapacity or death with the veteran's operational service. Cases are considered on their merits, taking account of known medical and other evidence. This approach will continue to be adopted.

13. The Commissioner sought an expanded role for the Vietnam Veterans Counselling Service. The VVCS, he recommended, should become a short term statutory authority, function as a mediator between veterans and Government agencies, provide an advisory service on Repatriation entitlements, issue travel warrants to veterans, and educate the community regarding the Commissioner's findings on Agent Orange.

14. The National Advisory Committee on VVCS has pointed out that development of the service would be delayed if a separate organisation with its own administrative structure had to be established, that the VVCS should not attempt to provide services and information to veterans which could be provided better by other organisations or by officers of the Department of Veterans' Affairs, and that it was inappropriate for senior counsellors to perform the administrative function of issuing travel warrants. The Government shares these views. As to an educative role for the VVCS outside its own service and clients, the Government considers that a general community educational role could be counter-productive to good relations between the VVCS and its clients. The role of the VVCS is to provide counselling for Vietnam veterans in need. The additional roles which the Commissioner seeks would inhibit the ability of the VVCS to carry out its primary task.

15. In responding to the Commission's concern about veterans in remote areas, however, the Government has decided to increase VVCS funding to ensure a better service for country veterans and their families. This decision is consistent with the Government's concern that people living in country areas have an equitable access to Government services. The VVCS will be able to begin recruitment action designed to add six full-time positions to its staff. The aim will be for the extra staff to organise networks in country areas, employing local personnel on a part-time basis and providing up to 1,000 hours of fee for service counselling. To ensure that these additional resources are employed to the best advantage of veterans and their families, and to provide a basis for Government decisions on the level of assistance in future years, the use made of VVCS services will be closely monitored. I should make it clear, Madam Speaker, that this announcement does not pre-empt the work presently being carried out by the House Standing Committee on Community Affairs. The Committee will be reporting on matters of detail which will assist in determining the future scope and extent of work by the counselling service. I expect to be considering the Committee's report later this year.

16. In the body of his report the Commissioner referred to the provision of half-way homes or hostels for veterans. The Government has already provided support to assist in setting up an emergency accommodation centre for veterans in Queensland. Where the need for short-term emergency accommodation is demonstrated and the Government is satisfied that an applicant group has the necessary management expertise and community support, the Government is prepared to contribute, in the form of a seeding grant, towards establishing further community-based facilities. It is proposed to earmark up to $400,000 for this purpose over the next two years. Submissions developed by the ex-services community will be considered on their merits.

17. The Commission recommended that the Government erect a Vietnam veterans monument. The Australian War Memorial has been established as the national monument to the veterans of all the wars in which Australia has been engaged. An important aspect of this monument is the commemoration of veterans fallen in all wars, including the Vietnam conflict, by inscription of their names on the cloistral walls of the Memorial.

18. Some veterans' associations have seen fit to erect their own monuments in the national capital. A Committee representing a broad spectrum of Vietnam ex-service groups has sought approval to erect a memorial in Canberra. In processing the application the Canberra National Memorials Committee will consider the range of sites which might be suitable. The next step would then be for the ex-service Committee to make a detailed submission, including design and costing, for a specific form of memorial. Subject to the result of the National Memorials Committee's examination of any such proposal, the Government would be prepared to offer some financial assistance to the ex-service Committee.

19. Mr Hogg made a number of recommendations in his report. Some of these, including matters already alluded to in the Evatt recommendations, are covered elsewhere in this statement or in the schedule to it. The most significant Hogg report recommendations I have not so far referred to are a series of proposals for further scientific studies. I do not propose to comment on two of Mr Hogg's proposals (for studies of agricultural workers and of women exposed to phenoxy herbicides) because of their lack of relevance to the specific issue of veterans' exposure to chemicals in Vietnam. Other studies he suggested were a regular update of the earlier Australian mortality study, reactivation of the morbidity study referred to in the Evatt Royal Commission and investigation of possible health effects arising from the use of dapsone.

20. It should be noted that Mr Hogg himself said: ``. . . it is conclusive that there is no marked difference in the level and nature of illnesses between Vietnam veterans and army personnel who did not serve''. As to mortality, the additional number of deaths available for analysis since the previous study would probably be too few at present to confirm or refute the findings of that study. As to morbidity, the Government had concluded earlier that such a study could not answer questions as to chemical causation (a conclusion which the US Government also appears to have reached after expenditure of many millions of dollars). The Australian pilot study has given cause for concern about the likelihood of reaching the necessary high contact and response rates and had indicated that, with veterans more motivated to participate than non-veterans, the difference in response rates could be marked and introduce distortions to a study.

21. Clearly, in addition to overall mortality, Mr Hogg saw the incidence of cancer as a continuing issue of concern. The Department of Veterans' Affairs (DVA) has already established a Vietnam veterans data base which contains, inter alia, details of causes of deaths. The Government is of the view that a more cost-effective approach to monitoring mortality or cancer incidence is to use the DVA's records, supplemented by information from State death and cancer registries. The Department will use its own staff to maintain update and improve the data base and extract material for analysis as required. The Department will also continue to monitor relevant overseas research.

22. Mr Hogg's final research proposal was that the Government immediately establish an epidemiological study into the possible health effects of the anti-malarial drug dapsone. The Government agrees with Mr Hogg-and with Mr Justice Evatt-that research into the cancer-causing potential of dapsone is desirable. It does not, however, support a wider investigation into all possible effects of the drug, given that dapsone's use for various medical purposes has resulted in an extensive knowledge of reactions it can cause. The National Health and Medical Research Council will be asked to advise on the feasibility of a study into whether dapsone is carcinogenic in man.

23. Madam Speaker, we have come a long way since fears about Agent Orange first emerged among Australian Veterans. Milestones along that road in Australia have included the Senate Standing Committee on Science and the Environment report in 1982, the Government-sponsored birth defects and mortality studies, and in America the Ranch Hand and Centres for Disease Control studies. Soon after this Government came into office, it set up a wide-ranging Royal Commission which brought many leading international scientists here and visited others overseas in its search for the facts. Since becoming Minister I have ensured that the Royal Commission report, subsequent VVAA submissions and the Hogg report received thorough examination before Cabinet considered the whole issue. The Government believes that too many Vietnam veterans' lives have been disrupted by fears about Agent Orange and other chemicals. In endorsing the view that any exposure of Australians to chemical agents in Vietnam would be unlikely to cause long-term adverse health effects, the Government in no way steps aside from its commitment to help veterans. Its latest decisions reinforce the measures in place to provide continuing assistance to veterans and their families.

TALK.START.PARA: —I thank Senator Sanders for giving me some advance notice of the question, but not the changing of it. I have read the article in the Rockhampton Morning Bulletin that he refers to. In that article, Mr Wright has included as a Press release, if we could call it that, possible developments at Shoalwater Bay. Mr Wright did receive a briefing on this issue last month from the Minister for Defence. The matter of access to Shoalwater Bay training area as a new coal export port has been under examination and discussion for some time. A number of port sites in and around Shoalwater Bay training area have been identified. Defence provided access to Queensland authorities to conduct a technical reconnaissance survey of possible options late last year. No firm proposal from Queensland has yet been received. Until a firm proposal is received, the total impact on Shoalwater Bay training area cannot be established. Any development of a port in Shoalwater Bay training area would need to be consistent with the defence needs and requirements to preserve the integrity of this vital joint service training area.

ANSWER.PARA: Finally, as indicated in the Press report, the proposal would also need to address all the environmental and heritage issues. Shoalwater Bay training area is on the Register of the National Estate. The implications for the Great Barrier Reef Marine Park Authority would also be a major consideration.

TALK.START.PARA: —Has the Minister for Consumer Affairs seen allegations that a company in Melbourne is advertising the availability of irradiation of food? Can the Minister say whether these reports are accurate and whether the Government needs to take any action in response to these allegations?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Bolkus Sen The Hon N.

TALK.START.PARA: —As Senator Childs indicates, it has been brought to my attention that there are some allegations that a company in Melbourne has advertised the availability of gas or gamma sterilisation of freeze dried chicken meat dice. I also understand that this particular company, called Cotter Food Services Pty Ltd, has given evidence to the House of Representatives Standing Committee on the Environment, Recreation and the Arts. There may be questions arising out of that evidence. To the Government it seems that there is prima facie evidence of a situation which needs further inquiry and explanation.

ANSWER.PARA: As honourable senators will know, the whole question of food irradiation is a complex and intricate one. It is still under consideration by government. In fact, the House of Representatives recently established an inquiry through its Standing Committee on Environment, Recreation and the Arts to consider further the question. Both the Federal and State governments have agreed that no further decision will be taken in this area pending the final report of that Committee.

In the meantime, the National Foods Standards Council and the Uniform Food Law Interpretation Committee met earlier this year. These bodies have been instrumental in ensuring that there has been an agreement between State and Federal governments to ensure that the process of irradiation is neither facilitated nor allowed pending the conclusion of the report and also to allow individual States to implement standards prohibiting food irradiation if an individual State so decides. I note that South Australia is one State that is conditionally going down that track. Further to this report being brought to my notice, I did raise the matter with the Victorian Government which is not implementing legislation, but which also wants to ensure that the agreement between State and Federal governments is being adhered to. I am assured that the Victorian Health Department is currently investigating the situation.

In conclusion, the Government's objectives in this matter are twofold: firstly, to ensure that the agreement between State and Federal governments is kept and, secondly, to ensure that there is no pre-emption of the agreed policy formulation process between State and Federal governments.

TALK.START.PARA: —I refer the Minister for Transport and Communications to my question to him last week about the danger of a mid-air collision over Coolangatta Airport because of the lack of radar facilities and the Minister's admission that that very busy airport has no radar coverage below 4,000 feet, but that coverage would be extended by the early 1990s. As the Minister and honourable senators would be aware, last Friday afternoon there was a terrible accident over Coolangatta Airport when two aircraft collided and four people were killed. Is it a fact that provision of suitable radar would cost less than $6m which, in terms of government priorities, is about the same as has been spent on the futile creation of the Constitutional Commission? In view of Friday's horrifying crash, which could have cost more lives had the wreckage fallen on the heavily populated areas surrounding Coolangatta Airport, will the Minister now reconsider the timetable he announced last week and make upgrading of radar and instrument landing facilities a matter of the utmost urgency? Finally, in light of the Minister's claim last week that lack of radar cover was not relevant to the incident I mentioned-I find this hard to believe with two big jets approaching the same runway from different ends-will the Minister arrange for the release of the transcript of conversations between air traffic control and the pilots of the two jetliners concerned and with the pilot of another commercial aircraft on the ground at the same time?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Evans Sen The Hon G.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —As to the last part of the question, I shall have to see what the normal practice is in relation to that and give Senator Sheil an answer on notice accordingly. As to the main thrust of his question, it is the case that a tragic accident did occur at Coolangatta at approximately 4.10 p.m., three days ago, on 20 May, involving a mid-air collision between two locally-based light aircraft. The aircraft were carrying out circuit and landing training at the airport. Both were operating on right-hand circuits to land and take off on runway 14. While on the downwind leg of the circuit the aircraft collided and fell to the ground out of control. The two people in each aircraft were killed. The details of this accident are currently the subject of investigation by the Bureau of Air Safety Investigation.

ANSWER.PARA: Senator Sheil would appreciate that it is simply inappropriate for me to comment on this accident specifically until the Bureau has completed its investigation and reported. However, I can say something about the larger theme of Senator Sheil's question, which is the implications of the presence or absence of radar for circuit and landing training of this kind. The present situation at Coolangatta with regard to radar, as I told him in this place the other day, is that coverage is provided down to approximately 4,000 feet above the aerodrome from Brisbane radar sensors. From this height aircraft are then processed into the Coolangatta terminal area.

The radar enhancement program, as I have also said, is currently in train and it will provide radar coverage at Coolangatta down to ground level, with expected commissioning in the early 1990s. However, when the radar is installed at Coolangatta, separation of aircraft operating on circuit and landing training will continue to be provided visually by the air traffic controller situated in the Coolangatta control tower. Control instructions to these aircraft operations are currently based on visual observation and this will continue to be the case, as it is at all other airports in Australia where circuit training is performed. Radar separation requires a minimum spacing between aircraft of three nautical miles or approximately six kilometres. This would severely restrict aircraft operating locally-as the expression goes-at airports where the minimum spacing required is only 600 metres.

Visual separation is considered to be the safest and most efficient means of controlling aircraft that are conducting circuits and landings in the aerodrome traffic area. That is not to say that things cannot go wrong on occasions but it remains to be established by the proper investigative process what happened and who, if anyone, was at fault.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr President, I ask a supplementary question in view of the answer given by the Minister about the timetable. I point out that Coolangatta Airport is an important tourist destination. If tourists think they will be flying into an unsafe area, that will have a very deleterious effect on the tourist industry at the southern end of Queensland.

—I did not understand that to be a question so much as a rather tendentious statement. It is not helpful to comment in those terms in circumstances where I do not believe the practice elsewhere in this country and around the world justifies so negative a conclusion being drawn.

—My question to the Minister for Transport and Communications is also on the question of air safety. Has the Minister seen the article in the Adelaide Advertiser on 19 May reviewing the recent Boeing 737 incident in Hawaii and discussing the worrying question of aircraft fatigue? Is it the case that these old series Boeing 737s, which are not used in Australia, were constructed using a now abandoned manufacturing process? Can the Minister say whether the same process was used in the manufacture of Australia's ageing fleets of B727 aircraft? How often are Australian domestic airliners inspected for metal fatigue?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Evans Sen The Hon G.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —The investigation of the Aloha B737 aircraft accident is being closely monitored by my Department, as I indicated in an answer to an earlier question on this subject. The now abandoned manufacturing process to which Senator Maguire referred is called cold bonding and was used on some joints in early aircraft. However, I am advised it was used in addition to rivets, which are designed to carry full loads. There are no B737-200 aircraft in Australia and later aircraft, including all Australian B727-200 aircraft, used only rivets with no bonding of those joints.

ANSWER.PARA: Components of all aircraft used in airline operations in Australia are inspected frequently for fatigue cracking, at different intervals ranging from daily to annually. The problem of fatigue cracking in older airline aircraft is the subject of constant examination by world airworthiness authorities. In addition to routine maintenance schedules and procedures, aviation authorities advise operators of special inspections in mandatory airworthiness directives, and there are supplemental structural inspections enforced for all types resulting from structural audits designed to ensure the long term integrity of older aircraft.

The United States Federal Aviation Administration is holding a meeting from 1 to 3 June of world airworthiness authorities and airlines to cover all safety aspects of old transport aircraft. Qantas Airways Ltd, Australian Airlines and Ansett Airlines of Australia are expected to send specialist engineers to this meeting and the Department of Transport and Communications will also be represented.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Minister for the Arts, Sport, the Environment, Tourism and Territories. In about July last year, did the Minister have discussions with representatives of the Design Board of the Australia Council and give it an assurance that no further actions would be taken by the Government in respect of the position of the Designs Board without further consultations? Is he aware that Senator Button has also had discussions with representatives of the Design Board and expressed his support for the continuing work of that organisation? Given these facts, can the Minister now explain why the Minister for the Arts and Territories has directed that the Design Board should be wound up and has taken steps to revoke the instrument appointing the Design Board as part of the Australia Council and replace it with two separate boards, one to be chaired by Professor Horne, and the other by Mr Andrews, which will have the net effect of reducing substantially the effective input of designs advice to the Australia Council?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Richardson Sen The Hon G.F.
ANSWER.MINISTERIAL: ARTS, SPORT, THE ENVIRONMENT, TOURISM AND TERRITORIES

TALK.START.PARA: —Yes, I can recall having some discussions with Mr Andrews, in particular, who was the Chairman of the Board. I am not sure whether those discussions were in July last year. However, I met with him on a couple of occasions. I can also recall discussing this matter several times with Senator Button. Our concern was-and it was certainly indicated to Mr Andrews-that the Government should maintain a design function for a board or committee of some sort. We were certainly of the view that this was an important function that should not be done away with. However, there was the matter of deciding where such a function ought best to lie and how it might best be conducted, the argument being, given that one of the roles of the old Design Board in the previous year had been to select the winner of a competition to redesign Parramatta Road, whether this was an appropriate matter to be handled under an Australia Council umbrella. Discussions about that lasted for some time. I am not sure whether the Minister for the Arts and Territories, Mr Punch, has made a decision yet, but the last time I spoke to Mr Horne of the Australia Council, certainly, I was led to believe that agreement with Mr Andrews and members of the Design Board was close as regards having it formed into a design committee. I have not precisely followed up whether that has been announced, or whether Mr Punch has approved it; but the last time I checked, that was where it was heading.

QUESTION.BLOCK.TITLE: SOVIET UNION: ACCESS TO AUSTRALIAN PORTS

TALK.START.PARA: —Has the Minister representing the Minister for Primary Industries and Energy seen a Press report in today's Australian Financial Review indicating that the Soviet Union has a real chance of getting fishing access to Australian ports following indications of a new bilateral fishing deal between the United States of America and the Union of Soviet Socialist Republics (USSR) at the coming summit meeting between Mr Reagan and Mr Gorbachev? Can the Minister give the Senate any details on the state of negotiations between Australia and the USSR regarding any such fishing deal between our countries? Can the Minister also give any details about such a deal as it relates to, firstly, access by Soviet fishing vessels to Australian ports; secondly, what would be the benefits, if any, to Australia by entering into such a deal; thirdly, landing rights for Aeroflot Soviet Airlines to assist in crew changes; and, fourthly, which Australian ports could be used for ship repair, maintenance and crew changes?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Cook Sen The Hon P.F.S.

TALK.START.PARA: —I did see a report in the Australian Financial Review today, I think under the by-line of Geoff Kitney, its chief political reporter, about Soviet access to the Australian fishing zone. I cannot answer all of the questions that Senator Schacht has raised, but I can make a fair bash at some of them.
—Did you see them beforehand?

—No, I did not. We actually do get questions without notice on the front bench, but the honourable senator will never get to the front bench so he will never find out. A Soviet Union delegation visited Canberra on 18 to 20 April last.
—You are a big deal, aren't you? Big hero.

—I cannot hear the honourable senator's interjection. She is wasting her time and breath. The delegation visited for what were termed exploratory, scientific and technical discussions on the Australian fishing zone fisheries. During that visit brief meetings were held with industry representatives and visits were undertaken to Geelong and Portland in Victoria to view industry developments and related infrastructure for fishing.

ANSWER.PARA: I am advised that the Union of Soviet Socialist Republics side in these talks has raised a number of specific proposals which will need to be considered by the Australian Government and discussed with appropriate industry organisations before they are finally considered. At this point no response has been given to the USSR other than to promise to consider the issues it has raised. In considering the proposals the Government will take into account the nature and level of benefits derived from the proposals, the interests of the Australian fishing and fish processing industries, and our relations with the Pacific island states.

In respect of all those four subquestions asked by Senator Schacht-about access to ports; the benefits that might apply, for example, whether Aeroflot might get landing rights on crew interchange; and which ports might be used in ship maintenance and repair-I will have to take them on notice. I understand, though, that there is some unused capacity in the Australian fish processing industry, and that is one of the things being discussed at these talks that are being held. But all of those other four subquestions I will take on notice and get back to the honourable senator on them as soon as possible.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Minister representing the Minister for Administrative Services. In response to a question from Senator Michael Baume in Senate Estimates committee hearings, did Senator Ray indicate that he was not aware of the extent to which properties the Government owns were vacant or underutilised, that it would be a `herculean' task to find out and that, `We may have to make a judgment as to the amount of resources we would need to devote to answering that question'? What measures does the Minister for Administrative Services intend to take to ensure that such basic information, which would be readily available to any private sector property manager, is provided in view of the extent of the waste resulting from rent forgone on empty properties, or cash proceeds not received from the disposal of such properties?

—I can confirm to Senator Patterson that I did make that statement at the Estimates committee. There has been publicity subsequent to that time, and we have made some efforts to track down exactly what the situation of dead rent in government buildings was. At the time of the Estimates committee hearing the rough estimate, if you like, given of government property involved in dead rent was 1.3 per cent, which related very favourably with any commercial rates. Subsequent to that we had some of the most ridiculous statements in the world made by Mr Porter, saying that dead rent was up to $50m a year, a figure Senator Michael Baume would not agree with. He has done research in that particular area. He has made accusations, but he has never gone to the point of making such a wild claim as $50m a year. At the time Mr West published the relevant figures.
—On leased property.

—On leased property, of course, and the amount of dead rent was adjusted, I think, between 1.3 to 1.6 per cent per year. I think the upper figure was $6.4m at worst, nothing like the $50m claimed by Mr Porter from South Australia. I do not think he is the shadow spokesman-but the actual figure was in the vicinity of $43m lower. However, the trend line for dead rent is definitely on the way down. The evidence given at the Estimates Committee hearing confirms that it is on the way down from a figure of over 3 per cent. In the time that Mr West has had that portfolio I think he has done very well in reducing the amount of dead rent burdened on any government, better than any other Minister in the last 15 years.

—Mr President, I ask a supplementary question. Will the Minister advise whether that includes leased land as well as owned land and whether there is any answer as to teasing out the difference between leased property versus owned property?

—There is no doubt that with enough work we can supply those figures. No doubt we will get asked for them at the next Estimates committee hearing. In anticipation of that I will have the figures prepared.

—My question is to the Minister for Finance. It deals with the Darwin-Alice Springs railway. Is it the Government's intention to match the Opposition's commitment to provide financial assistance to the Northern Territory Government to construct the Darwin-Alice Springs railway, as contained in the Liberal Party's transport policy of the shadow transport Minister, Julian Beale?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Walsh Sen The Hon P.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —I have seen the summary of what is laughingly-humorously-called the `transport policy', put out by one Julian Beale. The summary says that a Liberal-National government will--
—Was he one of the young Liberals?
—Oh no, he is much too old for a Young Liberal. The summary says:

ANSWER.PARA: To this end a Liberal-National government will . . . strongly support the efforts of the Northern Territory Government to facilitate completion of the Darwin-Alice Springs railway by a maximum private sector involvement.

Either that is a completely meaningless statement, other than one of standing on the sidelines saying, `That will be a nice thing if you can do it', or it is a commitment to funding from the Commonwealth Budget to support this uneconomic project. I would like to know when Senator Stone is doing his additions a bit later whether he has that on his list, not of spending cuts, but of spending increases. I would like to know whether Senator Stone is going to add an amount to the $500m or $600m that his National Party colleagues have already committed a coalition government to in spending increases. They are always talking about spending cuts in the abstract, but when it comes down to specifics they are always committing themselves to spending increases. I will be interested to see whether Mr Beale's commitment on this is on Senator Stone's list of spending increases when he finally gets around to publishing one.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr President, I take a point of order. Not only has the Minister got it wrong, but also he is undoubtedly debating the issue. I ask you to make him answer the question and not debate the Opposition's policy in relation to any other matter.
—The Minister was dealing with a legitimate area of his portfolio, but he was taking a long time to answer the question. I ask him to answer the question as quickly as possible.

—Senator Lewis says that I have got it wrong. I will be interested to hear Senator Lewis's personal explanation at the end of Question Time detailing how I have got it wrong. If Mr Beale's commitment means anything at all, it means money off the Commonwealth Budget. If it does not mean money off the Commonwealth Budget, it is a pea and thimble trick. I will be interested to hear Senator Lewis's explanation as to why it is not, or how I have got it wrong. I will also be interested to see not only whether it is on Senator Stone's increased spending list, but also how much he has got figured in for it, whether it is $100m, $200m or $500m.

ANSWER.PARA: I was asked whether the Government is going to match the Opposition's commitment. The Government made its decision about this proposal about four years ago, or it may have been a little more than four years ago. There has been no evidence that is worth anything-I add that qualification because I am aware of some shonky so-called economic analysis that was done a couple of years ago-to suggest that the Government should change its mind. This latest undertaking from Mr Beale should be seen as either a pea and thimble trick or the latest instalment in fiscal ratbaggery from the Opposition.

—Mr President, I ask a supplementary question. Will the Minister look further at this matter? Should the assessor be found to have been a witting party to a conspiracy against Mr Punch, will he ensure that the current advertisements are withdrawn?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Richardson Sen The Hon G.F.
ANSWER.MINISTERIAL: ARTS, SPORT, THE ENVIRONMENT, TOURISM AND TERRITORIES

If he is considering the views of people who might wish to operate the mine I think he is acting properly. He has wide powers under the ordinance and he has done nothing to go outside them. —Is the Minister representing the Minister for Primary Industries and Energy aware of the proposal by two Western Australian veterinarians to establish commercial fox fur production in Western Australia? What involvement has the Western Australian Department of Agriculture in this project? What involvement has the Federal Department of Primary Industries and Energy in this project? Is the Minister aware of plans to import fox semen? Is the Minister aware of reactions to the proposal from Western Australian farmers, in particular poultry farmers, in the light of the serious fox problems and the danger of escapes and subsequent potential improvement of wild fox stock? Will the Minister agree that foxes prefer to keep their fur coats on themselves and that divesting them of their coats is an unacceptable cruelty?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Cook Sen The Hon P.F.S.

TALK.START.PARA: —I do not know that I could agree that foxes prefer to keep their fur coats on themselves because I have never asked a fox. I assume that foxes prefer to keep their coats on themselves. But I must say that I find this beguiling sentimentality from Senator Jenkins a little odd in that--
—It is a worry for Western Australian poultry farmers.

—This is Senator Jenkins's third or fourth question about poultry farmers. Her question does not contemplate the hard reality that farmers kill foxes because they regard foxes as vermin. Foxes may prefer to keep their lives, let alone their coats; but farmers actively kill foxes because foxes are regarded as vermin. Foxes raid poultry coops and effect other damage to organised agricultural production in Australia. If this question is a question of concern about the well-being of foxes-I refer to that part of the question concerning their fur coats, et cetera-I assume that foxes prefer to keep their fur coats; but, if the honourable senator is concerned about foxes keeping their fur coats, why is she not concerned also about farmers killing foxes? It seems to me that that is internally inconsistent with the question that she has asked.

ANSWER.PARA: I come back to the four questions that Senator Jenkins has asked. I am aware of those proposals; but I am advised that the Agricultural Protection Board of Western Australia has had the proposal from the veterinarians, that Senator Jenkins referred to, withdrawn. Therefore, it does not stand before the Agricultural Protection Board as a positive proposal. On that basis I can answer all of her other questions, but it would seem to me that the answers are academic.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Minister representing the Treasurer. Has the Minister's attention been drawn to an article in today's Australian Financial Review headlined `High freight rates force coal-miners off-shore'? Does the Minister agree with the senior coal company executive quoted in that article that Australia is losing potential export revenue as a result of high hidden taxes levied by the Queensland Government? What is the effect of this on Australia's balance of payments position?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Walsh Sen The Hon P.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —I have seen the article. Indeed, I referred to it briefly in answering an earlier question. I will refer to it at greater length in answering this question. The article is written by Peter Gill and is published in today's Australian Financial Review. It begins by stating:

ANSWER.PARA: Australia is losing valuable new coal-mine developments to other countries because of high taxes and charges, particularly in Queensland.
It refers to the General Manager of Allied Queensland Coalfields Ltd and states:
He cites two examples from his own company's experience to demonstrate the impact of high Queensland rail freight rates and other unreasonable capital cost demands.
A central Queensland coal deposit, Baralaba, paid rail freight charges of $15.61 a tonne in trial shipments, giving the Queensland Government a profit of about $10 a tonne.

I certainly agree with what Mr Salway said. Indeed, I and a number of other people on the Government side have been saying similar things for a number of years. Queensland parades itself as a low tax, free enterprise State when in fact it rips off hidden taxes through excessive rail charges. This is a fact of which I am sure Senator Parer was well aware when he was working for the Utah company. Indeed, there is probably nobody in the Senate who is better aware of the great rip-off practised by the Queensland Government than Senator Parer. These taxes are disguised as rail freight, and the Queensland Government, according to the industry in which Senator Parer once worked, rips off $350m a year in hidden taxes from coalmining companies.

While I am not able to pass judgment on the specific projects to which Mr Salway referred, I think that, as a matter of commonsense or on a basic understanding of arithmetic, there must be a point at which a company decides that this Queensland State Government rip-off is so huge that it will not develop a mine in Queensland; it will go to some other country around the globe and develop a mine there instead.
It follows axiomatically that, to the extent that that is happening, it is adversely affecting Australia's export potential and our current account deficit.

TALK.START.PARA: —High taxes?

—Finally, I once again suggest to Senator Stone, and Senator Sheil, that instead of making completely unhelpful and usually frivolous and foolish suggestions about how the Australian Labor Party should be organising its affairs-a party in which they have absolutely no influence-they use whatever influence they might have on the Queensland National Party to see whether they can persuade it to behave a bit more sensibly both in the interest of Queensland and in the national interest, and to change the great rip-off policy which it has been pursuing for at least a decade, of which, as I said before, Senator Parer is very well aware.

—Will the Minister representing the Prime Minister make available as soon as possible the names of the 500 or so people on the personal list invited by the Prime Minister to attend the opening of the new Parliament House and indicate in which hall they were seated? Will he also make available the list of those distinguished former parliamentarians who were unable to be accommodated in the main hall and who were obliged to listen to the ceremony by loudspeaker?
