—My question is directed to the Leader of the Government in the Senate. When he was responsible for the Industries Assistance Commission was it the procedure that he and his Department, where appropriate, in consultation with other Ministers and their departments, agreed on the terms of reference for an IAC inquiry and announced the inquiry and the terms of reference at the same time? I refer to the Treasurer's announcement on Australia Day-that is, 118 days ago-that there would be an inquiry into non-tax government charges on industry. Is it a fact that those terms of reference have not yet been agreed and have not been delivered to the Industries Assistance Commission? Is the reason that they have not been delivered to the IAC that the terms of reference have not been agreed upon by the Minister and the relevant departments?

—The answer to the first question is yes. The answer to the second question is I believe yes; and the answer to the third question is that I do not know. There may be a number of relevant departments. I am not sure in respect of that issue.
—Mr President, I ask a supplementary question. Will the Minister find out?
—Yes.

—Has the Minister for Finance seen an article by Dr Daryl Dixon in today's Australian in which he costs unemployment at $6 billion? What has the Government done to minimise this figure? What is the Minister's response to the suggestion that private enterprise should have a greater input into training and retraining?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Walsh Sen The Hon P.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —I have seen an article. From reading the article it is not clear to me the extent to which Daryl Dixon is being quoted as against the extent to which he is being interpreted by Jan Carter from the Brotherhood of St Laurence. Having said that, it is reported that unemployment benefits consume 1.3 per cent of gross domestic product. That figure is very close to $4 billion, which is considerably higher than the likely outcome this year. The $6 billion figure is presumably derived by adding to the unemployment benefit payments the tax revenue notionally forgone because of the people receiving unemployment benefits not being employed. On that basis, the figure of $6 billion in revenue forgone and outlays and unemployment benefits paid is about right, I think, if it is assumed that unemployment could be reduced to zero. That is an unrealistic assumption. Even through the long boom during the 1950s and 1960s, unemployment was never zero. So the figure is overstated to some extent. The report does not make it entirely clear what are Dr Dixon's firm recommendations and what are somebody else's interpretations of them. But it is said that the study recommends research into reducing unemployment levels through job sharing and part time incomes. While job sharing might reduce the amount of unemployment benefits paid, if an existing job is shared between two people it would produce less tax revenue because of the progressive income tax system. It would not add to the gross domestic product. So I would like to have a much more comprehensive look at what Daryl Dixon prepared before passing final judgment on a number of those things.

ANSWER.PARA: The Government is doing something about training, which was one of the options canvassed. But it should be borne in mind, lest people think that the whole problem can be solved by training, that unless the investment which provides additional positions in the work force has already taken place, the number of potential jobs will not be increased, regardless of how much training is indulged in. It is possible, of course, that there are some potential positions in the work force presently unfilled because there are no trained applicants to fill them. Leaving that aside, the problem of unemployment cannot be solved by increased expenditure or effort on training alone. They must be accompanied by a level of investment commensurate with increasing the total number of places available in the work force.

Senator Burns also asked me what the Government has done about this matter. It has done a great deal. When we came into office, the unemployment rate, if I remember correctly, was 10.4 per cent. TALK.START.PARA: —The Australian Democrats view the statement of the Minister for Veterans' Affairs (Mr Humphreys) of last Thursday, which now comes to the Senate as a paper, as a statement of enormous consequence. SPEECH.SPEAKER: Coulter Sen J.R.

TALK.START.PARA: —I note both in the report of the Evatt Royal Commission on the Use and Effects of Chemical Agents on Australian Personnel in Vietnam and in the statement of the Minister for Veterans' Affairs (Mr Humphreys) the words `Agent Orange' and `not guilty'. One only needs to see those words to realise that both the Commission and the Minister have totally failed to understand properly the nature of the evidence that was before them. The chemicals that were used in Vietnam, principally 2,4,5-T and the principal contaminant in 2,4,5-T, the so-called 2,3,7,8-tetrachloro dibenzodioxane-are under consideration with respect to delayed effects and not acute toxic effects; that is, those effects which may turn up many years after the initial exposure.

SPEECH.PARA: It is one thing to identify an agent as toxic if within a few minutes of exposure to that agent, one simply falls down dead or becomes acutely ill. If one takes a dose of cyanide and dies within 30 minutes, there is very little doubt about the relationship between the cyanide and the effect. Moreover, the symptoms are classic and easily identified. If, on the other hand, one is exposed to an agent and it is 25 or 30 years on before a genetic effect shows up, it is extremely difficult to prove that there is a link between that exposure and that effect. Equally, it is very difficult to prove that there is no effect; in fact it is impossible to do so.

In relation to cancer, one is looking at an effect which has, in the technical jargon, a very large background noise. One is attempting to find an increase in cancer which exceeds statistically significantly the level of that background noise. In Australia some 20 per cent of the population will at some stage develop cancer-a very high incidence. Therefore, if we are looking at Vietnam veterans to discover whether there has been a statistically significant increase in the incidence of cancer, we require quite a large increase before we can statistically prove-I emphasise the words `statistically prove'-that that increase has been real. If there has been an increase, and the increase can be quite large, which is not statistically significant, that does not prove that the agent is not guilty, to use Evatt's term; it simply proves that an increase, if it occurs, was less than that required to establish statistical significance. As I have indicated, that increase can be quite large.

Even the best conducted animal experiments under carefully controlled scientific conditions-and Vietnam was certainly not a scientific experiment under carefully controlled conditions-have difficulty in proving an increase in cancer between 10 and 100 per cent. So all we have in relation to Vietnam veterans and the incidence of cancer is that if there is an increase, it is probably less than at least a very substantial percentage increase-perhaps lying somewhere in that range between a 10 per cent and a 100 per cent increase. Of course, exactly the same goes for birth defects. Those who were exposed to genetically toxic agents at high levels may escape entirely; those who were exposed to low levels may suffer an effect. One is simply looking at a statistical probability, and in that situation it is very difficult to establish proof and impossible to establish safety.

The Royal Commission misunderstood the scientific evidence, and that misunderstanding has been repeated in the Minister's statement. It is a great pity that neither the Commission nor the Minister has got it right.

Much of the Bill is devoted to improving the requirements of the taxation law that deal with the registration of tax agents. A substantial number of other matters are also dealt with. The income tax law will be amended as foreshadowed to restrict eligibility for the special depreciation allowances available for Australian trading ships. SPEECH.PARA: Registration of Tax Agents

In the interests of both the revenue and the taxpayer, it is important that a person who charges a fee for conducting income tax business on behalf of a taxpayer has the appropriate knowledge of Australian income tax law and of accounting principles and is otherwise a fit and proper person to be entrusted with the responsibility of conducting a person's income tax business. The income tax law therefore prohibits a person, partnership or company from charging a fee for preparing an income tax return, or transacting any business relating to income tax matters unless registered as a tax agent, or exempted from registration, by a tax agents' board.

The provisions that deal with the registration of tax agents have remained relatively unchanged since they were first enacted in 1943. The amendments being made by this Bill will substantially modernise and improve the provisions and give effect to a number of recommendations made by the Administrative Appeals Tribunal, the Administrative Review Council, accounting firms and the boards themselves. Interested parties were consulted as part of the drafting process and have indicated general support for the proposed measures.

In response to criticisms of the existing provisions by the Administrative Review Council and the Administrative Appeals Tribunal, the Bill will extend the range of decisions of a tax agents' board in respect of which a person may make application to the tribunal for review. In order to achieve a desirable degree of uniformity between decisions of the six State boards and the Administrative Appeals Tribunal, the Bill will provide a more objective test as to who is a suitable person to be registered as a tax agent or as a nominee, and will enable eligibility criteria to be prescribed. Also in response to a recommendation of the Tribunal, the Bill will give the boards a general power to suspend the registration of a tax agent in addition to the power of cancellation.

Under the existing law, company tax agents may register suitably qualified employees as nominees. Partnership tax agents, however, may only register partners as nominees while sole practitioners may not register nominees at all. Partnership and sole practitioner tax agents have expressed concern that the inability to register employees as nominees increases the workload of the principals and can impede the timely lodgment of returns. To overcome these concerns partnership and individual tax agents are to be permitted to register suitably qualified employees as nominees.

The ability of a company to gain registration as a tax agent on the basis of the qualifications of an employee-who need not be a director, shareholder or even a full time employee of the company-has led to exploitation by some unqualified persons. The Bill will therefore tighten the rules for registration as a company tax agent by requiring that shares carrying at least 25 per cent of the voting power in a company applying for registration be beneficially owned by a director or directors having the necessary qualifications to be registered as a tax agent. The $2 fee payable on lodgment of an application for registration as a tax agent or as a nominee of a registered tax agent has not changed since 1943 and is considerably less than those payable for broadly comparable professional registrations. The Bill will increase the fee to $80.

The existing law requires tax agents to notify the board by 1 April each year if they wish to remain registered. The Bill replaces the annual notification requirement with a requirement to re-register each three years and introduce a re-registration fee of $40 plus $5 per nominee. The fees have been set at a level that will recover the costs of operating the tax agents' boards and will be subject to regular review. Other amendments will provide for continuation of a partnership registration following a change in constitution of the partnership, effect changes in the composition of the tax agents' boards and make a number of minor technical and drafting amendments of the tax agents' provisions.
Special Depreciation for Australian Trading Ships

As announced on 2 April 1987, the Government has decided to restrict eligibility for the special accelerated depreciation concession for Australian trained ships to new ships that qualify under the Federal Government's scheme of capital grants for such ships. Under the Ships (Capital Grants) Act 1987 the Federal Government pays a taxable grant of 7 per cent of the purchase price of eligible Australian trading ships as an incentive to ship operators to purchase modern, efficient and technologically advanced ships. The Bill will restrict eligibility for special depreciation, from 22 December 1986-the date from which the capital grants scheme applies-to new ships that both satisfy the present eligibility criteria in the income tax law and qualify for a capital grant. Ships which do not qualify for a grant but which, on 22 December 1986, had either been given a manning notice under section 57am of the Income Tax Assessment Act or were the subject of an application for such a notice, will continue to be eligible for special depreciation. The amendments will also disallow the special depreciation if a grant becomes repayable.
Cash Bids

As announced on 17 September 1986, the Bill will extend the scope of the income tax deductions allowable for cash bids paid for the grant of offshore petroleum exploration permits. The income tax law was amended in 1987 to allow deductions for cash bids paid to the Commonwealth, under its cash bidding system introduced in 1985, for the grant of petroleum exploration permits in highly prospective areas. This ensured that Australian companies would not be disadvantaged in the bidding process in competing with foreign companies that could obtain deductions under their domestic law for their cash bids. When the amendments were introduced, the Government announced that it also proposed further amendments of the income tax law to allow deductions under other Commonwealth, State and Northern Territory cash bidding systems.

The amendments to be made by this Bill will allow deductions for cash bids paid for exploration permits and production licences under the Commonwealth's combined cash bidding and work program system which was included in the offshore petroleum legislation in 1967.

TALK.START.PARA: —Why are you reading this?

—I am reading it because the Opposition requires me to. I am sorry that it sounds so dull and boring. This combined cash bidding-work program system can only apply in circumstances where a previous production licence is discontinued or where a production licence application for a permit is not finalised and the relevant permit is given up. Deductibility will also be extended to cash bids paid under State and Northern Territory cash bidding systems that are equivalent to the Commonwealth's systems.

SPEECH.PARA: Consistent with the existing tax law, cash bid payments will be written off on a straight line basis over the lesser of 10 years or the life of the producing field to which the permit or licence relates. Write-off for cash bids will commence in the income year in which a production licence is first acquired in respect of the relevant permit area or at the time cash bid payments are made, whichever is the later. This should not have any cost to revenue over the next three years and revenue effects beyond that are dependent on when production licences are granted under cash bidding arrangements. The amendments will apply in respect of cash bids paid on or after 15 January 1986, the date of the original announcement to allow tax deductibility for cash bids paid under the Commonwealth cash bidding system introduced in 1985.
Foreign Tax Credit System

Amendments are being made to the foreign tax credit provisions to modify the practical operation of the system in relation to creditable foreign taxes and the treatment of overseas employment income of Australian resident individuals. The Bill will also correct some technical deficiencies in the law relating to the quarantining of foreign losses, the treatment of certain dividends as interest income as part of the interest quarantining measures, the amendment of credit determinations and the transfer of excess credits within wholly-owned company groups. Those amendments to the foreign tax credit system which are of a concessional nature are to apply from the commencement of the 1987-88 year of income. Other amendments will apply prospectively from the commencement of the 1988-89 year of income. The changes will have negligible effect on revenue in 1987-88 but may produce some unquantifiable revenue savings in subsequent years. The Government has under consideration a number of other foreign tax credit matters which if requiring legislative action will be the subject of a further Bill.
Thin Capitalisation

The thin capitalisation rules applying to foreign investments in Australia are to be varied in two particular areas. An amendment to the definition of foreign debt in relation to partnerships and trusts will close off an avenue for avoidance otherwise available to overseas investors who are not themselves partners or beneficiaries. The amendment will ensure that these investors are subject to the rules. The second amendment will modify the effect of an equity maintenance requirement that has a potentially broader application than intended. The redrafted provision will affect a much smaller group of investors than the present law.

Under the thin capitalisation rules the level of foreign equity in an Australian investment is generally measured annually. An equity maintenance requirement ensures that equity that is introduced in a year of income to comply with a debt-equity ratio rule is not removed in either of the two years of income following its introduction. Where the equity is prematurely removed the anti-avoidance measure treats that equity as if it had never been introduced. The present rule could apply wherever equity is removed regardless of how long it has been in place.

For resident companies the modified rule will apply to shares introduced in a year of income to ensure that they are maintained for the two subsequent years of income. For other forms of foreign investment the equity maintenance rule will apply where the level of equity is increased in a year of income and will operate to ensure that that level is maintained for the two succeeding years of income. Where the newly introduced equity is not maintained for the required period a lower level of equity will be substituted in debt-equity ratio calculations and may be reflected in an adjustment to related deductions for interest payments. The amended provisions, which will operate from the commencement of the 1989 year of income, should have negligible impact on the revenue.
Rebate for Service Pensioners

The income tax law will be amended to increase the amount of the rebate of tax, known as the pensioner rebate, available for service pensioners. The rebate will be increased for the 1987-88 income year from $250 to $308 so as to ensure that no income tax is payable by service pensioners if their taxable income does not exceed $6,384. The rebate will shade out at the rate of 12.5c for each dollar of taxable income in excess of $6,384, cutting out completely for a service pensioner with a 1987-88 taxable income in excess of $8,847. In the current year, there will be 27 fortnightly paydays for service pensioners instead of the usual 26.

But for this amendment, certain service pensioners whose sole source of income is their pension would become liable to pay income tax. The amendment means that a service pensioner in receipt of the single rate pension can receive additional private income of up to $3.70 a week and not pay tax. The level of the pensioner rebate available for social security pensioners will not be changed by this amendment. The estimated cost of the change is $17m in 1988-89.
Educational Allowances

As part of the Government's strategy to increase young people's access to employment, education and training, the Government has made a number of changes over the past three years to rationalise and improve youth income support programs. One of the changes has been to the education assistance available under the Aboriginal secondary assistance scheme and the Aboriginal study assistance scheme to bring the assistance more into line with that provided under Austudy, the main Commonwealth scheme for community-wide educational assistance. Consistent with the taxation treatment of Austudy payments, this Bill will make taxable from 1 January 1988 payments for students aged 16 years or more under the Aboriginal secondary assistance scheme and payments under the Aboriginal study assistance scheme.

The Bill will also extend the availability of the beneficiary rebates to affected students for the 1988-89 and subsequent income years. The purpose of the beneficiary rebate is to ensure that persons wholly or mainly dependent on certain social security benefits or education allowances do not have to pay income tax. The availability of the beneficiary rebates is also being extended to formal training allowance recipients for the 1987-88 and subsequent income years. The changes relating to the Aboriginal study assistance scheme and the Aboriginal secondary assistance scheme are expected to result in a gain of $0.5m in a full year while the formal training allowance charge is expected to cost $2.5m in 1988-89.
Carer's Pension

Before 1 February 1988 a carer's pension was payable to a relative of a severely handicapped age or invalid pensioner where the relative provided constant care and attention to the handicapped pensioner in the home of the relative and the pensioner. The pension was exempt from income tax where both the carer and the handicapped pensioner were below age pension age; if either were of pension age, the carer's pension was taxable. From 1 February, the carer's pension has also been available to a person caring for a severely handicapped age or invalid pensioner but who is not a relative. The effect has been to exempt the carer's pension from income tax where a person who is not a relative and is below age pension age cares for a handicapped pensioner of age pension age. As this is inconsistent with the treatment of the carer's pension when paid to a carer who is a relative, that particular exemption is to be removed, with effect from the date of enactment of the Bill. This will ensure that the tax treatment of the carer's pension is determined without regard to whether the carer is related to the person cared for. The revenue gain is expected to be negligible.
Technical Amendments

The Bill will also make a substantial number of minor technical amendments to the income tax law and certain other laws administered by the Commissioner of Taxation. These amendments will have no effect on revenue.

An explanatory memorandum which comprehensively explains the measures contained in this Bill is being circulated for the information of honourable senators. I present the explanatory memorandum and commend the Bill to the Senate.

DEBATE.TITLE: INTERSTATE ROAD TRANSPORT CHARGE AMENDMENT BILL 1988

PROCTEXT.PARA: Bill received from the House of Representatives.
Motion (by Senator Tate) agreed to:
That the Bill may proceed without formalities and be now read a first time.
Bill read a first time.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Tate Sen The Hon M.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That the Bill be now read a second time.
I seek leave to have the second reading speech incorporated in Hansard.
Leave granted.
The speech read as follows-

The purpose of this Bill is to amend the Interstate Road Transport Charge Act 1985. The Act provides for the level of charges to be paid by owners of vehicles registered under the Interstate Road Transport Act 1985. The charges recover road wear costs of vehicles engaged in interstate trade and commerce.

The Bill enables registration charges in excess of $1000 to be set for vehicles operating with a gross combination mass exceeding 38 tonnes. This is required to offset the extra costs of road wear caused by the operation of these vehicles. The $1000 limit for other classes of vehicles remains.
The Bill should be read in conjunction with the Interstate Road Transport Amendment Bill 1988 and is to come into effect on the same day as that Bill, 1 July 1988.
I commend the Bill to the Senate.
Debate (on motion by Senator Reid) adjourned.

PROCTEXT.PARA: Bill received from the House of Representatives.
Motion (by Senator Tate) agreed to:
That the Bill may proceed without formalities and be now read a first time.
Bill read a first time.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Tate Sen The Hon M.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That the Bill be now read a second time.
I seek leave to have the second reading speech incorporated in Hansard.
Leave granted.
The speech read as follows-

The amendments proposed in the Interstate Road Transport Amendment Bill 1988 and the Interstate Road Transport Charge Amendment Bill 1988 will enable the Federal Government to implement its part of a second package of reforms for the Australian road transport industry.
This Government is the only government in Australia's history to have attended to the problems of our national road freight industry.

Since it initiated the National Road Freight Inquiry in 1983, chaired by Mr Tom May, the Labor Government has worked closely with State and Territory Governments and the road transport industry to provide sensible and productive reforms. We have introduced significant efficiencies to the industry, improved its safety and recognised the difficulties faced by many truckies. We will continue to develop these reforms which will have major flow-on to the needs of Australian industry as a whole, to our economy, and our international trade.

Transport is a major sector in the Australian economy. It accounts for about 17% of Australia's GDP, with the road transport sector contributing about $16 billion per year to value-added output on 7.5% of GDP.

Transport costs make up over 40% of the final product price for the mining industry, between 6 and 12% for primary products and 13% for manufacturing. Road transport costs typically account for around 5% of product costs in the more trade-exposed parts of the manufacturing sector.
Road transport will continue to play a predominant role in the Australian economy. By the year 2000 total road use is expected to be about 60% above the 1985 level.

People often forget the geographic size of our country. They forget the distances over which our raw materials have to be carried, and too often make specious comparisons attempting to focus on transport costs as a scape-goat for their competitive position.
We know there are efficiencies to be gained and over the last five years we have achieved much with shipping costs, with our railways (particularly Australian National), and with road freight.
Our road freight industry is in fact one of our most competitive industries and internationally we are renowned for our trucking expertise.

The May Report has provided a blue-print for the development of the industry. The first set of reforms based on the Report was the fast-track package of reforms which commenced on 1 January 1987. Central to the fast-track package was the Federal Interstate Registration Scheme which was established under the Interstate Road Transport Act 1985 and the Interstate Road Transport Charge Act 1985.
This Scheme provides for the registration of vehicles engaged solely in interstate trade and commerce and the payment of reasonable registration charges which recover the cost of road wear.

On the initiative of this Government, State and Territory Ministers endorsed the second-stage package at the Australian Transport Advisory Council (ATAC) Ministerial meeting last December. The reforms are being introduced co-operatively by Federal, State and Territory Governments and have the strong support of industry.
The package comprises
increasing the national speed limit for heavy vehicles in non-urban areas to 100 km/h,
revising driving hours in the eastern mainland States to reflect more realistically modern Australian conditions,
introducing revised registration charges and new registration categories providing for higher and nationally uniform load limits under the Federal Interstate Registration Scheme.

The increase in the heavy vehicle speed limit to 100 km/h outside built up areas will improve safety by removing the disparity between truck and car speeds. This will reduce the need for overtaking, which has been identified as a major road safety problem.

The move to this limit follows an interim increase to 90km/h which was evaluated over twelve months. The results of this evaluation showed there had been no adverse road safety implications from the increase to 90km/h.

The introduction of uniform revised driving hours arrangements along the eastern mainland seaboard acknowledges the realities of modern vehicle design, today's road conditions and existing practices. Overall weekly driving hours will increase only slightly but more flexibility is provided to meet the varying needs of different operators.
Driving hours will be enforced by an enhanced log book system, with the alternative option of approved tachographs.

The impact of the new speed limit and revised driving hours will be closely monitored and enforced. ATAC Ministers called on the road transport industry to demonstrate a responsible attitude to the introduction of the new package. Industry associations support the concept of realistic enforcement. The industry supports the reform package.

The changes to the Federal legislation will provide for new vehicles categories to be introduced under the Federal Registration Scheme to allow Federally registered vehicles to operate at higher mass limits. This arrangement will obviate the need for the existing vehicle mass permit schemes in New South Wales and Victoria for Federally registered vehicles.
For the first time Federally registered vehicles will be able to operate at a uniform limit across Australia.

The registration charges to apply from 1 July 1988 for vehicles registered under the Federal Interstate Registration Scheme were announced on 26 April 1988. The revised charges are a further step in pursuing our commitment to allowing truck owners to make a fair contribution to maintaining our road infrastructure.

They include the new classes of vehicles operating at higher mass limits. In determining the charges, consideration has been given to the Inter-State Commission's 1987 Review of Federal Registration Charges for Interstate Vehicles.
Money collected from registration charges will continue to be returned to State and Territory Governments for the maintenance and upkeep of roads used by Federally registered vehicles.
Let me now turn to the individual amendments.

The principal amendment in the Interstate Road Transport Amendment Bill provides for new registration categories to be established to enable vehicles to operate at mass limits up to 42.5 tonnes under the Federal Interstate Registration Scheme.

To implement the higher mass limits a specific regulatory power has been used. In addition a general regulatory power for vehicle operating standards has also been inserted into the Act allowing us to implement a smoking ban on Federal interstate buses and coaches. This will also enable us to act quickly to achieve further reforms for the industry in the future.
The smoking ban was agreed to by Federal State Ministers and will complement similar State legislation to be introduced during 1988.
Clause 12 provides the general regulation making power covering vehicle operating standards which will be used to implement this ban.
The provisions are in line with the ban on smoking on commercial passenger aircraft which commenced on 1 December 1987.

Let me emphasise that at this stage the regulation making powers will only apply to new regulations for the control of mass limits and to implement the ban on smoking in interstate buses and coaches. The continued willingness of States to implement jointly agreed reforms will mean that the general use of these regulatory powers should be minimal.

Clause 6 clears the way to introduce increased mass limit for Federally registered vehicles and Clause 5 expressly exempts Federal vehicles from the need to obtain a State permit for operating at the higher mass limits.

Consequential amendments are required to the Interstate Road Transport Charge Act. They will enable the Government to set registration charges to offset the extra costs of road wear for 42.5 tonne vehicles. The charge for vehicles over 38 tonnes is $3135. The legislation will set a charge limit of $5000 for these vehicles. Any increase above this limit would require an amendment to the legislation. The $1000 limit for other classes of vehicles will be retained.

The remaining minor amendments are of an administrative nature and are required to streamline operations for the benefit of both the State authorities which administer the Registration Scheme and the users-the road transport industry.

The Interstate Road Transport Amendment Bill provides for the amendments to come into force on 1 July 1988. State Ministers of the Australian Transport Advisory Council have accepted this introduction date.

The net budgetary impact of these amendments will be nil. All registration charges will be paid into the Interstate Road Transport Trust Fund and will continue to be fully distributed to the States and Territories.

All administrative costs incurred by State and Territory authorities administering the scheme are met through the levying of fees. No additional staffing requirements or administration will arise for the Federal Department of Transport and Communications.
The charges for vehicles in the new categories will be offset by increased efficiency and productivity for the road transport industry.
Bus and coach industry organisations claim the ban on smoking will reduce maintenance costs.

The reforms being realised in the Interstate Road Transport Amendment Bills reflect the importance of road transport for the Australian economy. They are another constructive step towards achieving the Government's goal of restructuring the economy; part of the Government's micro-economic reform package for achieving an efficient transport industry.
I commend the Bills to the Senate.

DEBATE.TITLE: CONSTITUTION ALTERATION (PARLIAMENTARY TERMS) BILL 1988 CONSTITUTION ALTERATION (ELECTORS' INITIATIVE) BILL 1987[COGNATE BILLS:CONSTITUTION ALTERATION (FAIR ELECTIONS) BILL 1988CONSTITUTION ALTERATION (LOCAL GOVERNMENT) BILL 1988CONSTITUTION ALTERATION (RIGHTS AND FREEDOMS) BILL 1988]

PROCTEXT.PARA: Debate resumed from 19 May, on motion by Senator Tate, and from 23 September 1987, on motion by Senator Macklin:
That the Bill be now read a second time.

DEBATE.TITLE: CONSTITUTION ALTERATION (PARLIAMENTARY TERMS) BILL 1988 CONSTITUTION ALTERATION (ELECTORS' INITIATIVE) BILL 1987

TALK.START.PARA: —I propose that the Constitution Alteration (Parliamentary Terms) Bill 1988 and the Constitution Alteration (Electors' Initiative) Bill 1987 be debated cognately with the Constitution Alteration (Fair Elections) Bill 1988, the Constitution Alteration (Local Government) Bill 1988 and the Constitution Alteration (Rights and Freedoms) Bill 1988.

INTERJECT.SPEAKER: The ACTING DEPUTY PRESIDENT

TALK.START.PARA: —Is it the wish of the Senate that these Bills be taken cognately? There being no objection, I will allow that course to be followed.

INTERJECT.PARA: That so much of the Standing and Sessional Orders be suspended as would prevent the Leader of the Opposition in the Senate, Senator Chaney, the Deputy Leader of the Australian Democrats, Senator Macklin, and the Minister for Home Affairs, Senator Robert Ray, speaking for up to one hour in the debate.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Chaney Sen The Hon F.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Senate is now commencing what I think is the most serious debate that we are likely to have to undertake during the current calendar year, because it relates to proposals to alter the Australian Constitution, not merely once, but in four separate propositions that are being put forward in the four Government Bills, the titles of which have just been read by the Deputy Clerk. In addition, we are debating cognately a proposal for an electors' initiative which has been put forward by the Australian Democrats. That matter will be dealt with at the same time as the other Bills. The debate is important because the Government has put forward a series of propositions which, on their face, have won a lot of support from commentators in particular and it is the Opposition's view that the approach which the Government had adopted in bringing these matters forward is quite dishonest and certainly utterly misleading.

SPEECH.PARA: The debate takes place after a careful process of propaganda or education, according to one's point of view, undertaken by the Government through its establishment of the Constitutional Commission. Without any doubt the Government was hoping to capitalise upon the birthday atmosphere of the Bicentenary to achieve some of its long-term political objectives. We believe that the four Bills that we are debating-I talk about those principally rather than the Australian Democrats proposal which is being dealt with cognately-have a number of effects which the Government has sought to hide. For a start, the proposals increase the power of the Prime Minister. They do that by giving him even more flexibility as to when he may call an election. Most serious from the point of view of the Australian community and this chamber, the first proposal is an attack on the role of the Senate and its constitutional function. For that reason that proposal is bitterly opposed by the Opposition. The proposals would reduce the local autonomy of the people. They would not, as the Government has suggested, give power to the people. I think we can demonstrate in this debate that they would reduce the local autonomy of the people of Australia. They give new and measurable powers not to the people of Australia but to the judges of Australia. The proposals are internally inconsistent and hypocritical and we totally reject the basis which the Minister for Justice, Senator Tate, put as the basis of these changes in the second reading speech on the Constitution Alteration (Parliamentary Terms) Bill last Thursday. I personally would endorse one paragraph of that second reading speech, and I shall quote it. Senator Tate said:

The basic building blocks of our Parliamentary system are firmly in place; the edifice of the Australian federation, its basic principles of responsible and representative government, upheld by our judicial system, are not under challenge.
He went on to quote the words of the Constitutional Commission in its first report. I wish to repeat just some of those words. The Constitutional Commission said:
In particular, we have been conscious of the need to retain in form and spirit the federal framework of government in Australia, parliamentary government and democratic institutions.

That is claimed by Senator Tate to be the basis upon which these propositions are put forward, that we are to retain in form and spirit the federal framework of government in Australia, parliamentary government and democratic institutions. In the view of the Opposition that is precisely the opposite of the truth. Senator Tate went on to say:

I trust it will be in that spirit that this Parliament, and then the people of Australia, will approach one of the greatest responsibilities and opportunities enjoyed by a free and independent people-the task of making and amending their own Constitution, under which we all live, in this generation and for the generations to come.

It is certainly the view of the Opposition that it must approach this batch of Bills bearing in mind that they relate to the making and amending of the Constitution and that they will affect not merely this generation but the generations to come.

The Government has put an extraordinarily benign view, an almost status quo view, on these Bills. Yet other people take a quite contrary view. I was struck by the view which was expressed by Mr Ewart Smith, who from having been a little known but very senior member of the Attorney-General's Department over many years rocketed to prominence with his opinion and views on the identity card legislation and his discovery of the loophole in that legislation which led to its ultimate destruction. Mr Ewart Smith is a former constitutional adviser to successive Federal governments and a former Deputy Secretary of the Federal Attorney-General's Department. He has a very different view of the referendum proposals from that put forward by Senator Tate on behalf of the Government. In an opinion which I have, Mr Smith said:

The four proposals being put by the Government to referendum later in the year contain the greatest threat to the established institutions of our Federation ever put by a Government. We are being asked to accept them with overtones which suggest that it is somehow in accordance with the spirit of the Bicentenary year to do so: it is almost unpatriotic to refuse them!

We in the Opposition see these changes in the same terms as Mr Smith, as a threat to the established institutions of our Federation. I find that it is not just Mr Smith who is sceptical of what the Government is doing. In the weekend Press there was a column written by Mr Paddy McGuinness, who I think is well known in this place as a commentator on social and economic issues. He said:

The Australian Constitution, on which our federation is based, with all its faults, is a robust and reasonably well-constructed basic law, which protects our democracy in a way which other countries can only envy. It has contributed much to the stability of our political system.
Just a paragraph or so later he said:

The Federal Government is being very dishonest in its approach to the proposed referendum on constitutional amendments. It is also being quite unjustifiably hasty about the whole thing-itself a reason for suspicion. So it will be only its own fault if even the defensible amendments are defeated.

The Opposition does not agree with Mr McGuinness that any of the amendments are defensible but I quoted him because he writes as someone who is not necessarily opposed to all the propositions that the Government has put forward, but he is certainly opposed to the way in which this matter is being approached by the Government. He went on to make a point which has been made very strongly by the Opposition over recent times. He said:
The questions actually being asked are quite misleading. Here is what they really ought to be:

I quote them not because I necessarily agree with everything that has been said by Mr McGuinness but because they show that a totally independent observer, someone outside politics but a keen observer of the Australian legal, political and economic scene, comes up with a set of questions which bear very little relationship to what is being put in questions to the people of Australia by this Government. Mr McGuinness said the first question is:
Do you agree to weakening the power and status of the Senate?
That is the question which the Government should be posing if it wants this proposal to be honestly considered by the people of Australia. His version of the second referendum question is:
Do you want to stop the National Party gerrymandering electoral boundaries, especially in Queensland?

I might reject that as a fair putting of the question but I simply quote it as an example of how very different is Mr McGuinness's view of the question as compared with the Government's. Mr McGuinness suggests that the question on the recognition of local government should be:
Do you want to cater to the vanity of local government politicians and make it more difficult to reform corrupt local government?

Again, that is a very different view from the one I would express but that is Mr McGuinness's version of the question which should flow from this legislation. Finally, he says that question four should read:
Do you want to confirm rights of freedom of religion, trial by jury and compensation for property without bothering about any other human rights?

So we have from Mr McGuinness a thoroughly critical assessment of what the Government is about, both as to its honesty and as to its accuracy. He finishes by saying that what the Parliament should be debating is a whole new approach to constitutional reform rather than wasting another $30m on a referendum. The last person I wish to quote as an outside observer who has had comments to make about the honesty or otherwise of the Government's approach to constitutional reform is Mr Morgan, who as the head of the Morgan Gallup Poll organisation is one of the most well known Australians in the field of public opinion polling. He said that any public opinion polling company which asks questions `as blatantly biased as the Government proposes would completely lose credibility'.

There is some guffawing by the officials advising the Minister. If they wish to participate in this debate I hope they might get themselves elected to the Senate, or ejected from the Senate as the case might be. However, if they wish to be participants in this place they might let us know and we might see what can be done to amend the Standing Orders to allow it. Let me say that I do not blame the officials for this pathetic attempt to hoodwink the people of Australia but if the behaviour of the advisers in the box is an indication that the Attorney-General's Department is implicated in this exercise, I can only say that the Public Service of Australia has reached a very sorry state indeed.

To return to the matters of this debate, the dishonesty of the Government in the questions it has put is borne out by the fact that it spent $6m on having a Constitutional Commission, a clear part of the function of which was to soften up the Australian people to the whole idea of constitutional change. I do not make any allegation against the character of those people who accepted appointment as commissioners; nor do I challenge their right to put views, having been put in that position by the Government. I simply remind the people of Australia that a substantial part of the budget of this organisation has gone in publicising the very idea of constitutional change and that we have in some ways an inherently defective constitution. That, in our view, is not the truth. The Constitution is not inherently defective. Sometimes the way elements of it are used may not be what the people want, but that is not the fault of the Constitution. We had a $6m public relations exercise. The fact that it is no more than a public relations exercise is borne out by the simple reality that the Government did not even wait for the final report of the Commission before determining what matters it would put forward as constitutional amendments.

What more obvious demonstration could we have of the dishonesty of this approach than that the Government had to hasten some sort of preliminary recommendations out of the Commission so that that could have any temporal relationship with the propositions being put forward by the Government-and the Government is not even putting forward propositions which uniformly reflect even that preliminary view of the Commission, because what the Commission has said about the fundamental proposal that there should be a change to the parliamentary term and a change to the fundamental position of the Senate is quite different from what the Government is proposing. I accuse the Government of engaging in a charade and pretence. It has enlisted distinguished Australians to lend their names and minds to an exercise which, the Government has made quite clear, was an exercise not in achieving national agreement as to the changes needed to the Constitution but, rather, it has used those people to achieve a climate for change.

We should not be surprised at the dishonesty the Government has shown. We have had to use the authority of this Senate in the past to prevent a fraud upon the electorate, a fraud which was attempted by Senator Evans when he was Attorney-General. Senator Evans, in 1983, wished to bring forward constitutional amendments. He faced a situation in which it had been the established procedures for the publishing of constitutional amendments that there should be equal public expenditure on the Yes and No cases. It is a feature of our approach to constitutional change that every elector in the Commonwealth receives at taxpayers'-Commonwealth-expense a document setting out the Yes and No cases. The Government, which is usually the proponent of constitutional change, does not control the state of the No case. The content of the No case on the pamphlet is controlled by those people who have opposed the referendum.

It is a carefully designed and balanced approach which is aimed to ensure fairness, the word the Government continually uses about these referendum proposals. We have a procedure aimed at ensuring that, in a fair way, all people are advised of the pros and the cons-the case for Yes and the case for No. Senator Evans, in 1983, set out to breach that arrangement by obtaining $1.25m of taxpayers' money, not to spend on publicising both sides of the argument, but to arrange publicity for the Yes case, which he wished to promote. It was because of the opposition of the Liberal Party, the National Party and the Australian Democrats who were not prepared to see that perversion of the system, that we were able to prevent it. Senator Evans said that we were engaged in what he described as a classic demonstration of crude political opportunism. It just shows how debate in politics in this country is debased when a Minister who sets out to frustrate and thwart the procedures for constitutional change, and who is defeated by this Senate in his attempt to be quite duplicitous with the Australian people, accuses us of crude political opportunism. I mention that because it is a very good indication of the attitude of the Australian Labor Party to these matters.

The other general comment I wish to make is that in our assessment of the Government's motive in bringing these matters forward and its genuine objective, we take note of the attitudes which have been expressed so often by Labor Party spokesmen, including the leading members of the Labor Party in the Senate, about the role of the Senate. We enter into this debate knowing that it is the fundamental objective of the most senior members of the Labor Party in this place to see the role and influence of the Senate reduced, if not destroyed. The Labor Party may have taken out of its formal policy and platform documents the absolute destruction of the Senate but I remind honourable senators that Senator Evans made no secret when he came to this place of his contempt for it and his determination to work from within to destroy it. That quotation is too well known to need repeating. Senator Evans said here that the best way to deal with the Senate was to work from within to destroy its powers. We know what Senator Walsh thinks of it. He is reported to have said that the Senate:
is the biggest institutional obstacle to economic adjustment and reform.
He says:
The ill-informed sabotage of rational policy was a threat to responsible government.
He talks of the Government having to:
rely on the support of minor parties or single issue zealots-
he is referring there to the Australian Democrats, presumably, and the Independents-
none of whom will ever be burdened with the discipline or responsibility of government.

He made other very uncomplimentary remarks about the Senate, referring to comments of one of his colleagues about us being the swill of Australian politics. He referred with approval to Paul Keating's succinct assessment of the Senate as the repository of the `swill of Australian politics'. To have senators defending the Senate is to have the less important defenders, because we might be seen to speak from self-interest. I can only say that experts who sought to thrust upon the people the Bill of Rights and the identity card no doubt see that destruction of those proposals as an indication of our poor quality. For all I know, the giggling advisers may be in that category. But those people who over a period of months of debate and explanation of what was being done came to realise that the proposal was not in their interests, as they had once thought, because there were elements they had not clearly understood on the face of the proposal, will remember the value of the Senate. Those same people who saw that what the Government was proposing was not what it seemed will again come to the defence of the Senate.

I expect that the fundamental hatred by people of this place, which flows in part from the events of 1975 but mainly from the whole objection, on the part of those who believe that executive government knows best, to the idea that a House of Parliament should dare to interfere with the actions of executive government, has motivated these constitutional changes and, in particular, the first constitutional proposal. Those of us who believe that the people of Australia are entitled to representative institutions that will ensure that there is proper and full debate on the proposals of the Executive, stand in solid opposition to them.

I also want to say that, if we are trying to assess the honesty or integrity of purpose of the Government in bringing forward these constitutional changes, it is important to note that no serious attempt was made by the Government to achieve any bipartisan support. Again, it went through a charade. The Leader of the Australian Labor Party, Mr Hawke, and his Deputy, the Attorney-General, Mr Lionel Bowen, had a discussion with Mr Howard which, as I understand it from the description Mr Howard has given in the Parliament, focused on the issue of the change to the terms of Parliament. Mr Howard made it clear that, whilst supporting a four-year term, we would not in any way support a proposal which at the same time was aimed at the destruction of the Senate. Four hours after that discussion, which included the Government raising an alternative possibility of a five-year term, the Government announced its proposals. We say that if the Government were genuinely interested in achieving a bipartisan position there would have been a more genuine attempt than that to arrive at some common ground.

I will turn to the specific Bills which we are to deal with in this cognate debate. The first is the Constitution Alteration (Parliamentary Terms) Bill. The full title of that Bill is `An Act to alter the Constitution to provide for four year maximum terms for members of both Houses of the Commonwealth Parliament'. As I have already indicated in my preliminary comments, in fact the Bill has a much wider import. The effect of this Bill is to permit a permanent double dissolution arrangement. It effectively permits the Prime Minister at any time to call for the dissolution of the whole of the Senate and of the House of Representatives. There is, therefore, a massive increase in prime ministerial power to call early elections and certainly to call elections which affect the Senate.

As a necessary by-product of that, the Bill means an end to the rotation of senators. Since Federation it has been a feature of the Senate that only half the Senate is elected in a normal election. That is a procedure that was put in place to ensure that the Senate would not be prey to sudden shifts of political opinion. Effectively, that element of the Senate would be brought to an end if this proposal were brought forward.

The proposition also means an end to the fixed terms of senators. At the moment, subject only to the double dissolution arrangements, a senator is elected for a fixed term of six years. All of us who have been in this place since the mid-1970s know how often double dissolutions have been used to interrupt those full terms and few, if any, in this place have served a full six-year term. But it is also a remaining element of our constitutional arrangements that, when a Prime Minister is considering calling an early election, one of the limiting factors on him is his incapacity to bring forward elections for the Senate unless he has a double dissolution power or unless he is within the prescribed constitutional period for a Senate election. If this Bill becomes law and if the referendum is passed it will remove that fetter on prime ministerial discretion.

The only essential element of the Senate which is left if this referendum succeeds is the equal representation of the States. To some extent, that can be said to be already at risk because, with the approval of the High Court of Australia of the creation of Territory senators, it remains open to a government with control of the Senate to, in turn, gerrymander the Senate by the creation of unlimited numbers of Senate places from Territories. That is not something which I think could be got through the Senate currently. I trust that the present composition of the Senate would block any attempt to rort the Senate, to gerrymander the Senate in this way.

The point I make is that the fundamental constitutional protection of the institution of the Senate is thoroughly challenged and indeed virtually destroyed by this proposal. The Government's claim that it will lead to fewer elections is based on hope and, in our view, is likely to be proven wrong because there is less fetter on the ability of the Prime Minister of the day to call elections. He can call an election for both Houses at any time.

I think the attitude of the public to this will, in the end, be determined by the attitude of the public to the Senate and its role. The fundamental point which has to be considered by the Australian people is whether they want to have one chamber of this Parliament which still functions as a parliamentary chamber. I think it would be fair to say that there are few, if any, chambers of Australian parliaments-we have, of course, eight parliaments in this country-where the Executive does not ride roughshod over the parliamentary institution. Certainly in our sister chamber, the House of Representatives, the necessary majority of the Government has led to a quite contemptuous view about parliamentary debate.

In this chamber, even when the government of the day had a majority-I remind honourable senators that the Fraser Government had a majority in the Senate in the early years-there was no similar attitude to the functioning of this chamber. I remind the Senate of that because the reality is that we have a tradition in this place which is, in a sense, the last vestige of genuine parliamentary life in this country. To the men and women of Australia that means that, when a government is considering major changes which could fundamentally change the nature of our society or our country, the likelihood is that those changes will receive little or no consideration in the lower House.

One can take examples from whatever sort of government one likes-Labor or Liberal-it does not matter. I remind honourable senators that in the days of the Whitlam Government a proposal was whipped through the House of Representatives for a national compensation scheme that would have made an enormous difference to very large elements of Australian life-legal, workers compensation and accident compensation generally. It came to this chamber and was submitted to careful parliamentary scrutiny by a Senate committee. The present Leader of the Government in the Senate, Senator Button, was a member of that committee, as was I. The views of the Executive Government were subjected to the most careful and rigorous scrutiny and people had a chance to come before the parliamentary committee and to put their views. The three Labor members and the three Liberal members unanimously agreed that that Bill should be withdrawn.
When this Government introduced its quite radical proposal for a Bill of Rights it went through the House of Representatives in about a day. There was about one day of debate.

TALK.START.PARA: —It was guillotined.

—It was guillotined, according to my friend and colleague Senator Peter Durack. There was one day of debate on a major change to the institutional arrangements in this country. It was only when it came to the Senate that the long debate which occurred in this place resulted in such a public reaction that the Bill was withdrawn. That sort of parliamentary activity does not occur outside this Senate. If the people of Australia value what we have been able to do with respect to the Bill of Rights and the identity card-I believe that they do-they will throw out this first referendum because it is fundamentally about subverting the capacity of this Senate to maintain any sort of independent stance.

SPEECH.PARA: I do not care who has the majority in this place-whether it is a Labor majority when Labor is in government, a Liberal-National majority when we are in government, or a split Senate as we have now with the Australian Democrats and the Independents having the balance of power-if this referendum is carried, there will be a destruction of the institutional ethos of the Senate which was maintained during the period of the Liberal Government when we had the majority in this place without the assistance of Independents. I believe that Australia will be the poorer for that and that the people of Australia will have many fewer protections than they have today.

I remind the Senate, too, that the proposal which is being put forward by the Government is not in the terms recommended by the Constitutional Commission. In this respect the Constitutional Commission recommendation was quite clear. It recommended that there should be a continuation of senators having two terms of the House of Representatives. It did not put forward precisely the proposition that the Opposition would put forward; it put forward a proposition for simultaneous elections, but with half the Senate being elected.

The Government has chosen to ignore it, just as the Government has ignored the views of the Business Council of Australia which has published a document that I hope will not be widely misunderstood which supports the need for a longer term for Federal Parliament. When one reads that document carefully, one can see that the Constitutional Commission is making it clear that the problems in instituting a four-year term can be overcome by extending the terms of senators from six to eight years, or by providing that senators serve for two terms of the House of Representatives. Let me make the point that this proposal comes from nowhere but the Government and it is not a proposal that will be supported by anyone who believes Parliament should have any continuing role in the government of this country. I turn to what Ewart Smith said. His comment in the opinion to which I have referred was to call this `the most sinister of all the proposals' that are being put forward by the Government. While saying that `one can agree in principle that a four-year term has been readily accepted as a proper term for Australia', Ewart Smith continued to make the point that this will be a great attack, `a diminution of the influence of the Senate'. That is exactly what the proposed amendments do and are intended to do.
I turn now to the Constitution Alteration (Fair Elections) Bill, the title of which is:
An Act to alter the Constitution to provide for fair and democratic parliamentary elections throughout Australia.

Once again we have a totally dishonest question being put to the Australian people. The real import of the Bill is that the Government is seeking to apply as an overriding and absolute rule on the States the principle of one vote one value. I have absolutely no doubt that you, Mr Acting Deputy President, like many other Liberals and Nationals, would accept that the principle of one vote one value is of great importance in determining a fair electoral system. But what the Government is doing here is not saying, `Let us make this an important principle of electoral redistribution'; it is saying that this will be the overriding and immutable principle for State upper and lower Houses. Yet the Government is not prepared in this proposal, and nor should it be, to apply the same principle immutably to the Commonwealth.

The proposition says to the States, `We will not apply one vote one value to the House of Representatives or to the Senate but we will apply one vote one value on an immutable basis to the parliaments of the States'. I have had a look at the arrangements for the Commonwealth and they will not be touched by this referendum proposal. It will not change the basis of the distribution of seats in the House of Representatives or the allocation of senators to each State. Shortly, I should like to have incorporated in Hansard a table which has been prepared by the Parliamentary Library and which shows the variations from the quotas, from the principle of one vote one value, in the current Federal Houses. These variations will not be touched by the Government in its proposal. For example, one finds in the House of Representatives that Tasmania is 14 per cent below quota because the Constitution guarantees the Tasmanians five seats in the House of Representatives. No-one in this chamber would challenge the rightness of that but the effect of that principle in the House of Representatives means that all the seats in Tasmania are beyond the tolerance permitted any lower House seat in the States.

The Australian Capital Territory (ACT) has two Labor members. I do not remember anyone objecting yet to there being two Labor members from the ACT; they are 16 per cent above quota. In other words, the Government is leaving in place arrangements under the Constitution that do not allow the application of one vote one value to the House of Representatives.

What is the position with the Senate? With its guaranteed equal representation from the States, the Senate presents a far starker picture. The table shows that in New South Wales senators are 117 per cent over quota. There is not a 10 per cent tolerance; it is 117 per cent away from the average for Australia. Victoria is 65 per cent out; Queensland is within the 10 per cent tolerance, its quota being 4.4 per cent; South Australia is 42 per cent below; Western Australia is 44 per cent below; the Northern Territory is 70 per cent below; the Australian Capital Territory is 40 per cent below; and Tasmania is 81 per cent below. In other words, the Senate is based on tolerances that range between plus 117 per cent and minus 81 per cent. On the Government's definition, that apparently is not fair. Yet I would say that virtually everyone in Australia would defend the Senate's present composition and the Government would not dare attack it because it knows any such attack would be rejected by the Australian people. That is what the Government is leaving in place for the Federal Parliament.

I make the point absolutely clear that I am not objecting to that; the arrangements are proper and democratic and do not provide advantage for any party. They provide fair representation for the States in the upper House and fair representation for the State of Tasmania. I seek leave to incorporate the table in Hansard.

TALK.START.PARA: —I thank the Senate. Let us turn to what is being struck down. The most obvious places being attacked are the upper Houses in Tasmania and Western Australia. The Western Australian Legislative Council was recently reconstituted on a regional basis and some variations are outside the 10 per cent tolerance. The range is between plus 48 per cent and minus 55 per cent; in other words, approximately half the range that applies to the Senate. The referendum alleges that one cannot have half of the variation in the State House of Western Australia that one has in the Senate. Yet the Senate variation will not be touched. I accuse the Government of rank hypocrisy and of turning an important principle into an immutable rule that will take from the States their entitlement to have an electoral system that meets State circumstances.

SPEECH.PARA: I remind the Government that when it proposed to legislate for the State of Western Australia, the then Labor Premier, Mr Burke, told the Government to go away and to leave the matter to the State because it was a State matter. The Tasmanian Legislative Council has variations that range between minus 60 per cent and plus 31 per cent of the average quota-again, roughly half the variations that apply to the Senate.

The simple point I wish to make is that the Opposition embraces the view that one vote one value is an important principle to take into account when drawing electoral boundaries but one vote one value will not prevent gerrymanders and will not prevent distributions of seats which are wrong and which are aimed to benefit the particular political interests of a particular party. The figures show that at the Commonwealth level a fair and democratic electoral system permits considerable variations. Quite apart from any issue of federalism and quite apart from the vital issue of leaving to the States the jurisdiction of their own affairs, which the Opposition regards as a centrally important element of the Constitution, the simple proposition I put to the Senate is that the Commonwealth is applying a rule to the States that it will not, would not and could not apply to the Federal Parliament. This referendum must be thrown out because to do otherwise would be to fly in the face of the realities of Australia.

As a Western Australian senator and one who has always argued in my State Party for the need to pay regard to the principle of one vote one value, I say that, in a State the size of Western Australia with its population distribution and its geographic features, to deny it the right of any regional representation in the upper House other than on the basis of one vote one value is not fair and democratic. Again, if I may pray in aid the views of Ewart Smith, he describes this as something which, on a superficial reading, appears to have no barbs. But he continues convincingly to make the point that it was not contemplated by the Constitution that there should be this capacity to take matters out of the hands of the States. The other very serious criticism that needs to be made about the proposals which have been put forward is that it is not at all clear what would happen if the State boundaries were struck down by this proposed constitutional change. The possibility of electoral chaos is real and speaks against our taking the view that this is an appropriate constitutional amendment.

I will turn now to the proposal to alter the Constitution to recognise local government. This proposal seems to have been born out of the depths of the greatest cynicism. It claims to recognise local government. The proposal is that there should be inserted into the Constitution these words:

Each State shall provide for the establishment and continuance of a system of local government, with local bodies elected in accordance with the laws of the State and empowered to administer, and to make by-laws for, their respective areas in accordance with the laws of the State.

It seems that there are only two possibilities with that amendment. One is that it is meaningless because it does no more than acknowledge the status quo. It does none of the things local government was seeking in recognition. On the face of it, it provides no constitutional guarantee that the States cannot dismiss local government and then refuse to reappoint it. The second reading speech made by the Minister for Justice (Senator Tate) makes it quite clear that the Government thinks that the existing arrangements for dismissal of local government will still apply. However, the sort of constitutional guarantees being sought by local government certainly, on the face of it, do not appear to be granted by this provision. Rather, it is simply a pious acknowledgment of what is already there in a circumstance in which four of the six States have already given recognition to local government in their own State constitutions. It appears to the Opposition that it is an appropriate action for a State government to follow to provide for an appropriate recognition of local government within a State constitution.

The Opposition certainly does not see the value of words that are meaningless or, if they are to have some meaning, have a meaning that cannot yet be divined. The quite contrary points which can be put as a caution against the amendment to recognise local government is that, as was said by the High Court in considering whether the guarantee of trial by jury had any meaning at all, Justices Dixon and Evatt said:
We admit the difficulties which the form of section 80 creates, but to treat such a constitutional provision as producing no substantial effect seems rather to defeat than to ascertain its intention.

In light of the extraordinary variations of constitutional interpretation by the High Court, I fear that the judges may quite properly see themselves as being under some duty to find a meaning to these words. If the meaning is not merely to recognise the existence of local government as something which is there but over which the Commonwealth, the courts and everyone else have no control outside the legislative arrangements that are put in place by the States, then there must be some risk that the judges could be prepared to try to find some other meaning for those words.

I challenge the Government to give any real guarantee that the proposals with respect to local government are any more than simply a bit of window dressing to make people in local government feel that they are getting some recognition when, in fact, the proposal is meaningless. Alternatively, what guarantee can the Government give that the High Court will not at some later time place some new meaning on the words that are, on the face of it, so apparently meaningless?

Quite naturally, local government has shown some interest in this matter and there is a long history on the question of recognition of local government. Another point that is worth making in this debate is that if this provision is meaningless, as it appears on the face of it, and adds nothing to the Constitution, why is the Government undertaking it? I simply wish to remind local government that, over the past three years, the Hawke Government has demonstrated its real attitude to local government by the funding arrangements it has put in place. I remind local government of the relatively benign approach of the Liberal and National parties to local government when it comes to providing benefits for that level of government.

Local government should remember that the Hawke Government cutbacks in road funding over the past three years amount to a reduction of 25 per cent or $300m. The Hawke Government has cut back local government's share of personal income tax collections. Under Mr Fraser's Government, that share of income tax collections was increased 2 per cent. If one looks at the figures under the Hawke Government, again taken out by the Library, one sees that in 1985-86, the Government reduced the share of local government to 1.9 per cent; in 1986-87, it was reduced to 1.85 per cent; in 1987-88, it was reduced to 1.75 per cent; and the estimate for this year is 1.66 per cent.
