SPEECH.PARA: I turn now to the fourth misleading proposal the Government is putting forward, the referendum proposal regarding rights and freedoms, which are contained in the Constitution Alteration (Rights and Freedoms) Bill. Senators enter this debate having recently emerged from the debate on the Bill of Rights. Clear public disinclination was demonstrated during that debate to going down the track of handing to Australian judges the sort of power that has been given to judges in the United States to make broad political and social judgments on the basis of very broad statements of principle. I believe one basis for opposition to this proposal is that we do not want to see its being used as the thin end of the wedge towards a Bill of Rights in the Australian Constitution.

I believe it is important to remain suspicious when handing decisions over to unelected judges. One of the interesting elements of preparing for this debate has been to go over some of the decisions of the courts where they have tried to deal with those parts of the Constitution which touch on questions of civil rights, whether it is a matter of freedom of religion or the right to compensation when one's property is taken by Government. I have already quoted what was said by Justices Dixon and Evatt, who were concerned about the operation of section 80, which is the so-called guarantee of trial by jury. They said:
We admit the difficulties, which the form of sec. 80 creates, but to treat such a constitutional provision as producing no substantial effect seems rather to defeat than to ascertain its intention.

The reality is that the judges of the High Court have been severely split in the interpretation of that. Judges always have widely differing opinions on judgments of this sort. Nothing can be found in the precedents in terms of High Court consideration of existing so-called guarantees that would lead one to believe that its consideration of these matters is superior to that of democratic politicians. The experience of the United States and its Bill of Rights shows where it leads. The Brown case in the 1950s started the move towards school integration. The Supreme Court found that a doctrine of the separate provision of equal facilities was not equal treatment under the law, and that represented a substantial reversal of previous judicial appointments.

The reality is that what the judges think at any time about what these broad guarantees mean will change according to changes in the judges and changes in community values. One cannot look at the United States experience with respect to the bussing of black students to try to achieve that equality of education. If one looks at the United States arrangements with respect to electoral redistribution under the Bill of Rights, one cannot escape the inevitable conclusion that it has forced the United States Supreme Court to engage in what are effectively legislative and quasi executive roles. In other words, the courts have ceased to be courts as we understand them and have become a body forced to legislate to cover the complexities of the judgments required under the Bill of Rights. We see that in the field of abortion; we see it in the field of equal treatment before the law; we see it with the Supreme Court trying to balance up the judgments as to whether a positive discrimination in favour of a student from a minority group amounts to a discrimination against the white student who is denied admission to a medical school in California. These are matters of value judgments which, in the end, under our system, are better dealt with in the Parliament than in the courts.

I wish simply to affirm the concern of the Opposition at any Bill of Rights style of approach to the maintenance of human rights in this country, and to refer briefly to comments, one by the current Director of Public Prosecutions, Mr Temby, who, writing in the Australian Law Journal in 1984 on the past approaches of the High Court of Australia to the interpretation of section 92 of the Constitution, referred to the oscillation of the High Court. He said that the fact that the earlier decision `could be reversed serves to indicate how tortuous the path of judicial interpretation has been'. There are plenty of other authorities that I could go to, but time does not permit me to do so, to show this total lack of consistency of judicial interpretation which we have had with respect to the Australian Constitution, and the danger therefore of seeing that as the fundamental way of defending human rights.

But to look at the question of trial by jury, for example, the simple condemnation that can be made of what the Government is putting forward is that the Government has written into this proposal the way around it. The reality is that this proposal with respect to trial by jury provides specifically that it does not affect the operation of a law which permits waiver by the accused of trial by jury, which regulates the size of composition of the jury or provides for majority verdicts. In other words, within the Government's own proposal it has left room for endless variation on what form of jury we shall have and what a jury decision really means. What is quite clear from the authorities in this area is that the extent to which that will provide any guarantee is totally unpredictable. For example, will the court hold that a jury of three is a jury? Will it hold that a majority decision of seven to five is a jury decision? They are the sorts of questions which are completely left at large under this proposal.

With respect to the issue of freedom of religion, I would ask the Senate and the people of Australia to look at the difference between what is now proposed by the Government and what is already in place in the Constitution. The present Constitution provides in section 116:
The Commonwealth shall not make any law for establishing any religion . . .

It goes on in terms which are in common with the proposal that the Government now puts before us. What the Government is now saying is that the Commonwealth, a State or a Territory shall not establish any religion, impose any religious observance or so on. The taking out of the words `shall not make any law' potentially widens the application of this provision in a way which I think many people in Australia would find objectionable. For example, who is to say that the High Court would not hold, now that the reference to legislation has been removed, that the saying of the Lord's Prayer in this chamber should not be struck down under this new provision? Who would not say that prayer in a public school should not be struck down? The Minister at the table, the Minister for Home Affairs (Senator Robert Ray), laughs. Is he prepared to ignore the extraordinary interpretations of the American Supreme Court?

TALK.START.PARA: —You are desperate. I was not going to interject.

—The Minister says that is desperate. I simply draw the Minister's attention to the very wide interpretation which has been put on the United States guarantee under the Bill of Rights. I suggest to you, Mr Acting Deputy President, that there is no guarantee that the High Court will not interpret this sort of provision in the way I have indicated.

SPEECH.PARA: As far as the proposal that we should extend the just terms provisions to the States is concerned, I simply wish to say this: The only pressure that I have heard of politically for the extension of this constitutional guarantee came from the State of New South Wales. That came because the Wran Government took the coal rights of private landowners without compensation. That gave rise to a justifiable political outrage in that State and to the demand by people that there should be an extension of this constitutional guarantee. I simply wish to say with respect to that, that the people of New South Wales remedied that deficiency in a proper democratic way just a month or two ago when they threw out the Labor Government. The present Greiner Government has indicated that it will now remedy the theft of those coal rights from the citizens of New South Wales. That is the proper political remedy which is available to people in the States if there is an abuse of the usual principle that there should be compensation when property is taken.

The only other point I wish to make about that is to raise on behalf of the Northern Territory Government its concern at what is proposed by the Government in this area, because it says that the form of the Bill amounts to a discrimination against the Northern Territory because the constitutional guarantee applies only to property being taken from individuals in the Northern Territory and not from the Government of the Northern Territory. So there is, at the governmental level, deep concern on the part of the Northern Territory Government that what is proposed by the Government in this amendment is not fair to the Northern Territory and should not therefore be supported.

In the few minutes which remain I wish to refer to the proposals which are being put forward by the Australian Democrats in their Bill, the Constitution Alteration (Electors' Initiative) Bill. The view of the Opposition is that that proposal is one which is not yet ripe for public consideration in the form of a referendum. The Opposition announced at the time of the last election that it believed that this proposal warranted serious consideration, and we have in a number of ways been promoting discussion in the Australian community on the proposal that the electors of Australia should have, as they have in Switzerland and in some States of the United States, the right to initiate law making and to carry out law making without the intervention of this Parliament.

The Opposition released a Green Paper on voter initiated laws on 15 April 1988. It is a bulky document, so I do not seek leave to have it incorporated in Hansard, but I do seek leave to table that document, as an indication of the wide range of issues which the Opposition believes need to be considered before the people of Australia come to a final conclusion on whether they want to make this quite sharp change from the constitutional practices which have previously applied. The paper makes it quite clear that there are many detailed matters which need consideration-whether constitutional amendments should be concluded; whether proposals should cover only one subject, for example; what number of signatures should be required, should it be 5 per cent or more or less; should the signatures be obtained from more than one State; should there be a time limit on the obtaining of the signatures; should there be the involvement of the Parliament in the terms of a committee examination of any proposal so that it can be put in legislative form; should the Parliament have the right to put in an alternative proposal for consideration in the referendum; what should be the funding and campaigning expenditure disclosure requirements; what should be the majorities; should they involve States as well as the nation; should there be a limitation on the resubmission of proposals; should there be any power for the Parliament to repeal, and if so on what basis; what are the roles of the courts with respect to this process; and so on.

All of these matters in our view need to be substantially canvassed, because we believe that, just as the Constitutional Commission found that there was in the Australian community an imperfect understanding of the constitutional proposals for an Aboriginal treaty, for example, and that that matter should be put aside to enable further debate and discussion, I would put the view on behalf of the Opposition that the voter initiated proposal, whilst of great interest and potentially of value to us, is one which needs far greater public debate before it is embraced by this Parliament.

I conclude by saying that the Opposition will campaign very fiercely against the four proposals which are being put forward by the Government. We see them as proposals which will further centralise power, increase the power of the Prime Minister and, most importantly, destroy the operation of the Senate. We oppose the Bills, and we will fight against them.

He could have said that, on a variety of spurious grounds, the Opposition was going to oppose these referendum proposals on the ground of expediency. SPEECH.PARA: Today I am going to address only two of the referendum proposals. I will leave it to my colleagues to deal with local government and putting into the Constitution States rights. The first Bill that concerns us as parliamentarians is the suggestion of having four-year terms. The arguments for having four-year terms have been around for many years. Indeed, I think they were around at the turn of the century.

TALK.START.PARA: —You have never served a full term since you have been in government.

—Since Federation we have had 38 Federal elections; that is an election on average every 2.3 years. As Senator Boswell would say no doubt by interjection, no person in this chamber has served a six-year term. In fact, Senator McClelland, when he left us, was the last person to have served six years. From 1946 to 1987-in the last 43 years-we have had 22 Federal elections, which means that we are averaging government terms of less than two years. In addition, we have State elections at any given time. One of the public's arguments is that we are having too many elections. It seems to the public that every year we have an election of some sort. Let me take New South Wales as an example. Since 1960, 28 years ago, the voters in New South Wales-our largest State-have had the absence of an election, State or Federal, in only four years. In only 1979, 1982, 1985 and 1986 have they not had a Federal or State election.

SPEECH.PARA: The situation is similar in other States. It has been overcome somewhat by the movement of other States to four-year terms. Gradually we have seen a variety of States move to four-year terms-New South Wales, Victoria and South Australia. The two exceptions to that at the moment-although I have no doubt that they may even be giving it sympathetic consideration-are Queensland and Western Australia. We should note also that New South Wales, Victoria and South Australia not only have four-year terms but also have simultaneous terms for both Houses. Generally with the support of the coalition parties in this country they have moved to simultaneous terms. In Victoria there is a provision that one cannot take the Legislative Council out in the first three years. That is a variation, if you like, on that theme. But once the Legislative Council in Victoria has served three years the terms become simultaneous and simultaneous elections can be held. That has been supported by conservatives. I wonder why it is not reciprocated at a Federal level. The Northern Territory, the other remaining legislature, also has a four-year term.

In none of those legislatures can it be argued that democracy has been endangered by a four-year term. Of all the major Western democracies four- and five-year terms are the norm. We, along with New Zealand, have brothers or sisters in arms, if you like, only in the case of Mexico and Sweden, which have three-year terms. So, not only do we see four-year terms in a majority of States, but also in other comparative democracies around the world their parliamentary terms are generally four or five years. Only in two cases are they three-year terms.

The Government has been accused of not being bipartisan enough on these subjects. Written into the Australian Labor Party platform is a desire, not only for four-year terms, but also for four-year fixed terms. Very early we picked up the vibe from the Liberal Party of Australia, and from other debates, that it would not support four-year fixed terms. So we have already taken a step on the way towards bipartisanship by eliminating the fixed element, because it re-started the whole debate about Supply and everything else which the Opposition did not want considered a referendum proposal. So we went some of the way by removing the fixed element, hoping to get some sort of support. It might be very satisfying to Opposition parties and to the media for us to be continually in an election mode. It might be exciting for the Press. It might be encouraging for the Opposition. But it is not necessarily good for the country. That argument has been expounded by a whole range of people.

The various public opinion surveys generally show that people are in favour of four-year terms. Quite often the types of questions they are asked would explain the variations in the polls, but in general there has been support for four-year terms. Many groups in business and commerce have been strong in their support of four-year terms. Even the Business Council of Australia, albeit having a different view on the Senate term, has been strongly in favour of four-year terms. The Australian Council of Trade Unions has been strong in its support for four-year terms. The basic reason for that is that those groups recognise that the need in this country for stable planning and implementation of government policies is absolutely critical. Oppositions tend not to regard that as a national priority. Four-year terms give a government a much better chance to introduce an economic regime and to see whether it will work. Having elections every three years, whilst it does not totally contradict that, is an impediment of it. I would have thought that it was recognised by most honourable senators that that is one of the strongest arguments in favour of a four-year term. All I can say is that the Opposition, by its opposition to this proposal, is showing contempt for economic management in this country.

I should go to the reasons, professed not only by Senator Chaney when he actually got onto the referendums-which was rare-but also by other Liberals in another place and in their public statements for their objection to four-year terms as presented in this referendum. It really has two legs to it, although there are some other peripheral arguments, which I will deal with later. The Opposition opposes simultaneous terms and basically wants double, or fixed, eight-year terms for the Senate. In all my reading on this subject, though, I cannot establish whether the Opposition is arguing for double the terms of the House of Representatives or for a fixed eight-year term. The Opposition has been very clever in not spelling that out. I hope that in these debates some Opposition members get up and tell us whether they want eight-year fixed terms or double House of Representatives terms when it comes to four-year terms.

To demonstrate the absolute hypocrisy of the Opposition on this subject, let us go to the record of what Opposition members have had to say on the question of simultaneous elections. Speaking in the House of Representatives in 1977, the then Deputy Leader of the National Party of Australia, Mr Sinclair-he is now the Leader of the National Party; is he still the Leader?-said:
But more significantly I believe that there will be fewer elections and therefore whichever party may be in government will have a proper opportunity to govern and carry out its proper duties.
That is what Mr Sinclair said on simultaneous terms. Introducing the Bill into this chamber Senator Durack, as the responsible Minister, said:

Apart from the benefits of public convenience and savings of expenditure the proposal will benefit the Parliament by ensuring that the people's will is reflected simultaneously in both Houses, it will provide a more satisfactory electoral basis upon which the government of the country can proceed.

So one of the relevant Ministers, when the Opposition was in government, endorsed simultaneous elections. We then had one of the junior woodchucks of the then Ministry-Senator Chaney-get up. He said something very prophetic. He was criticised for inconsistency. In 1974 the Liberal Party opposed simultaneous terms, but in 1977 it put them to the people. Senator Chaney said:
If we all are to be men of absolute consistency it seems to me that we will never make progress with constitutional change and reform.

What prophetic words. No one these days can accuse Senator Chaney of consistency. He opposed simultaneous elections in 1974. He supported them in 1977. He is opposing them in 1988. If he ever gets into government, he will again support them. There is no doubt about that whatsoever. Senator Chaney then went on to expound the virtues of simultaneous elections. He said:
There is no real dispute in this chamber about the fact that we should have fewer elections in Australia.
That is the very point we make today. He then said:
It is common knowledge that Senate elections-
meaning separate Senate elections-
such as have been held since the early 1960s in Australia are held in a by-election atmosphere, and in that situation they do not genuinely reflect the wish of the people as to who should govern.
Listening to Senator Chaney's comments earlier today, I thought how history tends to haunt us. Finally, given the Chaney line today, this is the classic Chaney quotation:
Why is it that suddenly the concept of bringing the elections together will destroy this chamber? I do not believe that it will.

We have had the great recantation today. The statements of 1977, when Senator Chaney was in government looking after his own self-interests, no longer apply because he has different priorities today. Any sleazy method adopted by the coalition to get it back into government is worth more than constitutional principle and consistency. It is there on the record; the honourable senator is condemned by it.

What is wrong with simultaneous terms? Why do we have simultaneous terms in this legislation? Most times it is not simply a three-year period, as my friend Senator Boswell has pointed out, that will cause a government to go to an early election; it is the lack of simultaneous terms. The reason for it is that when we have double dissolutions the terms are backdated. I do not blame or condemn Malcolm Fraser for going to an early election late in 1977. He could not afford to have a half Senate election by itself and neither could Bob Hawke go to a separate Senate election in 1984. Why? As Senator Chaney has already indicated, it is a by-election atmosphere.

In terms of the fortunes of any major political party, let us look as the last occasion we had a half Senate election. In 1970 we went to a half Senate election, and what a joy it was. I am sure that Senator Lewis, who is in the chamber, was involved in it. We all turned up to hear our party leaders deliver their speeches and we could have let off a shotgun in the hall and not hit anyone. The results then flowed in, the Democratic Labor Party polling 19 per cent of the vote, with Senator Little getting up in Victoria, Senator Kane in New South Wales and Senator Condon Byrne in Queensland. We then had the great spectacle of Senator Negus getting up in Western Australia and Senator Townley, a renegade Liberal, getting up in Tasmania. It is an absolute bonanza for almost the ratbag candidates of the world. They have their rights and I am not about to step on them. But no government and no real opposition either-because oppositions get hurt just as badly as other parties-want a separate Senate election again. I might also say that in South Australia the better education group got 10 per cent of the vote and, by a fluke, missed out on the final quota. So we just do not have the political will in the Australian Labor Party and the coalition parties to have separate Senate elections any more. We just do not have them. By not having them and by not having a provision for simultaneous elections, time and again we will lay down the groundwork for forced early elections.

Let us just look at the second leg and at the new argument that has emerged from the Opposition parties. They say, `We might be a bit nervous about simultaneous elections, but really this is an attack on the Senate chamber because you must have double terms or fixed eight-year terms'. Let me go back again to the record. I will not go back to 1977; I will go back to 1983 and I quote the attitudes of some of the luminaries of the Liberal Party of Australia, not only in the House of Representatives but also in this chamber, on eight-year terms. Let me go to one of the doyens of the Liberal Party, Mr Spender, who, in October 1983, said:
However, I wonder whether eight years might be a little excessive. It causes me some concern that a person could sit in the Senate for eight years growing old without having to face the electorate.
That is what Mr Spender had to say. Let us go to what Mr Newman, who was then in the House of Representatives, had to say:

I could not tolerate a senator having an eight-year term. That would make him almost completely independent of the electorate. It would give him such a continuity of service that we might as well put him on the Public Service payroll and be done with it. That continually would allow him not to be answerable to the electorate.

That is one of the greats of the Tasmanian Liberal Party speaking. Let us move on, though, to a more respected figure in the coalition. Senator Boswell should prick up his ears. Mr Doug Anthony from the National Party--

TALK.START.PARA: —A good man.
—A good man, I hear. Then will the honourable senator endorse this or will he betray him here today? Mr Anthony said:

SPEECH.PARA: I find it very hard to digest the proposal that we extend the term of the Senate from six to eight years. Eight years is a very long time indeed, and I think that in the course of the referendum campaign many questions will be asked by the Australian people as to whether an alteration to elect senators into a position free from accountability to the people for eight years is really warranted.
That is what Mr Anthony had to say about it. Let us go back to Tasmania and hear what Mr Hodgman had to say about it at the time. He said:

I have to say with the greatest respect to my colleagues in the Senate that I think an eight-year term is too long. The reaction I have noticed from the electors in discussions I have had about these proposals is very much to that effect.
He is backed up by Mr Burr who is not, I understand, a friend of Mr Hodgman-he is from the other wing of the Liberal Party in Tasmania. Mr Burr had this to say:

It must be recognised that there are problems in extending the terms of senators to eight years and denying the public the opportunity to give a judgment on the performance of those senators for eight years.

So there we have some of the leading lights of the Liberal Party in the House of Representatives saying that eight years is too long. But why leave it there? Why not start a journey into the Senate? Senator Lewis's turn is coming. In the Senate we had the then golden boy of the Liberal Party, Senator Hill, saying:
I must confess that I am not entirely happy with the prospect of eight years.
I interpolate here that I bet he would have voted for it. He continued:
That seems to me too long a term.

I have often said that, in the secrecy of the ballot box, we are always sure of 76 votes when we go for eight-year terms as senators. What did former Senator Withers have to say about an eight-year term for the Senate? He said:

Not much is said of course, about its great benefit to us. We are all going to do a little better. Good lord, if we get four-year terms in the other place and eight-year terms here it will be almost as good as being either a tenured academic or a tenured public servant-not quite.
That is what Senator Withers had to say about eight-year terms. We then come to Senator Lewis, a very respected figure in the Liberal Party, and I quote him:
To give senators a term of eight years causes me great concern. I would be totally opposed to it . . .

He then goes on and qualifies that by saying that for the price of getting four-year terms-I point this out to protect him-he would buy eight years. But, basically, he then expressed his opposition to it. I do not think any quotations can be finished unless we tour back to Tasmania, the home of constitutional reform, where Senator Archer said:

But there is no way that I can go along with the suggestion that an eight-year term for senators is reasonable. I think that any member of this chamber who tries to sell himself in the community and get support for an eight-year term will have a job in front of him.

There we have on the record Liberal Party support for simultaneous terms. Malcolm Fraser put it to the people in 1977. We must have been mugs, in opposition, to say, `out of bipartisanship we will support you' because it is never reciprocated by those opposite. When it comes to eight-year terms-I assume that is what members of the Opposition are arguing for-there is vacuum opposite. Honourable senators opposite will not say exactly what they think the Senate should do. Would they double the term of the House of Representatives? Would they have an eight-year term in the Senate? I have read about nine quotes from leaders of the Liberal Party and the National Party who said only five years ago, and this is on the record, that they oppose the concept of eight-year terms. I think the argument of the Opposition in that regard is just a red herring.

Let me move to the second proposal that I want to discuss today; that is, the question of the so-called fair election-one vote one value. In the report of the Joint Committee on Electoral Matters, which I commend to all honourable senators to read, a lot of emphasis has been put on the definitions of the words `malapportionment' and `gerrymander' but there is a difference of opinion between honourable senators on this side of the chamber and honourable senators on the other side of the chamber. Honourable senators on the other side of the chamber say, `You cannot ever control gerrymandering; therefore, you should never try to control malapportionment'. That seems to be the guts of some of their arguments. I point out, though, that malapportionment is also a tool of gerrymandering. We cannot make an absolute distinction between the two because when we use malapportionment with a rural bias it is really one arm, one weapon of the gerrymander in this country. Its effect will depend very much on the socioeconomic distribution in Australia. It may well be that a rural bias in Western Australia does not disadvantage the Labor Party. I think that basically that is true. In Queensland, especially with the use of a zonal system to isolate provincial seats, it is very much to the Labor Party's disadvantage and very much to the Liberal Party's disadvantage.

TALK.START.PARA: —Why did they bring it in?

—I have been asked a question by Senator Sheil: Why did the Labor Party bring it in in 1949? I have answered that before. The Labor Party was wrong to do that in 1949. I might ask why Senator Sheil's conservative predecessors in the seventeenth and eighteenth centuries condoned slavery. That has about as much relevance to the argument. Our record on fair elections, as I will demonstrate in a moment, has been fairly good in the last 20 years. I do not defend every Labor decision of the past. I do not defend Labor's decision to support the white Australia policy which existed until 1970. Senator Sheil should not introduce absolutely irrelevant issues into the debate.

SPEECH.PARA: I will make one final comment about gerrymandering. People ask: How does one confront the question of gerrymandering? There are two things that one can do. Firstly, by removing malapportionment one tends to lessen the scope of any potential gerrymanderer. That is incontrovertible. Secondly, the only other way is to appoint fair and independent commissioners. The Labor Party has done that in some of the States. People often chip at us, but basically that is the case. I have not heard the Opposition criticise some of the Supreme Court or Federal Court judges that we have used to that effect. Before it says that we are trying to gerrymander anything, it should look at the commissioners. If the commissioners are fair, gerrymanders will not exist. If they do exist, they exist by fluke and anyone can be on the wrong side of them.

Let me point to the 1982-85 redistribution in Victoria. That redistribution, initiated by a State Labor government, appointed an independent judge and independent commissioners. When the boundary lines were drawn, the Labor Party was far worse off. We did not complain; we had to cop it. If one picks independent commissioners, gerrymandering is a thing that disappears from the political scene. It is only when one writes into the legislation, as is the case in Queensland, that specific areas such as the Wudja Wudja area, which has no contiguous boundaries with the electorate of Cook, will be placed in the electorate of Cook, that the accusation of gerrymandering can have some foundation.

Let us look at the history of malapportionment in Australia. The Federal Parliament has had by far the fairest set of boundaries in the history of Australia. The Commonwealth Electoral Act initially allowed a 20 per cent tolerance and not much direction to the commissioners. There was no mandatory enforcement of 20 per cent at any one time. In other words, when the commissioners started the redistribution they would use 20 per cent as their limit, but the boundaries could then blow out. It was up to government to initiate the next redistribution.

I joined the Labor Party in 1966. That was my first election campaign. I remember what the boundaries were like then. There were 30,000 in one electorate and 140,000 in another. There were 140,000 in the electorate of Lalor, 120,000 in the electorate of Bruce, 30,000 in Darebin and 30,000 in Melbourne. This occurred because not enough attention was given to the electoral laws. In 1975 we had entrenched in Federal electoral law a 10 per cent differential. That took a lot of doing. It took a double dissolution and a joint sitting; nevertheless, that 10 per cent differential was achieved. What did honourable senators opposite do when they regained power? Did they agree with the 10 per cent rule? Did they try to pervert it? Of course they did. Under pressure from the National Party of Australia they introduced the 5,000 square kilometres provision whereby no electorate greater in size than 5,000 square kilometres could have more electors in it than those electorates below that size. They had to fiddle at the edges again. They had to give a little sop to National Party members to keep them on side, but not enough to increase the number of National Party members; otherwise they would demand more Cabinet and ministerial positions. The attitude was, `Feed them a little and they won't get too hungry'.

We came to power in 1983. The Joint Select Committee on Electoral Reform looked at the question of electoral redistributions. We introduced in this country the fairest electoral laws in its history-mostly by agreement, I would concede. It meant having independent commissioners and a 10 per cent variation above or below, on average, with growth as the major criterion-not a country bias, physical features, or anything else. That meant that in the 1984 election there was not one seat that was 10 per cent above or below the average. By 1987 there was only a seat that was out of kilter, which was a record for Australia. It was a fast growing area on the Gold Coast. There was only one seat that was outside the State average by 10 per cent either way. That is an achievement that any Labor government can be proud of.

The Joint Select Committee on Electoral Reform produced, on page 42 of its report, a variety of figures and tables to make those points. TALK.START.PARA: —Sometimes it is said, `Let's leave it to the States. It will be fixed up over time'. I say in that regard that nearly all the reforms to do away with malapportionment have come from the Labor side of politics. The one exception occurred in South Australia from 1968 to 1970, but even then one vote one value was not achieved. There was a severe lessening of the rural bias-not its elimination, but a lessening of that bias-by Mr Steele Hall. I believe in that his motives were twofold: firstly, he believed in one vote one value; and, secondly, he realised that his only chance of being re-elected at the next election was to remove that running sore from the electoral system.

SPEECH.PARA: Let us look at the other States. The Bolte Government and Liberal governments generally were in power in Victoria from 1955 to 1982. They set up a zonal system. Did they ever consider one vote one value and fair elections? Not once did they contemplate that. The Cain Government, which was elected in 1982, introduced a 10 per cent variation above or below and independent commissioners. South Australia finally got one vote one value under the Dunstan Government. New South Wales finally got rid of the zonal system under the Wran Government which introduced a 10 per cent variation. The final example of a Labor government is in Western Australia. It introduced reform Bill after reform Bill in an attempt to fix the malapportionment in Western Australia. Every reform Bill but the last foundered in the upper House, where the Liberal and National parties had a majority. They foundered because of an intractable conservative Opposition. In the end we had to compromise in that State and had to cut our electoral reform measures to pieces just to improve the position. That improved position is by no means perfect. One must ask oneself: Why does this situation exist? Why does the Commonwealth have to motivate itself to intervene and impose laws on the States? It does not find any joy in doing so. The real reason lies with the conservative parties of Australia, the Liberals and Nationals, not wanting to contribute at the local level.

I heard Senator Chaney say today that he has always been a convinced supporter, virtually, of one vote one value. All I can say is that he does not have much influence. If he supports the principle it may be, as Lenin said, as the hangman's rope supports the hanged. I do not know how he supports it, but let us assume that he does. He cannot have had much influence over his Western Australian colleagues to bring that about. He cannot be a great educator. He cannot be a great numbers man in the Western Australian branch. He has obviously not been able to draw them across. If the Liberal Party in Western Australia had put its numbers behind the reform Bill in the Legislative Council there would have been equality of voting in Western Australia. I know that until recently another group of Liberals has been dominant in Western Australia. Therefore, one can understand Senator Chaney's impotence in dealing with that matter. But I would have thought that things had changed over there recently; maybe the newspaper reports are wrong. It seems to me that it has always been in the hands of the Western Australian Liberal Party to solve these matters. It has never availed itself of the opportunity.

Again, I remind the Senate of Senator Chaney's great quote on an Australian Broadcasting Corporation program on 17 May, at 7 o'clock, when he said: `Were I a member of the Queensland Liberal Party, I would be arguing very hard with them for a State electoral system that was fairer'. Obviously, Senator Chaney would be regarded these days as a man of principle only if he was born in Queensland. While we are on the subject of Queensland, I will not press the point. Everyone in the country knows how bad the Queensland redistribution systems are. They are based on zones and loadings. There are 8,000 in one electorate and 24,000 in another. Every justification for that system I have heard put up by the National Party of Queensland basically has fallen down. We hear the stupid argument: `Oh, but the people are a long way from the city'. Some of the smallest seats are 100 kilometres away from the centre of Brisbane and some which are more than 2,000 kilometres away--

TALK.START.PARA: —Which one?

—Like Mount Isa, are much bigger. It is not distance from Brisbane which counts; it is where the National Party votes are concentrated. Why do the Nationals need that system? Senator Sheil appears to have told Senator Boswell. They need it because the National Party can win in Queensland only when the cards are stacked, when the electorates are rigged. The Queensland rorted system is basically not about keeping Labor out of office, that is the great irony of it, it is about keeping the Liberals as the junior coalition members and wiping them out so there would be no Liberal Premier of Queensland. The Australian Labor Party is disadvantaged by the boundaries in Queensland, but not catastrophically so. The whole system was to dud the Liberal Party because the National Party cannot hack it on an even playing field. There is no way National Party members can hack it without stacking the deck in Queensland.
—They cannot fight fair.

—As Senator Maguire said, no way can they fight fair. But I have to say that at least one can understand the National Party's attitude in Queensland: it has got power and it is going to hold power; it does not care how. I have never been able to understand the Queensland Liberal Party's attitude, which historically was to go along with this system. It had many offers from the Labor Party to form a minority Liberal government to rectify it. It refused. Its attitude in Queensland was the most craven attitude of any political party in this country's history. It is woeful. It is to be condemned. It is only now, in 1988, that a Liberal leader in Queensland, Mr Innes, has finally woken up. He has said that he wants these referendum proposals up because it is the only way people in Queensland will get fair electoral boundaries. It has taken a long time of servitude. It has taken a yellow-bellied attitude by Liberal leader after Liberal leader in Queensland to evaporate, but it has. Now that it has, I congratulate the current Liberal leader for doing so. I think to do any less would be to betray some of the principles that we support. Mr Innes has been ready to do that; apparently no Federal Liberal is willing to join him in that way.

SPEECH.PARA: We must ask ourselves why the Liberals will not at least support their Queensland colleague. The answer is that they have one overriding principle at the moment and that is unity at all costs. After the events of 1987 they decided that they never wanted them repeated; they must go in future for the lowest common denominator at all times. That and that alone is the way they see electoral success in the future. They cannot have feuds between the National and Liberal parties breaking out again. The Liberal Party paid the price of this attitude before. McMahon paid the price in 1971 over devaluation. The Liberal Party paid the price in 1967 when it let the then Country Party veto the Liberal choice of leadership. Again, what we have seen in the last few weeks in Canberra is the National Party wagging the coalition's tail to such an extent that the Liberal leadership has been rolled more often in recent weeks than the Brisbane Broncos. Time and time again we have seen the Liberal leadership troop into their party room and have to give in under pressure from the National Party, leading people to ask who is actually leading the Liberal Party, does it have a leader or, as someone pointed out to me today, is it just a case of mistaken nonentity in terms of Mr Howard. We wonder who is leading the Liberals.

Leaving those arguments aside, one has to track down some of the other red herrings from the Liberal Party. Of course we knew we would cop the old States rights argument which has fronted up again. When the Liberals are bankrupt of ideas they trot out the States rights argument time and time again. It really has no validity in this case. The Constitution, the original compact, dealt with States rights but also put in a provision for changing the Federal Constitution in terms of States rights. There is a big hurdle in the Constitution in that not only a majority of votes but also a majority in a majority of the States is required for a change to the Constitution. That was part of States rights. That is what will be put to the people in September for them to make a judgment on it. We have not heard, but I know we will, the other hoary old chestnut of the Senate being a States House. I should run a tontine or a raffle as to which conservative will first raise this issue of the Senate being the States House. This is not a States House; it virtually never was. There may be some examples in the first decade of this century when States rights could have appeared to have some influence over some votes before party structure developed, but once the party structure developed in this place anyone saying that this was a States House was basically involved in an exercise in hypocrisy.

We have also not yet heard about the cost of the referendum. But no doubt that will come up. I point out that after holding three Federal elections we will recoup the cost of this referendum by having fewer elections in that period. We have heard of the great red herring of the cost of the Constitutional Commission. We are doing most things consistent with what the Commission recommended. We are not saying that these are the only referendums that will ever be put up; the other basic issues the Commission raised will also need consideration. I want to deal with one other issue in terms of the Labor Party's attitude. It has taken a long-term attitude on these questions. We are giving up some short term rights, as even Malcolm Mackerras was generous enough to acknowledge on radio the other day. We are basically giving up our right to an early election by putting up this proposition, if it is carried, because our argument for an early election will always be based on not having a separate Senate election. If we were to be minded to go to an early election we would now have to pay the political price: we would not have the excuse. Secondly, in terms of the rotation of senators, we are well placed at the next half Senate election. We have only three senators coming out in one State. My only doubt about these referendums is not that they will weaken the Senate's power but that they will potentially increase it. That is why I reject the thrust of Senator Chaney's comments today. I believe that by having a simultaneous election, virtually a double dissolution, every four years we may be doing too much to entrench the power of the Senate rather than weaken it.

TALK.START.PARA: —Well, you will never get control of it again.

—That is the key to it, because if I were so minded and were a Senate chauvinist and wanted to defend the rights of the Senate I would be arguing for a double dissolution every time and not for the potential for one party to get control. For all the glossy words I have heard today from Senator Chaney about the rights of this chamber and its future, et cetera, once a political party gets a majority in this Senate all those principles slide out the back door. I heard Senator Chaney say that there are no principles in the other chamber. I wonder why the members there were sitting until one o'clock every morning last week in order to give debating time to these matters. If they had been as ruthless as Senator Chaney alleges, they would have had a guillotine gag on and been home by 10.30 every night last week. So I do not accept the argument that it will necessarily weaken the power of the Senate. I have some concern that if the referendums are carried they may increase the power of the Senate.

SPEECH.PARA: The general argument will be brought up, probably even on my side, that these are referendum proposals and we should let the people decide. I reject that. I do not believe every referendum proposal that comes up here should be put to the people. I believe this chamber and the other chamber should have the right to make the decision as to what they regard as right and proper to be put at referendums. So I do not get up here today and say, `Let the people decide'. We are empowered and that is why we have to legislate to put a referendum before it is decided by the people.

The final point I want to sum up on is that we have attempted to put eminently fair referendum proposals forward. The Opposition has opposed them because it has to look after its lowest common denominator; that is, the National Party. It cannot afford the risk of divisions, of campaigning against each other. That was burnt into its psyche in 1987. The conclusion that the Australian people will draw from that is that if Opposition members are not willing to show some intestinal fortitude they are not entitled to come back into government. That is the price those opposite are going to pay for their papered-up unity. That is a terrible price, when we think about it. If they wonder why they have got such a bad reception in the Press on their attitude to the referendums, it is because most people have seen through their strategy.

People know that the Liberal Party and the National Party are going to go around dredging up all the distracting issues to try to distract the electors on these matters. I believe that this set of referendums will, if carried-and I do not proclaim that there is any certainty about it at the polls-make for a better and more democratic society. They deserve to be supported-and I hope they are. If they are not supported, the Labor Party will not stop pursuing such principles as four-year terms and one vote one value. We will continue to expound them and one day, I assure honourable senators, we will win.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Macklin Sen M.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —I wish first in this debate, which is dealing with five Constitution Alteration Bills, four proposed by the Government and one by the Australian Democrats, to refer to my Party's attitude to votes on referenda Bills before the Senate. Unlike the attitude of Senator Robert Ray, our attitude is that a proposal coming before this chamber, which is put by a senator whether from the Government or as a representative of another political party, who has taken the time and trouble to work out proposals to alter the Constitution, ought to go to the people as a matter of course.

SPEECH.PARA: We believe very strongly-and one of the functions of the Constitution Alteration (Electors' Initiative) Bill 1987 that is in this package includes this type of approach-that this Constitution is controlled by the people of this country and it is only the people of Australia who are permitted to change the Constitution. Essentially, what we are about here is to process these Bills so that they may go to the people for their deliberation and vote. We are merely engaged in the preliminary step of providing to the people a series of Bills upon which they may vote. Hence, with regard to the Government's proposals when they were announced, I was able to say on behalf of my Party that in distinction to the way we treat normal legislation, we would be able to support those proposals-before we had seen the legislation. We support those proposals going to the people. Indeed, we have supported previous proposals going to the people for their vote and then engaged in a campaign in the community to convince people that they should not cast their vote in favour of the proposals. I do not think that that is a stance that is too difficult for honourable senators here to understand. It is certainly not too complicated for the people to understand, because on every occasion that I have put that idea forward at a public meeting, it has been accepted by the people because they realise that it is their Constitution, not the Constitution of politicians.

The Constitution Alteration (Parliamentary Terms) Bill 1988 essentially moves the maximum term of the House of Representatives from three to four years and thereby reduces the Senate term from a maximum of six years to four years. As every speaker in this debate so far has pointed out, senators rarely have a six-year term. I understand that the last person to have it was the previous President of the Senate, who managed to get up a six-year term-and he had to be here for 25 years to manage it.

Essentially we are not talking about a reduction of the Senate term because senators do not get those types of terms. That is why the proposal to come forward from the Opposition seems to me extraordinary, that it would be willing to support these types of changes provided there were an eight-year term. Senator Ray, by quoting previous Opposition statements, has shown that the Opposition is not putting up that proposal with any seriousness or consistency. It is just another flurry of arms in an attempt to give itself the semblance of some type of principled stance. On this matter, as has been amply demonstrated by almost every political commentator and newspaper editorial, what the Opposition is doing is taking a short term political stance which has to do with today's politics and not to do with long term constitutional propriety.

It is an extraordinary proposition that the Opposition parties will oppose any and every proposition for reform. There was an extraordinary exercise last week when, in an attempt to run yet another furphy over this exercise, those opposite were talking about the possibility of extending the Government's life. Of course, it does not extend the House of Representatives term in any shape or form! If they had bothered to read the second reading speech on this Bill or the explanatory memorandum, they would have found out what the situation is. However, they needed their friend outside to inform them. Presumably he read the second reading speech and with brilliant deduction worked out what the second reading speech said in very clear terms.

But that is not the point I wish to raise at this time. The point is that if there had been any substance to the matter, it would have been nice to be able to go to the High Court of Australia to get an advisory opinion. But the last time we attempted to ask for an advisory opinion on a constitutional change, the Opposition campaigned against it. The Opposition campaigned against a very proper and reasonable situation which would have helped us mightily in that context. So those opposite managed quite delicately to hoist themselves on their own petard-on which they are now squirming.

Senator Chaney's arguments on this proposition did not seem to have a great deal of substance although, if we had given him another hour, he probably could have worked himself up a few more. But from what I was able to write down, these were his arguments: First, that rotation somehow or other managed to provide stability. That is an extraordinary proposition when we think about it, particularly since the second session of this chamber-that is, the chamber constituted out of the second election-was constituted as a party House with the Australian Labor Party having the balance of power. So we look forward to the day when somebody will be able to say the same thing about us. From that time onwards, decisions in this place have been made, by and large, along party lines. I find that unfortunate; but it is the circumstance.

Let us go back to the last election, to look at the notion of stability and see what happened. The House of Representatives had more stability than did the Senate in the last election. Fewer members of the House of Representatives lost their seats than those in the Senate. But I did not understand the House of Representatives to have any rotation. Indeed, I do not think it was the case. Senator Tate now assures me that it is not the case. But somehow stability has been linked with rotation. What happened here in the Senate? Every sitting senator was re-endorsed by his Party, with the sole exception of a Labor Party senator from New South Wales who was re-elected to this chamber. What provides stability in the House of Representatives? The political parties' renominating process provides stability, not the rotation of senators. But the argument is based on an even flimsier ground because the idea of stability can shift with one seat in this chamber and one seat in the House of Representatives.

We all remember well the election where the Labor Party, having gained a majority of votes in the House of Representatives, was still one seat short of a majority, the seat of Moreton, which was eventually won on Communist Party second preferences going to the Liberal Party and electing Jim Killen at the time. That was an interesting situation because, if that single seat had gone the other way, the political composition of the Government would have changed completely. The same can happen here. With a change of a couple of seats, a government could get a majority in this place. That is the extraordinary situation. Again, it has nothing to do with rotation; it has everything to do with the political parties. I think that particular argument is one which we will probably not hear very much of again except when the Government wishes to go out and raise insubstantial ghosts in the electorate.

On this particular issue, there seems to be a lot of arm waving to claim that it takes away Senate power. When we get to the committee stage, I look forward with great delight to alighting upon the clause of the Bill which takes away the Senate power. It will be very interesting when that clause is drawn out and flourished to public view. The fact of the matter is that no clauses take away Senate power. Indeed, one could very well argue, as Senator Robert Ray has already done, that some quite substantial arguments may be mounted to suggest that the Senate power could end up being enhanced.

What is this power of the Senate to which Senator Chaney referred before? He painted an excessively glowing picture of this chamber under the Fraser Government, saying how it was so independent. Quite frankly that is a matter of record and the record stands very clearly. This was not an independent chamber; it was a chamber controlled by a political party. If honourable senators look at some of the votes that were taken in this chamber after the 1980 election and before the changing composition in 1981 when the Australian Democrats gained the balance of power, they will see how the Senate was treated as a party chamber. Bill after Bill was pushed through this place because the Government knew it was about to lose control of the chamber.

Control of the chamber is what matters. Anybody in politics who can add up knows that the numbers count at the end of the day. This chamber engages in a number of activities in its consideration of legislation. It scrutinises Bills. Bills go through the committee stage and we look at clause after clause. Those functions would not occur if the Labor Party controlled this chamber. Of course, we would not have that type of scrutiny if that were the case. The Minister for Justice (Senator Tate) knows that we would not have that type of scrutiny. Senator Chaney knows that too. That type of scrutiny is here because the Government does not control this chamber.

The people have made sure in the last four elections that the government of the day, whether it be the conservative government of the day or the Labor government of the day, did not control this chamber. That state of affairs is mightily frustrating to the government of the day. It was so frustrating to the last Liberal Government that it had to dash off to the people on a concocted proposition because it said at that time that it could not govern. What did it want? It wanted to impose taxes on food, clothing, footwear and building materials. So we had to go to the people.

What happened on the second day of that campaign? I would like to remind Senator Chaney of it because he has probably forgotten. On the second day the then Prime Minister of this country, Mr Malcolm Fraser, went on talkback radio and mightily embarrassed the Governor-General by saying that he had no intention-absolutely none-of reintroducing the Bill. A couple of days previously he had gone to the Governor-General and said that he could not run this country because he did not have the passage of this Bill. But we know what is the type of exercise that goes on when the government runs this chamber. The reason this chamber operates differently from the House of Representatives is that it does not have a government majority.

It does not really matter, except in one instance, how the Senate majority is made up, provided the government is not in the majority. That instance is when the major opposition party of the day in the House of Representatives has a majority in this place. We know what would happen under those circumstances: we would return to the situation in 1975 when this place could not work. That is what we would have if the opposition party had the majority in this chamber.

What do we get down to? The only way this chamber will ever remain as a chamber independent of the government and be a chamber of scrutiny of legislation is if parties such as my own hold the balance of power here. To say that is not necessarily to blow our trumpet. That points to the facts of the matter. The Opposition and the Government know that. No political party in control of the other place and in control of this place would allow the type of scrutiny that currently goes on here to continue. Everybody knows that and yet Senator Chaney wishes to run some other type of furphy around with regard to that matter.

I noted Senator Chaney's quotations. I thought it was interesting that we did not have quotes from the media. We did not have quotes from a variety of editorials. Why did we not have these quotes? Why do we have the Opposition's hired hand outside extensively quoted? He is not a media person but is presumably trying to generate a profile for himself whereby he might be able to earn some more money, or whatever is the reason. Why did we not have these quotes? The editors, feature writers et al are scratching their heads as to what the Opposition is engaged in. We had an interesting example of that again today in Paul Kelly's article in the Australian. He was engaging in a bit more head scratching as to what the Opposition was doing. I will quote what he had to say on this issue. I wish to quote it because I think he has put it very well. Mr Kelly stated:
The Government is the side proposing longer parliaments; if the Opposition helps to defeat this question, it can scarcely complain if it gets shorter Parliament.

I think that that ought to be borne in mind by the electorate. No more will anybody be able to go around whingeing because we have these trumped up propositions from Prime Ministers that we need yet another election. The Opposition, in one fell swoop, would have taken the ground from under any complaint about having elections at any old tick of the clock. On the other hand, if this proposal is carried, there will be a massive moral pressure on the Government to make sure that it goes as close to the longer term as possible. Mr Kelly continues:
In the present case the Opposition, searching for non-existing conspiracies, cannot grasp that Mr Hawke's first referendum question has both pros and cons for Labor.

What does Labor lose? It loses its powerful Senate position. Labor is the only party with more long-term than short-term senators. So Labor will win from the next half-Senate election, an election that will never occur if the referendum is passed, thereby institutionalising full Senate elections.

That is an interesting fact. Senator Chaney skidded around that one and did not bother addressing himself to it because he wanted to draw out the conspiracy theories. It is difficult to get a conspiracy theory when one has a question that actually affects the Labor Party by shooting it almost in the foot. Having got itself in the last election the extra long term senators, it is now prepared to give them away. In the long term the Labor Party may lose from both making the Senate a more powerful chamber and ensuring that neither government nor opposition can ever control it unless the voting system is changed. The Opposition argument that the Senate will be weakened mistakes form for substance. The Senate's power is not a function of the rotation of senators system-the classic defect in the Opposition's case. Again, someone who knows how the Parliament operates can see clearly from the outside that the Opposition's case with regard to this is extremely flimsy.

However, the Australian Democrats do not see all good in this proposal. Our policy for fixed term parliaments has been consistent. Senator Ray was correct in pointing out that the Opposition had attacked that on innumerable occasions. I know because I introduced the Bills.

The fixed term parliament proposal unfortunately is not one the Opposition will take up; it is not one the Government will take up; nevertheless the Democrats still believe it is one for which the country is looking. It is a pity that the Labor Party, which was so strongly supportive of this idea in opposition, chose to give it away on the whim of the Prime Minister in 1983. In 1983 the Labor Party ended up introducing such a Bill, presumably because the Prime Minister did not notice in those early hectic days that such a Bill was being introduced. When he discovered it, the whole matter was scuttled. It is still by far the better proposal. It can be made to work and to work well in the Australian context. But that is not to be.

The Democrats believe the Victorian proposal, which again was mentioned by Senator Ray, is superior to this proposal. It was introduced by the Labor Party in Victoria, not necessarily because it wanted to but because it was an end to a matter of compromise on the upper House. It has more merit than this proposal. In these circumstances, we are left not with a fixed term but with a floating term. One must then ask, in handing over to the Prime Minister that particular power, whether it is a worthy proposition. Hopefully, in the general community debate, that particular point will be focused on-where the people believe the best type of reform can take place; not the type of furphies run by Senator Chaney but the best type of reform we may have, whether that should have been a fixed term exercise or this type of exercise.

The Prime Minister also loses some power under this proposal. Yet another give and take exists under that exercise, because one of the extraordinary powers that the Prime Minister has over this chamber is to choose whether there should be a half Senate election or a double dissolution. When this chamber is not controlled by the government, there is always a proposition that there is a trigger for a double dissolution floating around, certainly after the first year or so. We are just coming up to that now, and presumably the trigger mechanisms will be made available to us. The Government has already had the opportunity for some but has not taken them up. Presumably it is waiting for the outcome of this measure. If it fails, a trigger mechanism will be put in place by the end of the year. It always is. Why? Because it gives the Prime Minister the choice of having either a double dissolution or a half Senate election. That is the most extraordinary power the Prime Minister has over this chamber and he will lose it under this proposal. So far as I understand it, that has not been raised in the general debate thus far. Those types of items should be focused on-the actualities of the case as distinct from the type of furphies run around by the Opposition parties. That is the context. They are the types of powers that exist and that is what will occur.

We do not have to hypothesise; we do not have to raise conspiracies and chase them up and down the corridors. We have to look at only what actually happens and how power is used in this country. That is what I am referring to: what has happened in the past 10 years. That gives a far better indicator of what is likely to occur in the future. I wait with bated breath for the opposition in the committee stage of the Bill to point to the clauses that are supposed to destroy this chamber. It will not be destroyed unless the opposition parties of the day, whichever they may be, gain control and seek to do again what happened in 1975, or unless its effectiveness is destroyed by the party that has the majority in the House of Representatives again getting control in this chamber and treating it, as it has been treated before on so many occasions, merely as a rubber stamp.

TALK.START.PARA: —What happened in 1975 was that the people--

—That is the circumstance. Senator Stone has gone off yet again. He should stop twitching and wait for his turn. He is probably on the list and it would do him good to wait a little longer. Patience is a virtue.
—He is not on the list.

—I am sure that is an oversight. Clearly, the exercise is that this chamber works effectively when it is not controlled either by the major opposition party or the government party. That is the only time when it works as a House of review. One has only to ask oneself why, and the dynamics of politics tell one why. It is as simple as that. Presumably Senator Stone has been in politics long enough now to know about the dynamics of politics and that it is a numbers exercise. I am sure that he knows about the numbers; he is in the National Party in Queensland. If he does not know, he would not have been in this place. Therefore, he is well acquainted with the notion of numbers and politics.
—He had to have only one number.

—He might have had that lovely share which actually has all the votes. I turn now to the next Bill, which deals with one vote one value. It is a Bill with which I have been well acquainted, having spent such a long period of my political career touting it at every meeting to every group that will listen.
—Even captive audiences like this.

—Even captive audiences like this one here, as the Minister says. I am glad that people will at last be given the opportunity of saying what they believe about this situation. That is all I have been asking for from the beginning of my campaign in 1983 when I was elected to this place. In 1985 the Constitution Alteration (Democratic Elections) Bill, which I was proposing then, was an item that dealt with the notion that, coming up to the Bicentennial, Australians should look at whether they wished to accept the invitation offered to them by the Constitution in 1901 that State Constitutions were to stay as they are unless the people determine otherwise under the Constitution, and should grasp the nettle and decide, as a democratic country-as a country that has provided so much to the democratic movements around the world, as a country which is looked up to by many countries as an example that should be followed, as a country which probably amongst all countries in the world values freedom, values the right of individuals to express their opinions and values the right to engage in vigorous debate and to have both sides of questions aired for the people to make their judgment-whether we should still allow undemocratic processes for the election of our governments to remain and to initiate, as I believe they do, internal corruption in this country.

SPEECH.PARA: What emerges as the prime defender of democracy today is that those countries that are not democratic have no resistance whatsoever to organised crime. In a democratic country there is a changing of government, a changing of the people who hold power. The old adage that power corrupts and absolute power corrupts absolutely applies regardless of whether it is a dictatorship or a so-called democratically elected government which is elected on rigged boundaries such that it can never be removed. Many countries around the world have that, and they have no bulwark against corruption. The institutionalisation of democracy in today's world must be seen very much in the light of that bulwark against corruption and crime.

Those who hold onto power today can be likened to those to whom Mr Whitlam referred in his famous quotation. He said that those people who are the cockerels today may end up as merely feather dusters tomorrow. That, probably more than anything else, should tame the instinct in almost every person to use power, not to the ends of advancing the interests of the people of a country, but possibly for his own ends. That is why one needs to be concerned about democratic processes. That is why one must always pay attention to the means by which our parliaments are elected. That is why we must pay attention to whom we put in power, and that is why I believe the pendulum in countries that are truly democratic swings backwards and forwards at a reasonable rate.

The people are very much aware that they do not want to leave governments sitting in office for too long. Recently it happened in New South Wales, and I applaud that. It is a demonstration to any of those who may be tempted to use the power they get at the ballot box to enrich themselves and their friends that the day of accounting will arrive. The people will make their judgment and those who wish to abuse the power they are given by the people will be brought to account.

My Bill dealing with one vote one value was the first private member's Bill to be put on the agenda of a constitutional convention. It was part of my strategy at that time to get the Australian Labor Party committed to it and voting for it. The Attorney-General of the day was one of the delegates. I knew that once the Bill was before the convention, the troglodytes who emerge from the woodwork on these occasions would speak against it. One only has to read the proceedings of the Australian Constitutional Convention from 29 July to 1 August 1985 to realise how troglodytic those people can get. Arguments for all sorts of extraordinary propositions are put.

If some of those people had been allowed time, they would have got down to the worst of all arguments-that the vote for women was a retrograde step. They argued that the voting age limit should be wound back, that property ought to be used as a means for getting votes and all sorts of extraordinary things that had gone out with the passing of the reform Bills in Britain in the last century. However, those arguments were trotted out again in 1985 at a constitutional convention, and they are enshrined in this document I have with me.

I knew that opposition to my Bill would be mounted, and I knew that the Australian Government at that time would have no choice but to vote for it, as it did. By a margin of 39 to 29 votes, in 1985 the Constitutional Convention called on the Government to support the principles contained in my Bill and for a proposal to be put to the Australian people at a nationwide referendum. That was the point at which everyone was locked in. However, it took another three years of hard work by me, by people working within the Labor Party and in a number of other parties to push the Government to finally bite the bullet on this matter.

During that time we were taken on a lot of highways and byways. For example, a senator in this place was talking about the notion of whether our Federal powers could be used. There is only one way in which this item can be dealt with, and that is by asking the people to do it. There are no other ways; no other avenues are open. We must ask the people to enshrine in their Constitution what is contained in the proposals. The Constitution governs this country and I remind the people that it governs the States as well as the Commonwealth.

Many arguments have been heard during the time my Bill was presented to the Constitutional Convention, the silliest of which is the notion about States rights. I have been suffering under the delusion for a long time that States do not have the right to vote. Presumably, the motion of States rights is the notion to give States the right to vote. I thought votes were held by people. By way of an interjection from a National Party senator a while ago, we were talking about whether sheep should have the right to vote. Presumably they would have two votes because if one has two legs, one has one vote; therefore, because sheep have four legs they would have two votes. I imagine that the National Party's notion of reform would be to reduce the number of votes that sheep have to one. Others work in the real world and that is where only people have the right to vote and not States. It is not a States right to vote; it is the people's right to vote.

Honourable senators have heard this extraordinary proposition from Senator Chaney to stop the people voting on their own Constitution, which the Opposition will propose later. Luckily, that will not prevail because the people will be able to vote on their Constitution and they will be able to determine quite clearly that States will never have the right to vote in this country; only people will have that right.

As has already been pointed out, there will be an extraordinary campaign of misinformation. The first arguments have been trotted out; Senator Chaney ran a few around, such as the idea that because the Senate is not being reformed or the special position of Tasmania is not being taken away, the Liberal Party will oppose the proposal. Presumably, if we tried to change the Senate and take away the special position of Tasmania, the Opposition would still oppose the proposal. However, that is the reason, Senator Chaney informed us quite seriously in his contribution, why the Opposition is opposing the proposal.

Senator Chaney went on in that vein. He gave a series of reasons and with regard to the local government proposal he said, `Either it does not take States rights or the High Court might decide it will. In either case we are opposed to it', it does not matter what the Opposition's argument is; it will oppose the proposal and work out the reasons later. The reasons will have little substance because, for the first time that I can remember since being involved in constitutional change, there has been a willingness on the part of members of the public to address themselves to the issue through the media representatives. The people have always been willing to vote; they have wanted to vote more often. One of the Bills I wish to discuss later-my Bill regarding citizens' initiatives-would give the people the ability to vote more often.

We have rarely had the type of support available to us that is available in this instance. As someone suggested to me at the ANZAAS conference, it is interesting to look at how the people have voted in public opinion polls before the lies of politicians overwhelm a campaign. I am not sure whether that is parliamentary, but it is an interesting sentiment. When the people address themselves to the issues before the fear campaigns get going, they have a clear view of what they want. At the end of this campaign, I am sure that that clear view will be maintained.

TALK.START.PARA: —Before the suspension of the sittings for dinner I was discussing the second of the five Bills before us, that is, the Bill with regard to one vote one value. I was looking at the types of claims which are being made by Senator Chaney, leading for the Opposition parties, as to why they were opposing the Bill.
