I have already touched on a number of those, and I now wish to touch on only two more. One is that somehow this particular Bill, the Constitution Alteration (Fair Elections) Bill 1988, will be strengthening the hand of Canberra vis-a-vis the States. Again there is no foundation within the Bill or any clauses of the Bill with regard to that item.

SPEECH.PARA: Common standards are put down to apply. I have already referred to the notion of the Senate and the special position of Tasmania, and suggested that the Opposition's reliance upon those as a possible reason for not supporting the Bill is absolutely extraordinary, considering the fact that if they were included, the Opposition would not support the Bill on those grounds. They are not grounds upon which the Liberal Party can oppose this Bill, since it would not wish to touch those items. They are mere furphies in the whole debate. The situation is that the Commonwealth Parliament will be bound by its electoral laws to obey this, as will the States. In that argument Senator Chaney made comparisons between upper Houses of the States and the Senate.

I suggest that here again the facts are not as he presented them. Let us look at the last Federal election, in 1987, with regard to the vote for this chamber. What do we find? We find that the Australian Labor Party scored 43 per cent of the vote and got 42 per cent of the seats. The Liberal-National parties got 42 per cent of the vote and 44 per cent of the seats. That approximation between the percentage of votes and the percentage of seats is not met by any other chamber of any other parliament in this Commonwealth. That is the closest-including the Tasmanian lower House, which is elected by proportional representation-proximation between the percentage of votes and the percentage of seats. I suggest to Senator Chaney and those others who want to run that argument that if every other upper House of a State parliament had got that type of close proximation, there would have been no push anywhere to make any types of changes with regard to the electoral laws governing upper Houses. The facts of the matter are that this chamber is the most democratically elected chamber if one wishes to compare the percentage of votes and the percentage of seats. That is the extraordinary thing about this chamber, which of course is set up on a system which actually seeks to give equal representation to States directly under the Constitution and not equal representation to the people.

I intend to refer only briefly to the third Bill, the Constitutional Alteration (Local Government) Bill 1988. The point made by Mr Ian Wilson, the Liberal member for Sturt in South Australia, in answer to the Opposition's notion that this is pure tokenism, I think needs to be recorded, and that is that wedding rings are also tokens. I think the point is well taken, that symbols within our society are important and in fact can have a great deal of importance, as Mr Wilson pointed out in that notion of the wedding rings. I think our community does in fact treasure and cherish particular symbols, and I can refer to another one that the Opposition has moved a private member's Bill about, and that is the flag. It is in fact a piece of cloth but, more than that, it is a symbol of something. I see no problem in actually saying that symbols are important in our society. Likewise, the symbolic writing of `local government' into our Constitution is a symbol of our recognition of local government as a valid area of governance in this country, an area that governs so many of the items which are closest to the people in terms of how they live and their daily lives. The local government associations very strongly support this constitutional referendum and in fact, according to discussions that I have had with local government people, are really at a loss to understand the Liberal and National parties' position in regard to that. They say that they intend to go out and campaign very strongly, because they are aware that this will be the one and only chance that local government will ever have of being enshrined in the Constitution. If this question is lost, it will be only generations, way into the future, that will see another referendum. It certainly will not be anybody who is around today.

The Constitution Alteration (Rights and Freedoms) Bill 1988 is another item that a number of my colleagues wish to address. I wish to make only one comment. Again, in today's newspapers there is an item which I think would characterise the type of debate we are about to have on this item. It is the `In Brief' column of the Australian's letters to the editor, so the Minister for Justice and others in the chamber probably know what type of letter it is. It says that the proposed referendum regarding freedom of religion is alarming and:
It will place control of all religious practices in this country in the hands of the Government . . . Let's vote no.

That, I think, is the level of the type of debate we are going to have, because that person obviously has not even bothered to read the Bill and does not know that there already is an item in the Constitution with regard to this, and it is an item denying powers to government, not giving powers. At the moment the only Government that has these powers denied to it is the Commonwealth Government. It is within the role of State governments, as sovereign entities, to outlaw religion if they wish or to establish religions if they wish, or to do anything else with regard to religion. This proposition will be denying the rights on that items, not giving them, and likewise with the others.

Again Senator Chaney, in his comments, says that it does not do everything and therefore the Opposition is opposing it. This proposition that if we cannot reform the entire world, we are not going to attempt even a small reform, is extraordinary. Reforms are made in the real world step by step. I too have already indicated further reforms that I would like within each of these Bills, but they go some way towards the goal that I would like to achieve and I believe in that need to be supported, because in doing so, if these items are carried we create a new climate for reform, so we can move on.

I suggest that the criteria applied to these Bills by the Opposition parties, and by members in the community, should not be whether these in fact reform the entire world, but rather whether they move in the direction of reforms that I would like. That is the type of criterion to be applied. If they move in that direction they ought to be supported. If they do not move in that direction-and that is a legitimate argument that people may put up-they would not be supported. It is the direction in which they move for reform that is the important item. Here we have a number of propositions, one with regard to trial and one with regard to property-and that is particularly important because most of the problems with regard to the acquisition of property occur at State or local government level. The Liberal Party knows this well. Under the Wran Labor Administration in New South Wales there was confiscation of property with no recompense with regard to coal acquisitions. That is probably the most recent blatant example of a State government using its overwhelming sovereign power to confiscate property from private citizens with no recompense. Yet the Liberal Party, which was quite vicious with regard to that legislation, says that it does not want State governments to be controlled. I believe that every government should be controlled. This proposition supports the right to private property. As such I would have thought that the Opposition parties would support it.

The fifth Bill before us is the Constitution Alteration (Electors' Initiative) Bill. The other propositions I have been discussing are those that have come from politicians. In Senator Chaney's words, the Opposition parties believe that the debate is not at the right point-it is only just beginning. Senator Chaney's view is slightly arrogant. In other words, the Opposition takes the view that it has just started something, therefore public debate is just starting. I remind the Opposition that it voted against our Bill in this place about five years ago. We introduced our first Bill on this issue 10 years ago. The Opposition is just getting around to it now. Because it is just getting around to it, it assumes that the public is just getting around to it. Perhaps it should go out and talk to the public on this one, to see whether the public are just getting around to the issue of whether politicians should be able to put up questions with regard to changes to the Constitution or whether the people should do so.

My proposition is relatively simple. Under our Constitution it is only the people who are able to change the Constitution. Currently only politicians can pose the question. What we are suggesting is a step forward-a relatively small step forward: The people should be able to propose some of the questions. Of course the people will then make the decisions. How might this be done? The simplest method is tried and true. It was very strongly supported by my own State of Queensland. Prior to Federation Bills were introduced into the Queensland Parliament-unfortunately they were not proceeded with because of a number of local issues at the time-urging a vote against the Constitution on a number of grounds. I have already mentioned one ground in a previous debate-if it did not enshrine universal suffrage, which is rather interesting because that is what we are attempting to do now. The second ground was because it did not have a citizens' initiative proposal. It would be nice in terms of the history of my State if, 88 years on, those types of propositions went to the people, to bring our Constitution up to date-that is, up to 1899. That was when there was a major debate. At that time many of the States of the United States adopted a citizens' initiative proposal. The end of the Western world has not happened. The parliamentary system still operates in all the States of America. It is not affected by the citizens' initiative proposal. There are good arguments for suggesting that it enhances it.

As I said at the beginning of my speech, before the suspension of the sitting for dinner, we must always be on the outlook for new methods of improving the democratic life of our country. We must constantly work upon democracy. We must not think that we are the ultimate and that our system is as far as we can go. History teaches us that that sort of arrogance is always misplaced. Improvements can always be made. They can be made in the Australian democratic system. They will be made at some time in the future. One such improvement is to incorporate the people more into the initiation process. We have a representative system in Australia. We have used and developed it well. But now we ought to look beyond it.

One thing that is evident in most public debates about politics is the problem of so-called apathy. I do not believe that the Australian electors are apathetic. The problem of apathy is that people will not do something. The difficulty with an analysis of apathy is that it is identical to an analysis of powerlessness. If people are powerless they do not do anything, either. A correct analysis of the political life of Australia is not that the people feel apathetic or are apathetic; it is that they feel powerless and are powerless. They say, quite rightly, `In 1983 we elected an Australian Labor Party government that had an anti-uranium policy and it has managed to sell more uranium than the previous Fraser Government'. That is the type of powerlessness they feel. When they vote for politicians they do not get the platform they voted for. They voted for a Fraser government that put forward a whole series of propositions and eventually had to vote it out of office because it did not bother fulfilling any of them. Then they voted for a Labor Party government that managed to fulfil most of the promises put by the Fraser government. That is what I mean by `powerless'. We are about to have another broken promise. After going to the people in 1987 strongly on the promise that it would not introduce higher education fees and so forth, this Labor Party Government is about to renege on that promise, amongst others, and implement a policy that the Liberal Party went to an election on in 1987. That is the sort of powerlessness people feel.

The reason they are turned off politics is the cynicism that has tended to get built in. How might that be rectified? It will not be rectified by political parties or politicians. That is evident. It has to be rectified by a new mechanism. I believe that the new mechanism should be one whereby the people can intrude into the political process. They could intrude at various stages, either at the constitutional level, with regard to putting a stay on legislation passed or proposing legislation. The Queensland Government is looking at some of these proposals now. I congratulate it on doing so. Advances can be made across the board in all States and at the Commonwealth level. Something I have been suggesting and something my Party has been suggesting for 10 years, with all due respect to Senator Chaney who has just heard about it-we have had a Bill in this chamber for that length of time-is well and truly on the public agenda. There is worry about whether items that come up are right wing, left wing or whatever else. I suggest that these are mere furphies. It is merely the proposition or question that we are talking about.

Who gets to vote? Exactly the same people who get to vote now-the people of Australia. The people of Australia are the democracy. One cannot have any in principle argument against the people being able to propose a question in the only area in which they are able to make the sole determination. If one takes objection to the vote of the people one takes objection to their voting in governments. How can they be allowed to vote in governments? How can they be allowed to do this or do that? That is an absurd corner to paint oneself into. We have to put aside those arguments. We have to accept that the people's voice is sovereign. If they wish to propose a question and support it by way of referendum, then that is what they want.

One does not necessarily have to agree with it personally. It would be pretty silly of me to say that I have agreed with the results of the last few elections. One does not personally have to agree that that is the right or proper course. All that one has to say is that the legitimate course in a democracy should be followed and one can then go out and campaign to try to have it overturned-as in fact the notion of a loyal opposition in our parliamentary democracy does; it accepts the voice of the people at an election and then goes out and campaigns for three years to try to overturn it.

These are important items. The debate will go for a long time here. But, in the end, this debate is not all that important. What will be important is the campaign, and what will ultimately be important, as it should be in any true democracy, is that the voice of the people will finally be heard on these questions.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Lewis Sen A.W.R

TALK.START.PARA: —The Senate is debating cognately the Constitution Alteration (Parliamentary Terms) Bill 1988, the Constitution Alteration (Fair Elections) Bill 1988, the Constitution Alteration (Local Government) Bill 1988 and the Constitution Alteration (Rights and Freedoms) Bill 1988, put forward by the Government to alter the Constitution, and the Constitution Alteration (Electors' Initiative) Bill 1987 put forward by the Australian Democrats to alter the Constitution. This afternoon we heard a brilliant statement of the reasons why the Liberal and National parties are proposing that the people of Australia should vote no to each of the proposals. That speech, which was made by Senator Chaney, was a brilliant speech. I urge those honourable senators who did not hear that speech for some reason or other to get a copy of the Hansard in order to read it. Since then we have heard Senator Robert Ray lead for the Government in favour of the proposals and Senator Macklin lead for the Democrats in favour of the proposals.

SPEECH.PARA: It has always been my experience that whenever the Australian Labor Party is in the process of being defeated in a debate it resorts to personal attacks. This afternoon we heard Senator Robert Ray make a series of personal attacks on various members, present and former, of the Liberal and National parties in Canberra-Fraser, Anthony, Sinclair, Chaney, Howard, Boswell and Lewis-which, as I have said, is a general indication that the Labor Party feels that it is losing the debate. But I must say that Senator Robert Ray, as is usual with him, made those attacks with a certain joie de vivre, a certain humour and a certain lack of unpleasantness. I cannot say the same for Senator Macklin. Quite frankly, I found Senator Macklin's personal attacks on members of the Liberal and National parties emotional, hypersensitive, and at times irrational. I wondered from time to time what Senator Macklin was on about.

On the other hand, Senator Macklin turned at the very end of his speech towards some criticism of the Government for its very serious breaches of promises which the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke) and the Labor Party made to the people of Australia at the last election. Senator Macklin talked about the so-called feeling of powerlessness of the people of Australia, with no real criticism of the members of the Labor Party, demonstrating once again, as I have said frequently in this place, that since the retirement of Senator Chipp the Democrats have become the extreme left wing of the Labor Party in this place. The sooner they and the left wing of the Labor Party amalgamate and form a party that the people of Australia are able to recognise, the better.

I do not intend to continue with personal attacks on these people. I have responded in the way I have only because, quite frankly, Senator Macklin got up my nostrils with his deep personal attacks on the Liberal Party of Australia. I had to make those few remarks but I now intend to turn to a sensible discussion of the measures which are now before the Parliament.

The Government of this country is about to spend $30m on constitutional reform proposals which it is putting forward without any genuine attempt to find some bipartisan support for them. I put to the people of Australia as a fact that the Prime Minister and the Attorney-General (Mr Lionel Bowen) asked the Leader of the Opposition, Mr John Howard, to come to the Prime Minister's office in order to discuss some of these matters and the possibility that the Opposition parties might support them. At that meeting Mr Howard was presented with certain proposals. In relation to the first matter, he made a possible counter proposal that he would be prepared to take back and discuss with his Party and the Prime Minister and the Attorney-General agreed to consider that counter proposal. But the next thing that Mr Howard knew was that about four hours after that discussion the Government announced what it was going to do and did not bother to give us any opportunity to consider the alternative, nor did it give any consideration to that alternative.

TALK.START.PARA: —What was the alternative?

—It was not an unreasonable alternative. I do not mind admitting that it was one that I would have opposed, but that was my point of view. Mr Howard was prepared to say to the Prime Minister and to the Attorney-General that he would be prepared to take back to his parties for consideration a proposal whereby we give a four-year term to members of the House of Representatives and two terms of the House of Representatives to the Senate. He was prepared to take that back and consider it but he was not given the opportunity to have any discussion within the Party room because the Government immediately announced what it intended to do on all these issues.

SPEECH.PARA: On the question of endeavouring to achieve some genuine bipartisan support, in 1985 the Government abandoned the constitutional conventions which were being held and which were certainly the best mechanism for seeking some common ground. In fact, the Government has gone even further and has abandoned its own $6m Constitutional Commission. I have great difficulty in seeing how that Commission could have achieved some bipartisan proposals but there was a possibility that, if its recommendations could have been treated as some sort of general matter for discussion and a constitutional convention could have been held in order to discuss those matters, there would have been agreement on some measures. I refer, for example, to the Liberal and National parties' continual pushing forward of the proposition that, where the Senate blocks measures from the House of Representatives, the Senate ought to go to an election.

There were some possibilities along those lines. But this Government is not interested in any bipartisan support. It is taking this step for the purely political reason that it is in real trouble out in the electorate and this is an opportunity to divert people's attention away from the Government's mismanagement of the economy and to get people thinking about something other than the Government's current mismanagement. In the process the Government is putting dishonest questions to the people-questions which do not set out the genuine nature of the proposals which are contained within the Bills. Indeed, the first question which the Government is putting to the people is not only dishonest but also sinister, and I will come to that in a few moments.

Let me quote, as I have in debates previously in this place on constitutional reform, from Woodrow Wilson. I have quoted this repeatedly before and I hope that I never cease quoting this, even when the Liberal and National parties are in government:
Liberty has never come from the Government . . . the history of liberty is the history of the limitation of governmental power, not the increase of it.

TALK.START.PARA: —Hear, hear!

—`Hear, hear', says Senator Tate. I hope that he takes that up with his Party when he talks about these constitutional changes. The history of liberty is the history of limiting government power, not increasing it. These proposals are all about increasing government power, not limiting it.

SPEECH.PARA: I will also quote from an essay by Professor Gordon Reid, who is now the Governor of Western Australia. It is an extract from a revised text of an address delivered to the 1978 summer school of the Australian Institute of Political Science when Professor Reid was Deputy Vice-Chancellor and Professor of Politics at the University of Western Australia. At that stage there was some concern about whether the political system could cope. That was the theme of the conference at which Professor Reid spoke. In his opening remarks he said:

To give you an introductory glimpse of my findings, they are: that the elected Parliament is a weak and weakening institution; that the Executive Government is the principal beneficiary of the Parliament's decline; and that the Judiciary is tending to Parliament's decline; and that the Judiciary is tending to compete with the Executive Government in exploiting the Parliament's weakness . . .

I think that sums it up very well for those people who understand that there is a fundamental difference between the Executive Government and the Parliament. Because we have adopted the Westminster system in Australia, with the Executive Government being elected by the Parliament, there is a tendency for the people not to really grasp that their representative is the elected Parliament of the people, not the Government. The Government stands in the pseudo role of the former monarch who dictated to the people what he was intending to do. The Parliament is the people's place-in this Parliament, both the House of Representatives and the Senate. The Parliament-in the United States it is called the Congress-is the people's place. This is where the rights of the people are protected, not by governments. Governments are out to exercise their powers. We have here another example of a Government desperately endeavouring, as I have said, to divert the people's attention and, in the process, to take away some of the fundamental powers of the people's place, the Parliament, and, in particular, this House, the Senate of Australia.

The basic objections to the proposal are quite simple. I turn to the first question, the one which I have described as not only a dishonest question but also a sinister question. The question is: Do you approve of an Act to alter the Constitution to provide for four-year maximum terms for members of both Houses of the Commonwealth Parliament? In effect, the proposal is to increase the terms of members of the House of Representatives from three years to four years and reduce the terms of senators from six years to four years. But in truth, and here is the sinister part of it, the proposal sets out to give the Prime Minister and the government of the day-I say this as a Liberal, whilst recognising that it would apply also to a Liberal Prime Minister-control over the Senate.

This proposal destroys the fixed term of the Senate and effectively introduces a permanent double dissolution situation. It abandons the system of rotation of senators' terms and removes the restrictions on a Prime Minister calling early elections. That is the crucial point: it removes any restriction on the Prime Minister calling an early election. It will destroy the fixed term of the Senate. The Labor Party says that as part of its policy it would like to have a fixed term for the House of Representatives. It has a fixed term for the Senate, and it wants to destroy it. Why would it want to destroy the fixed term of the Senate if it were not because it can see some fundamental gain in removing that fixed term? Destroying the fixed term of the Senate makes it easier for any Federal government to turn the Senate into simply a rubber stamp. Any government could dissolve the Senate whenever it wished to have an early House of Representatives election.

Under this proposal there is no question that the Prime Minister will have to wait four years. He can simply call an election whenever he is able to persuade the Governor-General that the time is ripe for him to have an election and then both Houses of the Parliament will go to the people straightaway. The Prime Minister can have an election at any time. That means that if, for example, on the Australia Card proposal, the Prime Minister had got a bit cranky because the Senate was being difficult about it, he could have immediately called an election and said to the Governor-General, `I need a mandate to put through my proposal for the Australia Card; so we are going to have an election'. Then both Houses of the Parliament would have gone to the people and the Senate's ability in any way to delay or block that measure or to put it to a committee, to enable the people of Australia to understand what it was all about, would have gone by the bye. He would not have had to force a double dissolution. He could have simply taken both Houses of the Parliament out for an election.

This proposal, put forward by the Government, by undermining the constitutional independence of the Senate would make it easier for any Federal government to ignore the less populous States. It would make it easier for Federal governments to hold early elections. In fact, it would be likely to result in more frequent elections. The Labor Party would have us believe that by pushing for a four-year term there will be fewer elections. But the truth is that the fixed term of the Senate has in the past pushed governments into having longer terms before they go to the people. Senator Ray conceded today that the fact that there is a fixed term for the Senate means that the Prime Minister has to be cautious about when he calls a House of Representatives election or he might end up having a Senate election by itself. There have been only four Senate elections by themselves throughout our history. That is because of the fixed term of the Senate. Under this proposal all of that need for caution would be gone and it would be easy for the Prime Minister to call more frequent elections, not fewer elections.

What really annoys me is this talk about the Labor Party having some sort of fixed term policy and trying to have fewer elections. If the Prime Minister were fair dinkum about this he could announce tonight the date of the next Federal election. There would be no problem with that. He could say, `I am going to have the next Federal election on the first Saturday in December 1989'. That would fit in with the window of the Senate; a period of 12 months before the next Senate term expires. It would fit in with the Prime Minister's term. It would not be three years; it would be only about 2 1/2 years since the last election. If the Prime Minister wanted to have fixed terms he could announce now when he is going to call an election. Of course, he will not do that. All Prime Ministers, whether Liberal or Labor, want to keep to themselves the power to control the date on which they will go to the people.

There is a very simple solution to all of these problems. We do not have to change the Constitution, go through all this rigmarole and spend $30m. If the Prime Minister really wants to solve this problem-that is, if he does not want to have a lot of elections and if he wants both Houses of the Parliament to go to the people together-he can announce now that the next election will be held on the first Saturday in December 1989, or whenever he likes within that 12-month period before the term of the Senate expires, which is 30 June 1990. He can announce any date for an election within 12 months of 30 June 1990. Then the people of Australia would know when we are going to have the next election. I ask the people, if they have any doubts about this, why do they not ask those people who are supporting these proposals this simple question: Under this Bill will a government be able to have an early election for both Houses of the Parliament; will the Prime Minister be able to call an election for both Houses of the Parliament whenever he chooses? The simple answer is yes, of course.

The problems formerly associated with the proposals for simultaneous elections, which the people of Australia have now thrown out on, I think, four occasions, are compounded by the destruction of the basic principle of rotation of senators. Let me quote something that Professor Geoffrey Sawer said in evidence to the Select Committee on the Constitution Alteration (Avoidance of Double Dissolution Deadlocks) Bill back in 1950. He said:
There is no point in having a House of review unless you have some degree of difference between the points of view of the Houses, and you get that more with the staggered system of elections.

That is why our founding fathers set up this situation whereby we would have a six-year fixed term for the Senate and a three-year non-fixed term for the House of Representatives, with the Senate elections being conducted within a period of 12 months prior to the expiration of the six-year term. That would then enable the Prime Minister to have that period of 12 months in which to call an election at some time suitable to the people of the nation. In fact, in our history this has turned out to be-increasingly more so-for the benefit of the Prime Minister of the day. With a double dissolution election available to a government at its pleasure, there are no constitutional or practical constraints on a Prime Minister who wants an election at any time it suits him. At present, with only half of the Senate required to go to an election, there may be practical examples of sufficient force-for example, the substantial loss of Senate seats-to make a government think twice about calling an election, and the constitutional limitation on calling an election for the House of Representatives and half the Senate at whim, that is, the one-year barrier to calling Senate elections, is lost.

I draw the attention of honourable senators to section 57 of the Constitution, which provides the mechanism to resolve genuine deadlocks between the Houses with that section's built-in delay mechanisms on the hasty calling of an election. I point out that that provision will no longer operate as a constraint on the Government. As I have indicated, the Government, on a matter such as the Australia Card, could simply say, `The Senate has opposed this measure and we are intending to go to the people of Australia for a mandate to push this measure through'. There would be no delaying mechanism and no opportunity for the senators of Australia to get out into their States and explain to the people of Australia what the Government was trying to pull on them. We would all be stuck here debating this sort of matter. The Prime Minister of the day would then appeal to the people and, as we found at the last election, the issue before the Parliament would probably not get any real run at all. The Prime Minister would be talking to the people about economic or other matters and the crucial issue before the people of Australia that the Senate was trying to deal with would go in the hurly-burly of the election. Without all that delay mechanism the people would suddenly have something thrust upon them which it might take them 12 or 18 months to find out about. But in due course they would discover that they had once again been squeezed unmercifully, to their detriment, by the Federal Government.

Let me say that I am opposed to eight-year terms for senators. Frankly, I am also opposed to four-year terms for members of the House of Representatives. I have already told honourable senator what I think ought to happen. The founding fathers thought about this matter carefully. They were not prepared to give eight- or 10-year terms to senators. They were prepared to give senators only six-year terms and members of the House of Representatives, therefore, three-year terms. My view has always been that three-year terms for members of the House of Representatives are perfectly all right, if only Prime Ministers would observe the three-year term and not call early elections for their own benefit or the benefit of their parties. As I have said, there is a simple solution: Within two to three months of a Prime Minister being elected, the Governor-General could announce in his Speech that his Prime Minister had advised him of the date of the next election. He could then name the election date. That would solve all the problems.

TALK.START.PARA: —How does that square with section 57?

—Senator Tate raises a technical problem. Of course, if there were some major confrontation at any stage, it would have to be overcome by way of double dissolution. What I am saying is that the Prime Minister, through the Governor-General's Speech, could say, `Unless there is some major confrontation between the Houses of the Parliament, the next election will be held on the first Saturday in December, three years hence'. I pick the first Saturday in December three years hence because this seems to be the date on which the people of Australia like to have a Federal election. It is before Christmas, it is not in the middle of winter and it seems to be a convenient date. That would probably be the date if we had fixed terms. The Government talks about having genuine three-year terms. It is saying, `If you give us a four-year term, we will get close to a three-year term'. That is what this Government is on about.

SPEECH.PARA: My time has almost expired and I have really touched only on the arguments on the first proposal. In the last two minutes available to me let me very quickly refer to the other questions. The proposal for allegedly fair and democratic elections, claimed to be one vote one value, is a nonsense in many ways because the Federal Government is saying to the States, `We do not have one vote one value in Canberra but you are going to have it in the States'. We simply say to the people of the States that it is their decision. They elect their State government and it should be able to determine what policy its people want in their elections, whether it be a 10 per cent allowance up or down or a 5 per cent allowance up or down. If the people do not like the Government that they have, they should do what the people of New South Wales did in the last election-throw it out and put in a government that they want and overcome the problem in that way rather than asking the Federal Government to impose upon the States a constitutional requirement which would be of great concern because the proposal put forward by the Government does not deal with the crucial question of gerrymanders.

I point out that New South Wales allegedly has one vote one value but Nick Greiner needed over 52 per cent of the vote to win. At the last Federal election the coalition parties needed 52.3 per cent of the two-party preferred vote to win office. So what is all this talk about one vote one value being allegedly imposed by the Constitution? There would be great problems. I ask the people of the States to solve that problem with their State governments. The proposal on the recognition of local government is purely and simply tokenism. There is no definition of local government, so the whole proposal becomes meaningless with no guarantees for the benefit of local government.

Finally let me refer to the so-called freedoms. They are all put in one question so that we are obligated to have freedom of religion with these other freedoms. It is my belief that freedom of religion will create great difficulty. It would mean we would have to suffer such things as Scientology and have constitutionally protected tax rorts. I know there are a number of tax rort systems designed to be based on a religious proposal. We are also concerned that that may validate extreme religious practices-and I refer in particular to circumcision of young girls. The coalition parties have considered all these issues and generally we believe that the correct answer is to vote no on all of them.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Burns Sen B.R

TALK.START.PARA: —These Constitution alteration Bills have the purpose of modernising the Constitution by making a number of changes: a four-year term for the House of Representatives; a reduced term of four years for the Senate; one vote one value; recognition of local government in the Constitution; the right of people to fair compensation for land resumed; the right to trial by jury and the freedom of religion. They also contain the denial of the right of a State to create a religion and use that for its purposes. These Bills have been put before the Parliament by this Australian Labor Party Government and we support them. The suggestions for the issues contained in these Bills are contained in a recommendation from a committee of prominent Australians who are concerned for our nation in our times and into the future.

SPEECH.PARA: People will decide these referendum questions. That really gets to the bottom line of democracy. They will not have to vote for a government which has maybe a hundred policy points, 55 of which they agree with and 45 of which they do not. They will be looking at specific issues which will create a framework for this nation by way of the Constitution and its changes. That framework will have to be abided by by any government, whatever its political colour. This will be an occasion when people will make a decision and virtually make that framework for laws. It is not an occasion on which some people for a particular reason, in this place or in the House of Representatives, because they might owe somebody something or because they might have a pigheaded view about an issue, will say that we must vote for a matter, based on the decision of a number of people. This referendum will mean millions of people out there in the community making a decision.

Senator Chaney quoted some person, I think his name was McGuinness, who wrote for the Australian Financial Review. According to Senator Chaney, he said that our Constitution is robust and still appropriate for today-not in those words, but that is what he meant. Robust it may be, but that it is sufficiently encompassing to serve our needs I would dispute. To suggest that a constitution created by politicians at the beginning of this century, from six different British colonies, with boundaries that were created by people who had some axe to grind or some special interest to serve, is appropriate today when we have a multicultural community, is absolute nonsense.

We had a white Australia policy. We no longer have one and neither should we. Women were treated as chattels-they no longer are, mostly. Neither should they be. They are now well on the way to showing their capacity to contribute even more to our community than they have in the past. I appeal to them to vote yes to these referendum proposals to show their clear understanding of their determination to help Australia into the modern age. We once had highly protected industries; this is no longer the case, as it should not be. Changes are taking place which were brought about by this Labor Government. Yes, we are changing-and our society needs change. Our Constitution needs to change to facilitate the dynamic movement forward of our nation.

If members of the Opposition want to be troglodytes, as they have been in the past, so be it. The people of this nation will continue to reject them for their opposition to these referenda. The proposal to extend the term for the House of Representatives is sound as it will create more stable government. Long term planning of the economy and the creation of wealth which will finance the necessary social programs are important in areas of education, health and income for retirees. Senator Lewis talked about early elections. He ought to know. The Liberal and National parties have had a lot of practice at that because they have been in power for a lot longer than has the Labor Government in the last 40 years and they have had a tremendous number of early elections-for reasons that would suit the Liberal Party and its interests.

Included in this referendum is a shortening of senators' terms from six to four years. It is a very unselfish attitude that honourable senators should express, as I do now-it is a reasonable proposition. I certainly would not accept that anyone should be elected in this day and age for eight years and be allowed to remain in that position for that time without answering to the people. Those opposite say that this will reduce the power of the Senate. I am afraid that I have seen the power of the Senate used in a way that was spiteful and negative in terms of the interests of this community. Some people say this is a States House. If anyone wants to suggest that this is a States House, I would ask him to prove that to me by telling me the number of occasions on which senators from one State have voted together on an issue. The Senate has not been a States House, almost from the beginning. People vote on party lines.

People say they want the Senate to be a House of review. I do not see that that will be affected by bringing the two terms together. It will be a decision of the people whether they want a House of Representatives with the majority of a particular party in power and want those laws it passes to come to the Senate and also be passed or whether they want to pay fairly good salaries to and provide resources for the people in the House of Representatives to produce laws and then have the Senate reject them. That does not seem to be a sensible way of going about things. People will decide at the ballot box whether they want that and they will decide that at a time when the issues are before them. They can decide whether to vote together for all the members of the Senate and the House of Representatives and not have to put up with half the senators staying when the people want to be rid of them. The proposition bringing the voting for the two Houses together is sensible and will not interfere with the power of the Senate or its ability to review legislation, if that is the way the people wish it.

One hears a very interesting argument from the Opposition about the one vote one value principle. I looked up a few figures about Queensland-the home of democracy so we are told by the National Party there. That is not the attitude of the Liberal Party. Mr Innes, the Leader of the Liberal Party in Queensland, is most unhappy about the attitude expressed by the Federal Liberal Party on one vote one value. From the most recent figures I was able to procure, the number of qualified voters was 1,563,294. There were 89 seats. That is an average of 17,565 voters. Currently, the highest number of voters in a particular seat or division is 22,987 and the lowest is 7,909. No-one can tell me that by any standard or any test of fairness one electorate should have three votes for every person-even in Queensland sheep and cattle do not get a vote, though I suggest some people in the country areas might like that. The proposition contained in the referendum means there still could be a very great difference in numbers. We could have seats with 19,000 people, in round figures, and others with 15,000-but certainly not with 22,000 and 7,000.

I added the numbers of people in eight seats together and found that 74,158 people can elect eight parliamentarians in Queensland but for another eight seats it takes 174,476 people. So one person's vote is worth 43 per cent of another person's. Comparing the high and low numbers of voters in seats, the value in the 7,909-people seat is 34 per cent. By any standard of fairness people would have to agree that one vote one value is a splendid idea. Honourable senators opposite have a right not to agree with that, but they should not stand up in the Senate and suggest that nobody should agree with it. I have read that at one time only landowners voted and there was no vote for women. Things have changed. Everyone gets a vote, including women-and there are even more of them in Queensland than men.

The one thing that we have not got is one vote one value. If we are to have a fair electoral system, having accomplished the other things, we must have one vote one value. People in the country defend their right to have this loading so that it takes fewer of them to elect a member of parliament. They might get twice as much value for their vote, but I cannot see country people getting paid twice as much in wages; in fact, they get less than people in the city. People say that it is more difficult to service the large electorates. I say: Provide the resources so that those electorates can be serviced. We should not have one politician for only a few thousand electors. We should provide the resources for those electorates to be serviced. People from all sides of politics talk about the need for democracy, though I notice that members of the National Party talk about it less than others. Democracy is not about electing someone to parliament for three years and letting him do what he likes; it is about being involved in society, in everyday life. Supplying the necessary resources for the far-flung electorates could enable people to become more active in that way and do much of the work that they now wish to pass on to parliamentarians.

In that respect we come to another important part of the propositions for referenda-the recognition of local government. Clearly there is no national recognition in any way at this time. The State governments want the councils to be the creatures and servants of the State governments. They want to be able to sack them if it does not suit them. Senator Chaney made a point about how State governments would be able to get rid of corrupt councils if these changes were made. How do we get rid of corrupt State governments? I do not suggest that one would be more correct than the other in its approach to the job, but I do suggest that the councils are a vital element of our structure of government. They are closer to the people. Councillors know more people by their Christian names and have more involvement with them and are more accessible to them than are State and Federal parliamentarians. There are people in this House who have carried out responsibilities in that area and they would have had that experience. It has been suggested that State governments could be eliminated and costs could be reduced by having the local councils carrying a greater responsibility. It has not been suggested in this chamber, but I have heard it suggested elsewhere. I am very much inclined to the idea of giving local councils more authority and having the Federal government looking after the rest, thereby getting rid of the State governments. That seems to me to be a good idea. We would have a nation governed at less cost. Local government is indispensable and it should be recognised in our Constitution.

On the question of the freedom of religion we hear a person named Ahern from Queensland-I understand that he is the Leader of the National Party up there-making ridiculous comments about such freedom allowing crank organisations to start up. Crank organisations can probably start up now, but if they infringe the laws in any way they have to be answerable to this Parliament and to the various States. I think it should be made clear in the Constitution that there is freedom of religion and all governments should have to work within that aspect of the Constitution.

I refer now to compensation for land acquisition and trial by jury. My understanding of the utterances of various people in the Opposition over many years is that they agree with the proposition that we should have the right to trial by jury for certain crimes and that people should be properly compensated for land acquisitions. All of a sudden, because of some cheap political advantage that they hope to accrue, the Opposition is opposed to that. The people of the nation who are going to vote on these questions do not agree with them.

Before closing I must draw attention to one other point which I think has been made in this House; it was certainly made in the House of Representatives. We as a government, in developing this idea of having a four-year term for the Senate, would get a cheap advantage out of it in that we would get an extension of the life of the Senate for six months. I remind the Opposition that on 25 February 1977, when the Constitution Alteration (Simultaneous Elections) Bill was being debated, Senator Button pointed out to the then Government, the present Opposition, that the then Senate would get an extra six months. Apparently if the present Opposition is in office and puts up such a proposal it is wonderful but if we put up such a proposal it is not. The Attorney-General (Mr Lionel Bowen) made clear in his second reading speech in the House of Representatives that that advantage, if one could call it that, was available, but he did not say that it would be taken. I suggest that it probably would not be taken, but if the term did run over it would be for some machinery reason. As far as the record of this Government is concerned, it has nothing to fear about going to the electorate. However, our plans have been made on the basis of a three-year term and we have a clear understanding of what we are doing and when results should show. Obviously we are keen to run our present three-year term. We are also keen to go to a four-year term to allow for more stable government.

In conclusion, the people of this country should examine each of the proposals in the referenda. These proposals are intended to help this community in the future, to create fair play where it does not exist so far and to recognise people who have gone without recognition for so many years. It is something that everybody should support. I do not suggest that we should just go out looking for a simple majority; we should go out looking for a large majority. I believe that we can achieve that. I really think that at the end of the debate the conscience of a lot of the people in the Opposition will probably influence them to come on side with us, if not wholly, certainly partially. I commend the Bills and ask the Senate to carry them.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Powell Sen J.F.

TALK.START.PARA: —Unlike previous speakers, I will confine my remarks in this cognate debate almost totally to one of the Bills before us, a Bill for an Act to alter the Constitution to recognise local government, called the Constitution Alteration (Local Government) Bill 1988. As local government spokesperson for the Australian Democrats, I have consulted widely with local government, particularly in recent times since the referendum proposals have surfaced. Like people in local government, I am astonished that the Opposition appears to presume to speak in this debate for local government. It seems to me be an extraordinary arrogance as all we have had from the Opposition in recent times has been a series of policy vacuums which have resulted in some pretty interesting things from time to time.

SPEECH.PARA: Between sittings in the past month in particular I have been travelling in all areas of my home State of Victoria except Gippsland, where I will be going if we ever complete this session and get out of this place. I have listened to and talked with local government representatives both in regional cities and in some pretty small rural areas. The comments that I will make in this debate tonight reflect what I have heard from the local government people in those visits. I was not really surprised when I read in the Australian of 12 May that the Australian Local Government Association (ALGA) had expressed `amazement and disappointment at the coalition decision which had just been announced to campaign against all four referendum questions'. As I recall, on that particular day or very shortly thereafter I talked to some of the local government bodies in Victoria. I was also not surprised to find on the front page of the Canberra Times this morning a prominent article headed `Opposition about-face', in which the Australian Local Government Association, having had a look at the debate on this Bill in the House of Representatives, came out with a strong statement calling the Opposition stance an about-face. In the article the Association pointed to past statements by coalition party members and leaders supporting constitutional recognition.

I shall refer to only one of those statements, which I believe was referred to earlier in the debate, in which it was revealed that the Leader of the Opposition, Mr Howard, by courtesy of a letter tabled in the House of Representatives by the Attorney-General (Mr Lionel Bowen) had written to his constituents in support of constitutional recognition of local government. I am aware that many Opposition politicians from Mr Howard down have done just that very thing. At this point local government people are waking up to what is happening in that process.

Most particularly the Australian Local Government Association seems to have been rather put off, if you like, by the parliamentary debate which, it says in its statement, had been peppered with extraordinary claims about the implications of this Bill. It is worth exploring briefly some of that parliamentary debate to see just what it is that has caused a further reaction from the Australian Local Government Association which obviously, as I have, has had a good look at the debate in the House of Representatives. Some of the cynicism that surrounds the attitude of the community towards politicians and towards the processes of the Parliament can be explained by this sort of debate, a debate that honourable senators should remember comes in the context of a belief, until this point, by many if not most in local government that the Opposition would be in support of this particular proposition when it came before the people as it is now about to.

The shadow Attorney-General, the honourable member for Flinders, Mr Reith, in leading the debate made, amongst other points, the point that this proposal is a trick to con the local government vote. In spite of his saying that, the honourable member quoted the provisions of the Bill and the provisions of the Bill clearly show that, contrary to this sort of claim, the provisions of the proposed constitutional change clearly place State government in exactly the same position as it is now in relation to local government. It simply takes it one step further and ensures that local government is named and has status in the Constitution. I shall deal with that point later.

I agree with one point made by Mr Reith in the debate when he pointed to a problem that occurs frequently in local government, that is, that the Federal Government gives local government some new functions and funds it but in a year or two local government finds that the funding is withdrawn and local government ends up holding the baby. That is not exclusive to this Government or even to Federal governments. I support Mr Reith's raising that issue but it is a separate issue to the question of constitutional recognition of local government. However, while talking about local government, the issue is certainly worth making note of.
The Leader of the National Party of Australia, Mr Sinclair, in his speech, protested:
We are not opposed to constitutional recognition of local government.
His next sentence is rather revealing:
Indeed, most States already have that.

No-one is disputing that; what this particular Bill is attempting to do is to put forward a constitutional change to ensure that local government has status at the Federal level as well. Mr Sinclair talked about both conservative parties having a real respect for local government. Some of the material I shall read into the record shortly shows that, whilst Mr Sinclair might say there is great respect, that message is not getting through to local government. He went on to suggest that the Labor Party is using this legislation as a very good opportunity to aggregate power. I shall return to that point later.

The honourable member for Parkes, Mr Cobb, spoke about the centralising of power, picking up the point made by Mr Sinclair. That is particularly interesting when one reflects on the contribution of Mr Reith in which he protested that this is mere tokenism. That protest is repeated often by other Opposition speakers and no doubt will be in this debate as it is pursued in the Senate. Certainly that is a contradiction in the argument of the Opposition. If it is tokenism, how can it possibly do anything about changing the position of power let alone centralise power. If the Opposition is going to bring the wrath of local government down upon its head, as it has done, the very least it could do is to get its arguments square.
I am very interested in another of Mr Cobb's comments. He said:
. . . support for this referendum virtually came only from local government people and from no-one else.

If there is to be a referendum before the people concerning local government, surely it is entirely appropriate that local government be the group to endorse it. Who is more affected than those groups of people who administer what I suggest is the most significant tier of government in terms of person-to-person contact and in terms of grassroots understanding of issues at local level-local government. If local government is to be affected by constitutional change, surely we should welcome the fact and not deride the fact that it is local government that is supporting this move.

I refer next to the contribution of the honourable member for Braddon, Mr Miles, in the debate in which he drew a picture of a situation resulting from this referendum proposal in which we would not have just Premiers conferences but lord mayors conferences, mayors conferences, shire presidents and wardens conferences, and so on. The Local Government Association has had something to say about this; it found it quite astonishing and somewhat of a joke.

It is interesting that the honourable member for Gippsland, Mr McGauran, in his contribution, said that like it or not local government is a creature of State governments. He is just condemning local government to being the creature of State governments in perpetuity. That does not indicate to me the sort of support which his Leader, Mr Sinclair, insisted local government has from the National Party. Mr McGauran went on to talk about the concerns that the third tier of government has about being under threat. He said:

. . . and to my knowledge it is not under threat from the Government; it is certainly not from the Opposition-and any fears it has about guaranteeing its future existence should be directed towards State governments.

Here I agree with Mr McGauran. I shall give two examples which are probably bipartisan in this instance. We see that there is and has been abuse of the power that State governments have over local governments. That is one of the reasons why many of us, including local government, are supporting constitutional recognition. An example of the abuse of power is the turfing out of the Sydney City Council by the Unsworth Government for goodness knows how long. No particular impropriety was even alleged except that the Council had the temerity to disagree with various State Government policies. There is demonstration of a lack of commitment to local government in my State of Victoria where a restructuring process was aborted because of the general incompetence of the Minister at the time and by the chairman of the local government commission charged with the task. Even now many councils are being subjected to unprecedented interference in the way they are elected. Not to appear one-sided in this debate, I also mention that I have some documentation from the Municipal Association of Victoria (MAV), which calls into question the commitment of the Liberal Party in Victoria to local government. Its local government spokesperson in State Parliament, Mr John Delzoppo, has had some discussions with the Municipal Association of Victoria subsequent to some comments made by a Liberal Party backbencher, a former municipal local councillor, Mr Vin Heffernan, who said:
Local councils have never been able to make a dollar, they wouldn't know how to make a dollar if they fell over it.

That caused some concern with the Municipal Association of Victoria. As the spokesperson, Mr Delzoppo sent out letters to local councils attempting to explain away the remarks, but there is considerable concern about the fact that those sorts of remarks should be made.

Referring again to Mr McGauran's contribution in the other place: he took it for granted, and it is obviously the Liberal Party's determination that it will not see anything done about it, that local government is a creature of State governments. He went on to say that local government is not under threat, but that can be no comfort whatsoever, and is no comfort to local government around Australia, as will be seen when I refer to some further material.

Of all the debate in the other place on this issue, it is worth noting the contribution of the honourable member for Sturt, Mr Wilson, who noted that he was the chairman of the Liberal-National Party committee on federalism in earlier years, a representative of the Liberal Party at the Constitutional Convention, and a representative of Parliament on the Advisory Council for Intergovernment Relations when it was still in existence. He went on to give a clear and sincere picture of the value of local government and its place in the three-tier government system. He went on as far as he could to back up his words by his actions in Parliament-something which should be commended. The contribution of the honourable member for Moncrieff, Mrs Sullivan, was also to be commended.

Subsequent to the debate in the House of Representatives, a statement was issued by the Australian Local Government Association, which is not surprising in the circumstances. It objected particularly to the picture that was painted of hundreds of mayors and shire presidents being called to local government versions of the Premiers Conference. The President of the Association, Mr Peter Kyle, said in a statement that these claims were simply untrue and that they were red herrings aimed at diverting voters' attention from the real issue. Senators should note the real issue as seen by the Australian Local Government Association, which is the fact that the Opposition has reneged on its commitment and is now assembling a series of excuses for its actions, some of which I have referred to from the debate in the House of Representatives.

I shall now refer further to the response to this from local government organisations, first recalling the contribution of the honourable member for Parkes, Mr Cobb, in the other House, in which he said that it is simply the case that only local government supports this constitutional change. Again, that is extraordinary arrogance and a dismissiveness of local government which is quite unwarranted and has received a due reaction.

I shall quote first from the Municipal Association of Victoria, my own State, which has swung into quick action to provide materials to its councils so that the campaign being waged by the Opposition can be countered. It has sent me a copy of the Press release it has been sending to its councils and it notes that it is the opening shot in a concerted battle between now and September to win constitutional recognition for local government. The arguments of the Opposition have not washed with local government.

The letter goes on to say that the Association had wanted a debate to be conducted in an apolitical atmosphere, and, of course, a local government organisation would want that. The letter then goes on to say:
Unfortunately this is not possible now that the Opposition has announced its intention to campaign for a no vote on the question.
As a guiding principle, the MAV has adopted a `what is best for local government' yardstick against which it will measure its conduct in this campaign.

As I have already said in my contribution, who better to make the case for local government than local government? The letter says that there will be further information but, in the meantime, it is important to get the public campaign started. It is important to put the next paragraph of the letter on the record. It states:
The information concerning the division in the Opposition over this question may well have changed in the time that it takes for this letter to reach you.

That is absolutely fascinating and shows the sensitivity that local government people have to what is going on in the Opposition. That shows the level of political awareness of local government. The letter was written on 20 May and it warns councils of goodness knows what the Opposition will be doing by the time the councils receive the letter. The letter concludes:
Please update and amend the release as you see fit.

The reference to `the division in the Opposition' is in the words of the MAV, not mine. A Press release sent out by the MAV is headed `A bit of respect is not too much to ask'. I have used the term `arrogance' in this debate to describe what I think is the approach of the Opposition on this referendum proposal. Obviously, the MAV has similar feelings. The first line of the Press release says:
The Federal Opposition has shown contempt for local communities.
It goes on to talk about the division within the Liberal Party, stating:

Some Liberals have told us privately that they support the notion of constitutional recognition for local government but they think people will be confused if they advocate a `no' vote for some questions and a `yes' vote for others.
Now that's real tokenism. And it's an insult to the collective intelligence of local communities.
A bit of respect for the rights of local communities is not too much to expect and I would urge the Opposition to change its stance on this issue.

That is revealing stuff coming from a major local government association. I have no doubt that similar Press releases have been going out in other States awaiting a campaign from the umbrella body, the Australian Local Government Association, whose draft Yes case I have with me. The draft rebuts the No case, and the Association sent a fax to me late this afternoon.

When I was speaking with the Director of the Australian Local Government Association, she pointed out to me that since the Opposition has been remarkably quick, it believes, to get the No case flying around the country, it felt it had better get in there and support its constituent bodies, as it is now doing. It has a comprehensive Yes case which answers the points that have been made in the debate in the House of Representatives. The case contains three pages refuting the claims that are made in the House of Representatives debate.

The salient points for the Yes case are made by local government and not by some Federal politicians who imagine that they know what is best for local government in a typically patronising way, which is particularly true of parties that always thought they were born to rule and that are perhaps starting to get a whiff of that again after recent electoral results. I suggest it would be no more than a whiff if they went back to the born to rule approach of thinking `We know what is best', which is paternalism at its worst.
The first point in the Yes case, from local government itself, is very instructive:
Constitutional recognition will acknowledge that Australia's federal system comprises three spheres of government working in partnership. No longer will these sentiments be mere rhetoric.
The second point is:

Federal Constitutional recognition will ensure that Local Government cannot be permanently replaced by State appointed administrators. Consequently, a system of elected Local Government in each State will be guaranteed.
Constitutional recognition will not centralise power. On the contrary, it will strengthen the system of decentralised community based government.

It points out, as is clear from the wording of the proposition, that each State shall provide for the establishment and continuance of a system of local government, with local government bodies elected in accordance with the laws of each State and empowered to administer and make by-laws for their respective areas in accordance with the laws of the State. The powers of the States are enshrined three times in the proposition that is before us and that will go before the people of Australia. I do not know how many more times the Opposition wants that. The ALGA goes on to say that how and where local government operates will still be determined in the parliaments of the States and so on. It makes a very important point in its fifth point, which states:
Federal and State politicians and bureaucrats will be more ready to consult with Local Government on the development and implementation of programs in which Local Government is involved.

I think there is no doubt about that. Constitutional recognition means status, which local government has not had before. It talks about new opportunities for local government to work productively with the Commonwealth and the States. It points out that local government is an important element of the public sector. In fact, it states:
Local Government's fiscal capacity equates to the combined budget sectors of Western Australia, Tasmania and the Northern Territory.
It cites figures to back that up and its significance. It also points out:
Constitutional recognition will not directly affect financial matters such as grants, Local Government taxation and borrowings.

It points out in its Yes case, as it does in refuting the No case, that these are issues for resolution at the political level, not in the Constitution. Local government has got it all clear in its mind what is political and what is constitutional. The Opposition clearly has not and is clearly still confused. The ALGA goes on to make the point, which has been made before in this debate, that:

If the Constitution were being written for the first time in 1988, there is little doubt that it would reflect today's reality, and acknowledge that Australia's federal system comprises three spheres of government.

As I have said, local government is, in the eyes of the Democrats, a very significant tier of government. From the Local Government Association's refuting of the No case I particularly wanted to draw attention to one of the points it makes about the Opposition's argument. The Opposition has often raised the issued that what the Government is trying to do here is water down in some way and centralise in some way aspects of local government. This is the claim made by those who want a No vote on this referendum:
Constitutional recognition is part of the Federal Labor Government's secret agenda to impose a network of regional governments across Australia.
Local government responds this way, and I think this is important:
More than two thirds of Australia's 836 Local Governments are voluntary members of regional associations and work with that form of Local Government regions effectively and happily.

I interpose here that in my experience at least many of those voluntary regional organisations of local government bodies are a continuation of, or are modelled on, the Australian Assistance Plan experience of the Whitlam years. I am pleased to see present Senator McLean, who was a participant in that process and who often speaks highly of it, as do many other people of my acquaintance. That it is voluntary is something to be commended and noted. The Local Government Association points to this as positive, not as negative. I simply put on the record that the Australian Democrats are strongly in support of this referendum proposal and that we share local government's astonishment at the sorts of scaremongering tactics that are taking place in this debate with reference to it.

I must say that sitting here in the chamber tonight I have been rather astonished to hear Senator Lewis oppose freedom of religion, perhaps a little less astonished to hear him oppose fair elections and quite astonished, as I have already said, to hear him oppose the right of local government to be recognised in the Constitution. I am astounded that he fails to understand the value of a move to four-year terms of office in both Houses of the Federal Parliament. I express the belief, as I am sure other speakers will, that the Australian people will see the merit in the particular proposition to which I have devoted most of my time, and, indeed, in the other propositions. Whilst none of them are absolutely perfect, they are steps in the right direction. They recognise the need for change in a Constitution which, whilst it may have been written by our founding fathers, was not written, nor should it have been, in stone never to be changed at any time in our history.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Short Sen J.R.

TALK.START.PARA: —The four Bills proposing constitutional change, which are the subject of this cognate debate, are a curious mixture. The first, the Constitution Alteration (Parliamentary Terms) Bill, goes to the core of our bicameral federal parliamentary system and seeks to disembowel the ability of the Senate to perform its two essential constitutional responsibilities. Those two responsibilities are, firstly, to be a House of review and, secondly, to be the protector of the interests of the States, and particularly the smaller States. The Bill contains three separate quite dishonestly disguised propositions about which I will speak later in this debate.

SPEECH.PARA: The second proposal, to give the Federal Government the power to dictate to the States what their electoral laws should be, strikes at the rights of the States as laid down in the Federal Constitution after years of the most meticulous and thorough debate by the drafters of the Constitution. The third, to specifically mention local government in the Federal Constitution, is a piece of meaningless motherhood nonsense that fails to deliver to local government either of the two essential objectives it seeks, namely, the right to deal with the Federal Government direct, and some form of guarantee on revenue sharing between Federal and State governments on the one hand and local government on the other. Let me interpose there to pick up a point that Senator Powell made in her remarks about the policy of the Liberal Party and the National Party and the suggestion that we are in some way backing away from our earlier policy. If she reads the policy documents for the last election properly, she will see that our policy was that we would examine, with State and local government, the most appropriate role for local government. That was the commitment we gave and we in no way back away from that.

The fourth referendum Bill, the Constitution Alteration (Rights and Freedoms) Bill 1988, is really three Bills in one, and as such is a dangerous mismatch. It deals with totally unrelated issues-freedom of religion, trial by jury and compensation for property acquisition by government. This seemingly innocuous proposal is in fact an attempt to introduce a Bill of Rights by a back door route. The Australian people will remember that less than two years ago the frontdoor route to a Bill of Rights was shut very firmly by the Senate at the request of, and with the overwhelming support of, the Australian people in perhaps the greatest expression of the voice of the people in Australia's history.

All four Bills, whilst containing at least eight separate proposals, have fatal flaws in terms of their constitutional validity, their inconsistency with our federal system and/or their technical drafting. Each of them should be soundly rejected by the Australian people when they are called upon to vote on them later this year. Let me here lay to rest one totally mischievous lie that is being assiduously peddled by certain sections of the media. That lie is that the Liberal and National parties are recommending a No vote to each of the four referendum proposals, rather than recommending one yes and three noes, or two and two or three and one, because we believe that is the most likely way to ensure the defeat of the most important proposal, which is the proposal for four-year parliamentary terms. That is simply untrue. Each of the four Bills is flawed. Each Bill should be rejected on its own merit. I will come back to the details of each Bill shortly.

However, before I do so I want to put to the Senate a brief overview. There are several points that should be made which have equal application to all four Bills. The first question we should look at is why the Government has brought these proposals into the Parliament at this late stage in the autumn parliamentary session. Why the indecent haste to rush these Bills through the Parliament without opportunity for adequate debate and reflection? We are talking about some quite fundamental issues here.
