What does the Government do? In the House of Representatives last week the Government adopted that most undemocratic of all parliamentary procedures-it gagged or guillotined the debate. It refused to allow the debate on these four Bills to continue, despite the fact that these Bills, taken together, constitute major proposed changes to our whole federal system of government.

That brings me to the second lie being peddled by sections of the media, namely, that these are non-controversial, unimportant issues. Paul Kelly, for example, was on this line yet again in today's Australian when he wrote:
Many people will ask how they-
that is, the Liberals-
could oppose such unremarkable and moderate reforms.

Let me repeat: these are not unremarkable and moderate reforms. One will drastically weaken the ability of the Senate to meet constitutional responsibilities, one will allow the Commonwealth Government to dictate to the States on their own electoral laws, one will introduce a Bill of Rights through the back door and one, whilst on the face of it a piece of meaningless nonsense, may well have the effect of disadvantaging local government as distinct from giving it what many might regard as its due and proper recognition.

The fact that these Bills are being put through the Parliament in the closing days of this session is ground for suspicion in itself as to the motives of the Government. That suspicion is magnified when we see that the Government has not even waited for the final report of its own chosen, appointed and hand-picked Constitutional Commission to be completed before it rushes in here with these half-baked proposals. Why did the Government appoint, at great cost, a Constitutional Commission in 1985 to advise it on constitutional change when it is not prepared to wait for the final report of that Commission before bringing into the Parliament certain proposals for fundamental constitutional change?

The Senate will recall that the Whitlam Government in 1973 established the Constitutional Convention to bring forward and discuss proposals for constitutional change. That Convention comprised members from the three elected tiers of government. In other words, its members were elected representatives of the people and, therefore, persons responsible to the people. But the Hawke Government in 1985 bypassed the Constitutional Convention and replaced it with its own hand-picked Constitutional Commission. I doubt whether many people would argue that, overall, the ideological bent of the majority of the Commission was left of the centre of the political spectrum.

Equally, there can be no doubt that the Hawke Government bypassed the Constitutional Convention and stacked the Constitutional Commission because Labor has always seen the Constitution as blocking its path towards radical reform of social and institutional structures in Australia. This attitude was clearly expressed by Gough Whitlam more than 30 years ago when, in delivering the 1957 Chifley Memorial Lecture, he said:

Labor finds itself confronted at every turn by a Constitution framed in such a way as to make it difficult to carry out Labor's objectives and interpreted in such a way as to make it impossible to carry them out.

Mr Whitlam, of course, is a member of the Government's hand-picked Constitutional Commission. That Labor Party attitude has not changed in the ensuing 30 years. In 1979 the now Prime Minister, Mr Hawke, in his Boyer Lecture series, described our constitutional arrangements as `anachronistic lunacy'. He had, in particular, the very existence of the States of the Commonwealth. In 1984, in a now famous speech to Labor's Fabian Society, Prime Minister Hawke said that the more general and deeper long range task facing the Labor Government was `the establishing in the mood and mind of the nation pre-eminent acceptance of the naturalness and inevitability of change and reform, as the authentic way of life'. When one takes these several statements of Labor philosophy together, they constitute the essential reasons why Labor wants to change the Constitution. Labor feels constrained by the Constitution in pursuing radical social and institutional reform in this country. As my colleague in the other place, Mr Alasdair Webster, said so accurately in relation to Labor when debating these Bills:
. . . would prefer to be free of the constraints of constitutional government in a Federal system, with a bicameral parliament . . .

That is what much of this debate is about. The four Bills before us are a mish-mash. One, relating to four-year parliamentary terms, is of fundamental importance to what I have just been saying. The other three are less fundamental, although each in its own way is significant. I am quite sure that the less fundamental Bills are being used as the coating for the poison pill of the parliamentary terms proposal.

Introducing these Bills at this time is also good political tactics for the Government. Labor is in desperate shape in the electorate and is deeply divided on policy issues within its own ranks. What better diversionary tactics to adopt in such circumstances than to attempt to sidetrack the attention of the electorate on to other issues and away from the fundamental economic and related issues that we face? It is difficult to escape these conclusions. How else can one explain rationally why the Government would spend $6m on a Constitutional Commission and then not wait for that Commission to produce its final report? Why else would the Government proceed then to spend a further $35m or so on actually conducting the referendums later this year? The sum of $35m is a lot of taxpayers' money, whichever way one looks at it and especially so if one really believes, as some would have us believe, that the proposals are `unremarkable and moderate'.

The final general point I want to make before turning to each of the four Bills is that the actual questions that will be asked in the four referendums are highly misleading and are blatantly biased in favour of a yes vote. In a paper delivered to the Ninth Australian Statistical Conference last week, Gary Morgan, the Managing Director of Australia's leading polling organisation, the Roy Morgan Research Centre, and his research director, Michelle Levine, had this to say:

There is no doubt that the proposed referendum questions are biased to try to obtain a yes vote. In addition, the questions do not honestly convey the issues being asked . . . Any public opinion polling company who asked questions as blatantly biased as the Government's proposals would completely lose credibility.

There are many different ways of asking so-called opinion questions. That is why it is critically important that the voters of Australia be made fully aware of the real content behind the bland and superficially attractive questions that will be put to them in the four referendums. That is the task before the Opposition over the next three or four months between now and the actual polling day. The first question that will be put to voters is:
Do you agree that the Constitution should be altered to provide for four-year maximum terms for members of both Houses of the Commonwealth Parliament?

A yes vote to that seemingly innocuous question would greatly weaken the ability of the Senate to carry out its responsibility to act as a House of review and as a watchdog on the rights of the States. The actual proposal contains four distinct elements but they are hidden in the question. The four elements there are, firstly, increase the maximum term for the House of Representatives from three years to four years; secondly, reduce the maximum term for senators from six years to four years; thirdly, abolish the rotation system for senators whereby half the senators are up for re-election each time; and fourthly, abolish the concept of fixed terms for senators and replace it with the concept that all senators should face the electors each time the House of Representatives is put to an election at the whim of the Prime Minister of the day, whoever he might be and from whatever Party. Those are the direct effects of the first referendum question if it wins a yes vote. Those four provisions are contained in the Bill we are now debating but they will not be presented to the people.

The Liberal and National parties agree with the first of these four elements. Of course, we agree that there should be a lengthening of the maximum term of the House of Representatives and we agree that a lengthening to four years is appropriate, but we do not agree with the other three hidden elements in the proposal. By choosing this particular form of the four-year proposal the Government deliberately picked the very one with which it knew the Opposition would not and could not agree. We told the Government that a year ago. There are other ways in which the Government could have approached the four-year terms for the House of Representatives that would have had bipartisan support from the Opposition, but the Government deliberately chose not to do so.

TALK.START.PARA: —Rubbish.

—The Minister knows perfectly well that that is correct. Over recent years the Senate has played a quite vital role on behalf of the Australian people. It was only because of the position of the Senate that we were able to implement the will of the people by preventing the introduction of the Hawke Government's sinister and Orwellian ID card proposal. A similar situation occurred with the Government's horrendous Bill of Rights proposal. It is now trying to sneak this proposal through the back door as part of this package of referendum Bills.

SPEECH.PARA: The reason the Senate was able to act in this way, to stand up for the rights of the Australian people and to implement their wishes, was that we have the fixed rotation system, whereby senators have fixed terms of office, not dependent on the political whim of the government of the day, whatever the political colour of that government, and whereby half the total number of senators face the electorate each three years. These two fundamental elements of the existing system provide stability in the Senate plus a degree of independence for senators from day-to-day pressures of political forces-pressures which not infrequently lead to bad decisions being taken for cynical and expedient reasons determined entirely by short-term political considerations rather than the long-term interests of Australia and Australians. If we remove this stability and independence from the Senate we will, in one single stroke, let the Australian Labor Party achieve one of its most sought after agenda items-the destruction of the ability of the Senate to provide checks and balances against the excesses of executive government, the excess of any party bent on radical reform, and the overthrow of our existing social and institutional systems.

It is no secret that that is Labor's agenda. The former Attorney-General, the present Deputy Leader of the Government in the Senate (Senator Gareth Evans), made that crystal clear in his maiden speech in this place when he said:
The way to abolish the Senate, or at least muzzle it, is to whiteant it from within.

That is precisely what this proposal is all about. One of the Government's claimed benefits of the proposal-indeed, perhaps the main rationale for the proposal-is that it would lead to fewer elections. That is a very dubious argument. The way in which the proposal has been framed could well lead to more frequent elections because it removes the Senate constraint from the Prime Minister of the day when deliberating on whether to call an early election. The proposal, as drafted, also suffers from the major disadvantage of almost guaranteeing the continued existence of splinter and minority parties in the Senate, and that is quite patently inconsistent with the desirability of a stable political system.

The second referendum question we are being asked to approve is this: Do you agree that the Constitution should be altered to provide for fair and democratic parliamentary elections throughout Australia? One could well ask, `How could anyone possible disagree with such a proposition?'. I think the answer from most people, certainly on the Liberal side of politics, would be, `Of course we agree with fair and democratic elections. We always have and we always will'. But, as with the first referendum question, this second one also contains major elements which are either misleadingly presented to, or deliberately withheld from, the people.

The proposal is that the number of electors in each electorate will be equal when it comes to voting in both lower and upper House elections for all State parliaments, subject to a 10 per cent tolerance factor either side of equality. In essence, this is what we have now for House of Representatives elections for the Federal Parliament and we agree with that so far as the House of Representatives is concerned. It is also what already exists in several of the States, the major exceptions being Queensland and Western Australia. But it is not what we have in the Senate. In the Senate there are 12 senators for each State, totally regardless of the population of the State. Thus Tasmania, with a population of about half a million, returns 12 senators and so do Victoria and New South Wales with populations in excess of three million and four million respectively. That is a provision that was written into the Constitution for very good and valid reasons-equal representation from the States in the upper House. We would not have had a federation without that proposal being accepted.

The Government's referendum proposal, though, does not alter the Senate position. The Government is proposing to foist on to the States an electoral system that it is not prepared to adopt for itself. That is unfair, it is discriminatory and it is downright arrogant. The Government's so-called fair elections proposal has two other major defects. The first is that it does not provide for fair elections. Whilst it would lead to more equal numbers of electors in each electorate in Queensland and Western Australia and in the Tasmanian upper House-the numbers in the other States are already fairly equal-it would not tackle the major cause of unfair elections which is the gerrymander.

TALK.START.PARA: —Oh, rubbish.

—Senator Ray knows that. A gerrymander results when the boundaries between electorates are drawn in such a way as to prevent elections being decided on the basis of 50 per cent of the vote plus one. This is very different from having unequal numbers of electors in each electorate. As we know, that is called malapportionment and that is what the referendum proposal is directed to. But I repeat that the main cause of unfair elections in Australia is the gerrymander, not malapportionment.
—Prove it, come on. Give some examples.

—I am coming to that. This Bill does not tackle the problem of the gerrymander at all. Indeed, according to my colleague Dr Wooldridge in the House of Representatives, it is possible that this Bill will increase the gerrymander that exists in Queensland and Western Australia. The extent of gerrymanders around Australia can be seen from the fact that, to win the next Federal election, the Liberal and National parties will require 52 1/2 per cent of the total vote. In Victoria the corresponding figure is 51.3 per cent and in South Australia, 52.2 per cent. The coalition needed 52.8 per cent of the vote to win the New South Wales State election two months ago. The Senate should note that in each of these cases the so-called fair election proposals contained in this Bill already exist in the situations I have just cited.

SPEECH.PARA: This Bill is obviously aimed at Queensland and Western Australia. In Queensland, Labor needs 51.3 per cent of the vote to win. In Western Australia, the Liberal Party of Australia needs 52.2 per cent to win. All those figures show that Queensland is the least gerrymandered State so far as Labor is concerned. It is the Liberals who suffer from the gerrymander in Queensland, not Labor. The other point to note is that in only one instance does the gerrymander work against Labor. In all other instances it advantages Labor. So much for fair elections! This Bill will do nothing to reduce the unfairness the electoral systems around Australia currently show in Labor's favour.

But the other and most damning indictment of this referendum proposal is that it seeks to impose Commonwealth House of Representatives electoral laws on to the States. As the Leader of the Opposition, Mr John Howard, said in the debate in the other place last week:

I utterly and completely endorse the concept of fair and democratic elections but I hold very strongly to the principle that the conditions governing elections for the States should be a matter for the parliaments of the States.

On each of at least three counts this proposal is basically flawed and must be rejected. The third question to be put to the voters is: `Do you approve of altering the Constitution to recognise local government?' In fact, the words proposed to be included in the Constitution do nothing of the kind so far as Commonwealth recognition is concerned. The wording is:

Each State shall provide for the establishment and continuance of a system of local government, with local government bodies elected in accordance with the laws of the State and empowered to administer, and make by-laws for, their respective areas in accordance with the laws of the State.

Honourable senators should note that the word `Commonwealth' is not even mentioned in the clause. There is no reference to revenue sharing arrangements or to the ability of local government to deal directly with the Federal Government. There is no guarantee against wrongful dismissal of a local council by a vindictive State government or any of the other matters which local government is seeking to have recognised. There is not even a definition of local government. The constitutional lawyers will have a field day with this proposal if it is passed. Quite frankly, the proposal is an insult to local government, even though it was obviously designed as a worthless sop. Worse though, through its very wording it even more firmly entrenches local government as a creature of the States, a shadow from which they have for years quite rightly been struggling to emerge.

There is no doubt that, when it comes to comparing actual policies towards local government, the Liberal and National Party record stands tall and proud. It was a Liberal and National Party government that introduced personal income tax sharing, that introduced the bicentennial road funding program and that provided a forum for local government to be heard.

TALK.START.PARA: —We introduced that.

—It was part of the federalism policy of the Fraser Government. The Labor Party tried to chop out local government and substitute regional government. Where it really counts, for example, in road funding, the Hawke Government has slashed road funding to local governments by 25 per cent in real terms over the past five years. It is about time this Government ceased its meaningless, insulting tokenism towards local government and instead developed some policies of real benefit to this vitally important third tier of government.

SPEECH.PARA: Time will prevent me from commenting too much on the fourth referendum proposal which covers three totally unrelated matters, other than to say, as I said earlier, that it constitutes an attempt to introduce a Bill of Rights through the back door. But on the package as a whole I conclude where I commenced: all four referendum Bills are fatally flawed. They are designed to pave the way for the removal of constitutional restraint over the Federal Government. They dramatically weaken the ability of the Senate to carry out its responsibilities on behalf of the people of Australia. They do not provide for fairer elections. They do not assist local government in any way whatsoever, and they are a thoroughly dishonest attempt to introduce a Bill of Rights which has already been comprehensively rejected by the Australian people. All four proposals not only deserve to be defeated when put to the people but, in the interests of our federal system and the integrity of our basic statute law, namely, the Constitution, they must be defeated.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Maguire Sen G.R.

TALK.START.PARA: —This evening, we are debating the Government's four referendum Bills-the Constitution Alteration (Parliamentary Terms) Bill 1988, the Constitution Alteration (Fair Elections) Bill 1988, the Constitution Alteration (Local Government) Bill 1988, and the Constitution Alteration (Rights and Freedoms) Bill 1988. We are considering also another Bill, the Constitution Alteration (Electors' Initiative) Bill 1987. In opening my remarks, I place on record that these Bills do not in any way give more powers to the government of the day, despite the nonsense that has been parroted tonight. In fact, they are not designed to give advantage to any political party; rather, their only concern is to guarantee the democratic rights of the Australian people.

SPEECH.PARA: Four fundamental rights are addressed by the Bills which will give effect to these referenda proposals. The first is: the people's right to a more stable, responsible government at the national level. The second right is the people's right to vote at free and fair elections-cleaning up the abuses of the voting system in the Queensland Legislative Assembly, cleaning up the abuses of voting in the upper Houses in Tasmania and Western Australia and, in those ways, dragging those recalcitrant States into the twentieth century with regard to electoral reform. The third right is the people's right to have the important third tier of government-I refer to local government-recognised as part of the Constitution. The fourth right is the people's right to have certain inalienable rights and freedoms guaranteed in the Australian Constitution, including trial by jury, just compensation for compulsorily acquired property and freedom of religion. These rights are taken up in the four referendum Bills.

The Government recognises that the Constitution is not an immutable, fossilised relic, but a living document which is capable of change and adaptation to the needs of the nation. The changes proposed in these Bills seek to establish in the Constitution a number of basic political, civil, judicial and religious rights. They are rights and freedoms which are central to every democratic nation-rights such as one vote one value which are part of the democratic consensus of parliamentary systems of government around the world.

The Government had hoped that all political parties would respect this democratic consensus and approach the Bills in the same spirit of non-partisanship. Unfortunately, this is not the case. The Liberal and National parties have decided to turn the referendum Bills into a political football. They have decided to oppose all four Bills for no other reason than to gain short term political advantage. They have turned the debate on constitutional change into a grubby little exercise of political posturing.

By opposing the democratic rights contained in the Bills, the coalition hoped to score a few cheap political points off the Government. But, in doing so, the Liberals and Nationals have exposed the full extent of their political bankruptcy and opportunism. The reality is that the Liberals and Nationals are desperately looking for an issue on which to defeat the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke). That is the reality: they are not looking at the long term benefits of these proposals, but simply are desperately looking for an issue on which they can try to defeat the Prime Minister. They are desperately trying to turn the process of political and constitutional reform into a referendum on the Prime Minister. That is how one should examine it. They are simply trying to turn it into a referendum on the performance of the Government. Because they have had so many defeats over the last five years, Mr Howard is so unpopular as a leader and the coalition is hopelessly divided and torn apart, they want a diversion. They want to divert attention from their internal problems. They do not care about the long term advantages and benefits for the people of Australia. They want short term, cheap political gains.

I have noted, as have members of the Australian community, that a few of the more principled members of the Liberal Party have not voted with the Opposition on some of these Bills in another place. It is a pity that other members of the Liberal Party did not have the courage of their convictions to defy the Opposition, the Howard leadership and National Party vetoes. Perhaps in September a number of Liberal members of parliament will vote yes in the secrecy of the voting cubicles. I would be fascinated to be a fly on the wall in some of those voting cubicles. I would imagine that a number of members of the Opposition will vote yes to these proposals in the secrecy of the voting compartments when referendum day comes around. The Government's proposal contained in the parliamentary terms Bill is for a four-year maximum term for both Houses, with elections to be held concurrently for the Senate and the House of Representatives. The proposal for a four-year maximum term for both Houses will mean greater stability, fewer elections and better government in Australia, because Australia has had far too many elections.

Since 1945, on my calculations, expensive elections have occurred on average about every two years. That is the reality in this country. In current dollar terms elections cost some $50m to conduct. Several Australian State parliaments have four-year terms. That is the reality. This proposal is not coming from outer space and foisting something new on the Australian landscape. The fact is that several State governments have four-year terms. A majority of democratic nations around the world have four-year or five-year terms. I instance in the last week or so the run-off in the French presidential elections. President Francois Mitterrand was elected for not four or five years but seven years. Yet the rabble in this place is trying to turn the clock back on even trying to get a four-year term for Australian parliaments.

A four-year term would give governments more time to plan in a very complex age. It would give them more time to implement policies so that they could take more difficult, long-term decisions about Australia's future without having one eye on the poll results all the time. Frequent elections may force business to defer important planning decisions. Investors' confidence could be undermined because of uncertainty about economic policy with frequent elections occurring. There is a need for greater stability in government in Australia. It is critical if Australia is to face the economic challenges of the next century. I note in passing that the Government has decided not to propose a fixed minimum term for Parliament. There have been occasions when matters of national importance have had to be taken immediately to the people. Fixed terms clearly would reduce the powers of this House. Those opposite go on about weakening the powers of this House. Fixed terms would have done that. They have not referred to that in this debate, but that policy was not adopted by the Government.

The Liberal and National Party objections to this Bill centre on the Senate's powers. They claim that the Senate's powers would be reduced or undermined. But the Senate's power would not be affected in any way by the proposal for four-year terms. My view of the situation is that the Senate's powers probably would be strengthened because senators could argue to the community that they had been elected more recently and therefore their views should be heeded more by the community. I think that is a very strong argument. The reverse of the position taken by the coalition parties probably would apply: the fact that all the Senate had been elected more recently is a very strong selling point to the community and would give senators enormously more credibility in putting their views and asking for them to be supported in the community.

Under these proposals, the Senate still would be able to amend and reject any legislation, including Supply. The Government rejected the Constitutional Commission's recommendation which would have removed the Senate's power to block Supply in the first three years of a parliament. The Leader of the Opposition, Mr Howard, claims that he would have given bipartisan support to this Bill if the Government had agreed to keep Senate terms at twice the length of House of Representatives terms. That is, with a four-year House of Representatives term, I imagine he was talking about an eight-year term for senators. That would result in a situation in which senators probably would not have to face more than three elections in a quarter of a century. I am sure that would be unacceptable to the Australian community. It would be an unwise, unhealthy and unacceptable position.

What lurks behind the objections of the Liberals and Nationals to the four-year term concept is naked self-interest and unbridled political opportunism because coalition members fear that the four-year term for the Senate would mean an end to their ability to block the Supply of an elected government in the House of Representatives. They want the power to force an election for the House of Representatives without all senators having to face a simultaneous election. That is what it boils down to. At present, only half the Senate is required to face the people if the Senate blocks Supply and forces an election for the House of Representatives.

This anomaly in the Constitution was ruthlessly exploited by the Liberals and Nationals in November 1975. The coalition used its majority in the Senate to block Supply of the Whitlam Government and force an election in the belief that the expected half-Senate election would not affect its majority in the Senate. The Liberals and Nationals want to retain the privilege of being able to force an election without facing the full political consequences of their action. At present, a government can win an election, forced by the Senate, in the House of Representatives but still be left facing a hostile majority in the Senate-despite winning that majority in the House of Representatives. That is one of the key propositions: a government could win an election forced by the Senate but still be left facing a hostile majority in the Senate under the present arrangements.

The Hawke Government is simply asking the Australian people to close this loophole in the Australian Constitution. The Government's proposal will mean that all senators will face the people simultaneously with the House of Representatives. If the Senate blocks Supply and forces an election, it will have to answer to the people for its actions: all senators will face re-election at the same time as members of the House of Representatives.

I would like to turn briefly to the third question being proposed; that is, the recognition of local government in the Australian Constitution. In my State of South Australia I have noted that over the period since this was first mooted it has been an extremely popular proposal amongst officers and members of that vital third tier of Australian government, local government. I must say that over the years I think I have had more representation from local governments on this subject than on any other ranging from the councils in the south-east of my State to those in the very far west. This proposal for constitutional recognition has been and is very popular. I am greatly disappointed by the position taken by the Opposition over this particular proposal. In fact, today I sent a letter to local government representatives in my State expressing my disappointment and suggesting that they send a `please explain' letter to Liberal members in South Australia telling them to own up and to try to justify this extraordinary decision on local government recognition.

There is a certain flaw in the Opposition's position on local government recognition. The Opposition is describing our third proposal as tokenism despite the very strong wishes of local government-I am sure Senator Reynolds as Minister for Local Government is aware of this-which overwhelmingly supports it. Local government does not believe, as Mr Howard would have us believe, that it is tokenism. We can only instance the comments made by the Australian Local Government Association and its amazement and disappointment. A real slap has been given to local government by this Opposition on this proposal for recognition of local government in the Australian Constitution. So there it is: tokenism is the response of the Liberal Party to the third referendum proposal; tokenism on the recognition of local government in the Australian Constitution.

We can contrast that position with the Opposition's position on the first referendum question; that is, on four-year terms. It is not saying that that is tokenism, it is saying we are going too far. So, when the Australian people go to consider two referendum questions on the ballot paper in September, the Liberals will, on the first one, be saying that the Government is going too far and, on the third one, be saying that it is tokenism and that we are not going far enough. What an internal contradiction. What an untenable position for an opposition to be in. Opposition members are being led up the garden path by Mr Howard. They are in a very awkward position because there is a total contradiction in their positions on two questions on the referendum ballot paper. On the face of the position of this referendum question one can only conclude that if they will not support this referendum it is hard to see their supporting any beneficial programs for local government.

We have to contrast the Opposition's position on these proposals-a position which has been cobbled together subject to the veto of the National Party-with the position of the Labor Party when it was in opposition. I take honourable senators back to 1977 when Mr Fraser was Prime Minister and Mr Howard was a senior Minister in his Government. He was not quite Treasurer and he had not mucked up the Australian economy at that stage. On 21 May 1977, 11 years ago last weekend, Mr Howard and his Government put four referendum questions to the Australian people-for simultaneous elections for the House of Representatives and the Senate, for the filling of casual vacancies in the Senate, proposals that citizens of the Australian Territories should be able to vote in referendums, and provisions for retiring ages of judges. That was in 1977. The Liberals were in power; the Labor Party was in opposition. We went out and supported those proposals. We did not try to turn the referendum campaign into some sort of censure of the Fraser Government. We did not try to take the irresponsible position of looking for some way of defeating the government of the day by finding an issue on which we could win. We went out and actively campaigned for those proposals. Right around Australia, in the cities, the towns and the small communities, we urged people to support those referendums. I am pleased to say that three out of the four were carried in 1977 with the support of the government of the day, the Liberal Party, and the Opposition Labor Party.

That is the contrast between 1977 and our bicentennial year, 1988. When we try to make some modest improvements in the Australian Constitution we find this incredible contrast between the behaviour of the Liberals in opposition and the Labor Party in opposition in 1977. In 1977 we had a constructive Labor opposition that went out and campaigned for those referendum proposals. In 1988 we have a destructive and negative Liberal opposition, one which opposes simply for the sake of opposing. That is what it comes down to; it is a negative, knocking, carping opposition which opposes for the sake of opposing. The Liberals and the Nationals do not constitute an alternative government. They just do not measure up. They are just a bunch of destructive, disunited no-hopers. Their referendum case has been hastily cobbled together and the people will pass judgment on it in September.

Do you approve of an Act to alter the Constitution to recognise local government?

Naturally everybody would say, `Yes, give local government a go'. But this referendum does nothing-and the question certainly does not say this-for local government. It is a symbolic gesture and nothing else. But the phrasing of the question does not give that inference. Then we get on to question No. 4. It states:

Do you approve of an Act to alter the Constitution to extend the right to trial by jury, to extend freedom of religion and to ensure fair terms for persons whose property is acquired by any government?

Anybody would think that we did not have freedom of religion and trial by jury. Of course Australians have those benefits and rights. There is a very great danger if this Government or the people of Australia allow that sort of question to go through. If the Government were serious about freedoms it should put the question: Do you allow people the freedom not to join a union? That is the sort of freedom people out there are interested in. They know they have freedom of religion and trial by jury but the Government will not allow them the freedom not to join a union. That is the sort of freedom the people are interested to know whether the Government will give them. I will start from the beginning and go through the questions in detail.
